questions.text: Relapse is seen in ?
questions.solution:
Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and ovale.

Malaria relapse :

In case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts and others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites.

True relapse is caused due to hypnozoites (resting forms). Some get activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.

In case of Plasmodium falciparum and malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

questions.text: During ward rounds, the neonatologist tries to pick up the newborn. You observe the sign as shown in the image given below. The presence of this sign is considered abnormal after ________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pull-to-sit maneuver being performed and there is a complete head lag on picking up the child. The presence of this sign is abnormal if it persists beyond 20 weeks.

In the newborn, the head completely lags and the back is rounded. The head lag disappears once neck control is achieved and the child starts to flex his head when trying to pick up from the supine position.

The head control first begins to develop at 6 weeks, and there is a slight lag at 12 weeks. Complete neck control is attained by 20 weeks, after which, the infant lifts the head from the supine position when about to be pulled.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dull pain and heaviness over the right lower abdomen for two months. Imaging reveals a right-sided multiloculated cystic ovarian mass and cystic dilation of the appendix, with mural calcification. Which among the following conditions is most likely associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
The condition most likely to be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei among the given options is a mucinous ovarian tumor.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to abundant mucoid or gelatinous material surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule in the pelvis or abdominal cavity that results from an ovarian mucinous carcinoma with ascites. 

Mucinous ovarian tumors are predominantly true epithelial tumors and are mostly undetected primary intestinal cancers of the appendix or colon. Ovarian mucinous tumors associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei are usually metastatic tumors.

Well-differentiated type of mucinous tumors resembles those that originate from the intestine or endocervix. These are mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas. Advanced mucinous ovarian tumors have the worst prognosis. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors

questions.text: You are a researcher conducting a study in an urban young population regarding skin melanoma. You formulate a hypothesis on etiology. Which of the following studies is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis?
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis.

Descriptive statistics is a type of statistical method which helps to describe, organise or summarise the data. It refers only to the actual data.

Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease, including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population. Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology. There is no intervention in this type of study. it is merely observational.

It involves the following: 

  • Defining the study population 
  • Defining the disease under the study
  • Describing the disease by parameters like time, place and person
  • Measuring the disease
  • Comparing it with known indices and
  • Formulating an etiological hypothesis.

The formulated hypothesis should specify the following:   

  • The study population 
  • The cause which is taken into consideration
  • Expected outcome
  • Dose-response relationship
  • Time-response relationship

Types of epidemiological studies:

Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.

  1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population.
  2. Analytical studies - go further by analysing the relationship between health status and other variables.
    • Ecological studies
    • Cross-sectional studies
    • Case-control studies
    • Cohort studies

Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences.

  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials      

Other options:

Option A: Analytical study is a type of epidemiological study and its objective is to test the hypothesis. 

Option B: Experimental studies involve making changes in the experimental group while no changes are made in the control group and comparing the outcome. 

Option C: A cross-sectional study or prevalence study is a form of observational study. A cross-section of the population at one point in time is examined and it reflects the results of the whole population. 

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: A patient who is recovering from head trauma due to a road traffic accident has difficulty planning sequential movements.  Which of the following parts of the brain is likely to be damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario where a patient has difficulty planning sequential movements is suggestive of damage to the cerebrocerebellum.

Cerebrocerebellum consists of the large lateral zones of the cerebellar hemispheres, lateral to the intermediate zones. It is involved in the planning and timing of the sequential movements, and in the extra-motor prediction of the movements.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with inflammatory bowel disease in remission comes to you for a follow-up. She is on azathioprine to prevent recurrence. Which of the following should be advised?

choices.text: Routine analysis of complete blood count

questions.solution:
Routine analysis of complete blood count for the duration of the azathioprine therapy should be advised.

Azathioprine is a purine analog commonly used in the treatment of moderate to severe inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It is an immunosuppressant that can be used alone or in combination with other drugs. It is used alone in patients in remission to prevent a recurrence. Side effects include hepatotoxicity, arthralgia, and pancreatitis. Bone marrow suppression is a dose-related adverse effect and warrants regular monitoring of complete blood counts. Regular liver function tests are also recommended. 

Inflammatory bowel disease includes ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. Ulcerative colitis is a recurrent condition marked by mucosal inflammation restricted to the colon. Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural inflammation of any section of the gastrointestinal tract.

Laboratory investigations usually show elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin can be used to differentiate it from irritable bowel syndrome. In ulcerative colitis, a sigmoidoscopy is usually done before treatment to assess disease activity while a colonoscopy is done when the disease is not active. A colonoscopy also allows visualization and biopsy of mass lesions and strictures in Crohn's disease. 

IBD can be medically managed by 5-aminosalicylic acid agents such as sulfasalazine and mesalamine. Other drugs used are azathioprine, mercaptopurine, methotrexate, glucocorticoids, and anti-tumor necrosis factors. Indications for surgery are extensive bleeding, intestinal obstruction, symptomatic perianal fistulas, and unresponsiveness to medical therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening for skin cancer is recommended in patients who are prescribed anti-tumor necrosis factor anti-TNF agents such as infliximab or adalimumab. These drugs increase the risk of developing melanoma.

Option B: Folate supplementation is recommended in patients on methotrexate in addition to liver function tests and CBC monitoring.

Option D: The patient should avoid pregnancy while on treatment with methotrexate. Methotrexate is a known teratogen and should be stopped at least 3-6 months before conception.

questions.text: A baby born at 32 weeks of gestation developed tachypnea, grunting, and cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed a ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with chest x-ray showing ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram is consistent with the diagnosis of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease) is primarily seen in premature infants. It is commonly seen before 28 weeks, followed by 32-36 weeks, and is rare after 37 weeks.

Risk factors for RDS include:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Multiple births
  • Cesarean section
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Asphyxia
  • Maternal history of previously affected infants

The primary cause of RDS is reduced production and secretion of surfactant. It leads to an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse.

The clinical features include tachypnea, prominent expiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. They usually appear within minutes of birth. 

Chest radiograph shows diffuse, fine reticular granularity of the parenchyma known as ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram.

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) is the initial intervention in infants with RDS or in infants at risk of RDS without respiratory failure. Oxygen therapy with warm, humidified oxygen is provided to maintain a target SpO2 of 91-95%. 

Mechanical ventilation is indicated in infants with respiratory failure or persistent apnea. 

Prevention is possible by antenatal administration of betamethasone or dexamethasone before 37 weeks is recommended in preterm labor as it reduces the incidence and mortality of RDS.

Other options:

Option B: Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limiting clinical condition caused due to delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. Early-onset tachypnea, expiratory grunting or retractions, and occasional cyanosis are the characteristic findings. 

The chest radiograph reveals prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the interlobar fissures. It is distinguished from RDS by its rapid recovery and the absence of radiographic findings of RDS.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in the transient tachypnea of the newborn.

Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs secondary to a structural defect of the diaphragm and is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia. Babies present with tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, cyanosis, and scaphoid abdomen. The chest radiograph shows bowel loops in the thorax and the contralateral mediastinal shift.

The image given below is the chest radiograph showing multiple gas shadows in the thorax indicating congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Option D: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the passage of meconium into the amniotic fluid due to fetal distress and hypoxia that gets aspirated into the lungs. It usually occurs in term or post-term infants. The clinical features include tachypnea, retractions, grunting, and cyanosis. The chest radiograph reveals bilateral streaky densities, hyperinflation, flattening of the diaphragm, and atelectasis.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in meconium aspiration syndrome.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
B cell is not a component of innate immunity. It is a component of adaptive immunity.

Innate immunity refers to the body’s natural immunity. It is a built-in defence system that is present since birth. It differs from adaptive immunity in that it does not require any prior sensitization to an antigen.

The major components of innate immunity are as follows:

  • Epithelial barriers that block the entry of microbes
  • Phagocytic cells (neutrophils and macrophages)
  • Natural killer (NK) cells
  • Dendritic cell
  • Cells that can sense and react to microbes - mast cells, epithelial and endothelial cells
  • Plasma proteins - complement system factors, mannose-binding lectin, and C-reactive protein
  • Innate lymphoid cells  
  • Lung surfactant 

Related Pearl: Innate and Adaptive Immunity

Innate immunity

Adaptive immunity

Immediate maximal response

Lag phase between exposure and maximal response

Non-specific

Highly pathogen-specific

Limited diversity

Extensively diverse

No memory

Memory present

Subsequent exposure → Amplified response

Receptors: Pattern-recognition receptors

Receptors: T-cell and B-cell receptors

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with an obstetric score of G2P1, presented to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation, with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain abdomen and vaginal bleeding. She has a past history of classical Cesarean section 3 years ago. A uterine scar rupture is suspected in this patient. All of the following findings indicate uterine scar rupture, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of station of presenting part

questions.solution:
Maternal tachycardia (not bradycardia) is a feature of uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is one in which all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa ) are disrupted any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labor, manual removal of placenta, dilatation, and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features of scar dehiscence:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the primary health centre with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He reports having reduced sensation in his feet. After addressing the wound, he is referred to another centre to receive microcellular rubber footwear. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this scenario?

choices.text: The ministry of health and family welfare has sponsored this program
The aim is to reduce the complications of this disease
This is a tertiary level of prevention
The district hospital will supply the microcellular footwear

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding this scenario is that the district hospital will supply the microcellular (MCR) footwear. The district nucleus supplies the MCR footwear, not the district hospital. 

In the given scenario, the patient has developed multiple abrasions and cuts secondary to insensitive feet suggestive of neuropathy. To reduce further complications this patient is referred to the district nucleus to receive the MCR footwear. This is a form of tertiary prevention since it reduces the number and impact of complications. 

National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) is a program of the ministry of health and family welfare, the government of India. It is sponsored centrally and the program has the following components: 

  • Case detection and management   
  • Disability prevention and medical rehabilitation (DPMR)   
  • Information, education and communication (IEC) including behaviour change communication (BCC)
  • Human resource and capacity building   
  • Program management

During the year 2017-2018, India reported 1,26,164 new cases with an annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) of 9.27/1,00,000 population. 

The system of the levels of implementation and referral in the NLEP is shown below:

questions.text: Which of the following tests is denoted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given test is Adson’s test done for evaluation of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome is a syndrome occurring due to neurovascular bundle compression in the thoracic outlet. Its causes include: 

  • Cervical rib
  • Anomalous insertion of the scalene muscles
  • Tumors in the neck region
  • Brachial plexus trauma and diseases. 

The image below shows the cervical rib. 

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has been started on clozapine. Which of the following is the most serious side effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
The most serious side effect of clozapine is agranulocytosis. 

Clozapine is an atypical anti-psychotic drug that acts via D4 receptors and 5­HT2 as well as α adrenergic block. It is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia. 

Other side effects of clozapine include diabetes, weight gain, sedation, hypersalivation, fever, tachycardia, and postural hypotension. Seizures are more common with clozapine than with other antipsychotic drugs. 

Other options:

Option A - Corneal & lenticular deposits are seen with chlorpromazine which is a typical antipsychotic. 

Option B - Prolongation of QT is seen with ziprasidone which is an atypical antipsychotic. 

Option C - Extrapyramidal side effects are less common with clozapine, but more frequently seen with typical antipsychotics. They are acute dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, akathisia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome etc. 

 

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation
Amisulpride Hyperprolactinemia
Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia 

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: A elderly male patient complains of chest pain at rest. He previously experienced it on exertion. ECG shows ST depression, with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina based on the clinical features given. Unstable angina is a subtype of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

ACS includes:

1. Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

  • Unstable angina
  • Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

2. ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The former, which includes unstable angina arises due to an imbalance in the myocardial oxygen supply-demand ratio. They present with characteristic features such as chest pain at rest, of recent onset, and lasting for more than ten minutes. It usually lasts longer or is more severe than previous episodes. (crescendo pattern). The pain is usually retrosternal and might radiate to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw. 

ECG may show new ST-segment depression in one-third of the patients. It can be transient or may last for several days in NSTEMI. In unstable angina, there is no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, namely cardiac troponin I or cardiac troponin T. In other words, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis.

Stable angina is marked by ischemic episodes which present as chest pain, precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest. 

Other options:

Option A: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, a component of ACS, presents with similar symptoms. In contrast to unstable angina, there are elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers.

Option B: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, occurs due to occlusion of a coronary artery by thrombus. Usually, these vessels are already affected by atherosclerosis. The chest pain may last for more than 30 minutes, associated with marked diaphoresis. The ECG initially shows ST-segment elevation, and usually develops Q waves later on. There is an elevation of cardiac biomarkers. 

Option C: Left heart failure, which arises due to pulmonary edema, presents with shortness of breath. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and N-terminal pro-BNP are biomarkers that are usually elevated. There are no specific ECG changes. Any abnormality can rather point to the underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: During the routine ward rounds, a neonatologist demonstrates a reflex as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the elicited reflex?

choices.text: The onset is at 37 weeks of gestation
It disappears one month after birth
It disappears by 3-6 months of birth

questions.solution:
The reflex elicited is the Moro reflex. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth. 

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backward onto the examiner's hand. As a response to this, there is initial extension and abduction of fingers and upper extremities. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth.

An asymmetric reflex can point to a fractured clavicle, brachial plexus injury, or hemiparesis. Absent Moro reflex is suggestive of central nervous system dysfunction as seen in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and kernicterus.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

2-3 months postnatal

5-6 months postnatal

35 weeks of gestation

3-4 months postnatal

Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient, who is on chronic antiarrhythmic drug therapy, presents with hypotension, photosensitivity, and cold intolerance. He also complains of difficulty in getting up from the squatting position. Pulmonary function tests revealed a restrictive pattern of lung disease.  What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug implicated in this scenario is amiodarone. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

Amiodarone is used to convert atrial fibrillation and to slow ventricular rate in the treatment of tachyarrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardias, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and recurrent VF. It is also used in the treatment of cardiac arrest if epinephrine therapy is not effective.

The clinical spectrum of hypotension; photosensitivity; cold intolerance, which is indicative of hypothyroidism; difficulty in getting up from the squatting position indicative of proximal muscle weakness; and restrictive pattern on PFT, which is indicative of pulmonary fibrosis are all side effects of amiodarone.

The other significant side effects of amiodarone include the following:

  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Optic neuritis
  • Abnormal liver function tests
  • Peripheral neuropathy

The below image shows skin pigmentation in a patient due to prolonged amiodarone therapy.

Other options:

Option A - The side effects of adenosine are short-lived due to rapid transport into the cell and deamination. The side effects seen are transient asystole, transient dyspnea, and rarely transient atrial fibrillation.

Option B - The side effects of digoxin are common and include GI symptoms, visual and cognitive dysfunction, and arrhythmias, typically atrial tachycardia with AV block. Other arrhythmias that can occur are ventricular bigeminy, bidirectional ventricular tachycardia—a rare entity—and AV junctional tachycardias.

Option C - The side effects of quinidine are diarrhea, diarrhea-induced hypokalemia, marked QT prolongation, and a high risk of torsades de pointes at therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations. Cinchonism is a syndrome associated with quinidine intake, which includes symptoms of headache and tinnitus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of excruciating paroxysmal pain on the right side of her lips, gums, and cheek. The episodes last for 2-3 min and have been present for the past 2 months.  Which of the following is incorrect regarding the primary drug used in the treatment of this condition?

choices.text: It is a GABAc receptor modulator
It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.solution:
The symptoms of excruciating and paroxysmal facial pain are suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is used as the primary drug in this condition. The incorrect statement about carbamazepine is that it is a GABAc receptor modulator. 

Carbamazepine acts by slowing the recovery rate of voltage-activated sodium channels from their inactivated state and acts as a sodium channel blocker. 

It is used as the primary drug in both trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias. It is also the primary agent for treating generalized tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It can also be used in bipolar affective disorders.

Carbamazepine also has a potentiating effect on the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease. Other adverse effects include:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions such as:
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Skin rashes
    • Transient leukopenia
    • Aplastic anemia 
    • Agranulocytosis
    • Hepatotoxicity (on concomitant use with valproate)
  • Dose-related neurotoxicity such as:
    • vertigo
    • ataxia
    • diplopia and blurred vision
    • worsening of seizures
    • vomiting

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has frequent episodes of facial edema around his lips. It usually occurs after an emotional stressor. He also has a family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is the main mediator of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioedema. The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin.

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases the vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, its deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Features of the condition include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stressor. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

Option D: histamine is implicated as a mediator of angioedema in anaphylaxis. However, the main mediator in Heriditory Angioedema is bradykinnin and therefore the correct answer.

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text:
A 15-year-old patient, who has chronic asthma with mild severity and occasional exacerbations, is on regular use of MDI-containing steroids. Which of the following steroid is likely being used?

MDI - Metered dose inhaler
questions.solution:
Metered dose inhaler contains an inhaled type of steroid. Therefore, budesonide is the likely steroid being used. 

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are glucocorticoids that have high topical and low systemic action. The commonly used ICS are:

  • Beclomethasone dipropionate
  • Budesonide
  • Fluticasone
  • Ciclesonide

They act by suppressing bronchial inflammation, increasing PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) thereby reducing the use of inhalational beta2-agonist. They prevent acute attacks of asthma but are not effective during acute asthma or in status asthmaticus. 

Regular low-dose ICS can be started as part of Step-2 management of asthma and continued along with other add-ons according to the type of asthma. In seasonal asthma, regular low-dose ICS is given 3-4 weeks before an anticipated attack. ICS is indicated in patients with persistent asthma requiring a daily dose of beta 2 agonists and those who taper oral steroids require additional inhalational steroids to prevent withdrawal symptoms. High-dose ICS is useful in severe COPD with exacerbations.

ICS is given through MDI, nebulizer, or dry powder inhaler forms. Hoarseness of voice, sore throat, dysphonia, and oropharyngeal candidiasis are a few of the side effects which can be prevented by the use of a spacer to reduce the drug deposition from the mucosa.

Other options:

Option A: Hydrocortisone is a potent systemic glucocorticoid that is used to treat status asthmaticus. 

Option B: Dexamethasone is a systemic steroid that is used in inflammatory and allergic conditions. 

Option D: Methylprednisolone is a systemic steroid that is primarily used in immunosuppression therapy such as post renal transplant and nonresponsive active rheumatoid arthritis. 

 

 

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presented with mild irritation in her left eye. The ocular examination revealed a necrotic scleral plaque as shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a necrotising scleritis without inflammation
It is associated with connective tissue diseases.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. Spontaneous perforation occurs rarely in this condition as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation, characterized by progressive scleral thinning. It is typically seen in elderly women with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with mild irritation of the eyes. It is a painless condition and has no visual defects. On examination, necrotic scleral plaques may be seen near the limbus, which may coalesce and enlarge. 

It is also associated with other systemic diseases, especially connective tissue diseases. The associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants. In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

 

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A woman presents to you with complaints of feeling dizzy while getting up from the sitting position. Which of the following is not a criterion to diagnose orthostatic hypotension?

choices.text: The drop in BP occurs after 3 minutes of standing

questions.solution:
Compensatory tachycardia is not a criterion to diagnose orthostatic hypotension (OH).

Orthostatic hypotension (postural hypotension) is defined by a fall in systolic pressure ≥20 mmHg or in diastolic pressure ≥10 mmHg seen after 3 minutes of standing.

When OH occurs because of autonomic dysfunction, it is known as neurogenic OH. Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include cardiac pump failure, hypovolemia, metabolic abnormalities, and medications like alpha-blockers, diuretics, etc.

In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/minute. This may not occur in neurogenic OH. 

Other symptoms of OH include light-headedness, blurred vision, pallor, diaphoresis, and palpitations.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a high fever and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. Which is the organism most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest the diagnosis of Lemierre’s disease. Fusobacterium necrophorum is most likely to be involved in this condition.

Fusobacterium necrophorum is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus that is very pleomorphic. It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections that can progress to a complicated and life-threatening condition called Lemierre’s disease. It is most commonly caused by Fusobacterium necrophorum. However, species of Bacteroides, Eikenella, Streptococcus, and Peptostreptococcus may also be implicated.

Lemierre’s disease often occurs after infectious mononucleosis in older children and young adults. It is characterized by internal jugular vein septic thrombophlebitis. This progresses to abscesses of the lungs, mediastinum, pleural space, and liver with sepsis. It presents with pharyngitis that is not resolving, associated with rigors, neck pain, and swelling.

questions.text:
A male patient with a history of hepatitis B infection for a year presents with worsening confusion for 2 days and yellowing of the eyes for the past 5 days. Examination reveals flapping tremors and ascites. The lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?

Prothrombin time: 30 sec

HBsAg: Positive

HDV RNA: Positive

Serum bilirubin: 10 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ascites, encephalopathy, jaundice and prolonged prothrombin time (PT) in the setting of superinfection with hepatitis D virus is suggestive of fulminant hepatic failure. A liver transplant is the best step in the management of this patient.

Fulminant hepatitis /massive hepatic necrosis is a rare complication of viral hepatitis. It is seen primarily in hepatitis B, D, and E. Hepatitis B accounts for more than half of fulminant cases of viral hepatitis and can be associated with HDV infection and underlying chronic hepatitis C. Hepatitis E causes fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women.

This patient's history with clinical signs of confusion along with jaundice and ascites suggests hepatic failure with encephalopathy. The liver is usually shrunken. Cerebral edema is commonly seen. Brainstem compression, gastrointestinal bleeding, sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse, and renal failure are complications that can be fatal. 

The mortality rate is extremely high but patients who survive may have a complete recovery. Liver transplantation is lifesaving in affected patients.

Other Options:

Option A: N-acetylcysteine therapy is indicated in acetaminophen overdose. 

Option B: Glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis. 

Option C: Parenteral administration of vitamin K will not correct prolonged prothrombin time in cases of severe hepatocellular injury,

Most common cause of acute liver failure in India  Viral hepatitis (B and E)
Most common cause of viral fulminant hepatitis  HepE
Highest risk of progresion from acute viral hepatitis to fulminant hepatitis HepD

hepatitis (prevalence)		  HepC (150 million)

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented with a deformity of the left arm as shown in the below image. It is due to the rupture of the tendon of:

choices.text: Long head of the biceps brachii muscle
Short head of the biceps brachii muscle

questions.solution:
The given image shows Popeye's sign. It occurs due to the rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii muscle.

Popeye sign appears due to the bulging of the muscle belly caused by contraction of the unrestrained muscles on flexing the elbow. The sign is named due to the resemblance of the deformity with the famous cartoon character 'Popeye'.

Biceps brachii is one of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. It has two heads - a long head and the short head. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula whereas the short head originates from the apex of the coracoid process. Both heads get inserted into the radial tuberosity. 

The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6). It causes powerful flexion of the forearm at the elbow joint and supination of the forearm. It also is an accessory flexor of the arm at the glenohumeral joint. 

The rupture of muscles and tendons of the upper limb is usually uncommon, however, the long head of biceps brachii is the most commonly ruptured tendon. The distal biceps tendon may also rupture and it is important to determine its exact site, as it will determine the surgical approach for repair. 

The brachialis is also a muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm. It originates from the anterior aspect of the humerus and inserts into the ulnar tuberosity. It is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6) and radial nerve (C7). It is a strong flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman works at a garment factory. She has two children and is now pregnant. According to the Maternity Act of 2017, she can avail a paid maternity leave for:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the woman has 2 surviving children and is pregnant with the 3rd child. So according to the Maternity Act of 2017, she can avail of a paid maternity leave of 12 weeks. 

The Maternity Benefits Act of 1961 was formulated for the welfare of the women employed in factories, shops or commercial establishments in which 10 or more employees are working. It was amended in the year 2017 by which the maternity leave was extended from 12 to 26 weeks for the first two children. It also mentioned the provisions of crèche and work-from-home options under certain circumstances.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A man suffered from a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. Gram stain was done and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gas gangrene. The most likely causative organism is Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is a consequence of missile wounds and crush injuries. It is commonly caused by Clostridium perfringens, a spore-forming, gram-positive saprophyte. C. bifermentans, C. septicum, and C. sporogenes are the other organisms causing this condition.

Following crush injuries, the spores gain access to the body. These spores germinate under anaerobic conditions and start producing toxins. The alpha toxin (lecithinase) produced by C. perfringens, destroys red and white blood cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and muscle cells. The kappa toxin destroys connective tissue and blood vessels.

Patients present with severe pain, swelling of the limb, serosanguinous discharge, bluish-black discoloration, soft tissue crepitus, and hemorrhagic bullae. Other signs such as pyrexia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status may be seen. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. A peripheral blood smear can show hemolysis. Gram stain reveals gram-positive bacilli. Radiography is used to visualize gas in soft tissue.

Robertson-cooked meat media is used for the culture of anaerobic organisms like Clostridia. It consists of fat-free minced meat in broth. The organisms may be saccharolytic or proteolytic. The saccharolytic species turns the meat pink, while the proteolytic species turn it black.

Management is by admission to the intensive care unit and administering high-dose penicillin G and clindamycin with intravenous third-generation cephalosporins. Surgical excision to remove the debrided tissue should be done.

The below image shows bluish-black discoloration and hemorrhagic bullae due to gas gangrene.

Related Pearl: Oxygen Requirements of Bacteria

Type of organism

Cannot ferment or respire anaerobically.

Bacillus sp

Legionella sp

Bordetella sp

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Can't grow in the presence of oxygen as most of them don’t have Superoxide dismutase and Catalase.

Many organisms including Enteric gram-negative bacteria, S. aureus, Vibrio cholerae

Are indifferent to Oxygen. They are basically anaerobic organisms but can tolerate oxygen.

Peptococcus anaerobius

Lactobacillus sp.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a long history of heavy smoking presents with complaints of shortness of breath and chronic coughing. He is diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and started on regular use of ipratropium bromide. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ipratropium bromide acts as a muscarinic receptor antagonist.

It is a semisynthetic derivative of atropine and acts selectively on bronchial muscles to produce bronchodilation. It is used extensively for acute exacerbations of COPD and rhinorrhea.

Ipratropium blocks all subtypes of muscarinic receptors thereby antagonizing the inhibition of ACh release. It is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist that is administered in a powdered or nebulized form via metered dose inhaler around 3-4 times a day.

Nebulized ipratropium bromide may increase the risk of glaucoma in elderly patients and thus cautiously used to avoid exposure of the drug to the eye. Paradoxical bronchoconstriction may occur with ipratropium bromide when given along with hypotonic nebulizer solution and antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

Other options:

Option A: Muscarinic receptor agonists such as pilocarpine directly act on the muscarinic receptor to produce actions similar to acetylcholine. 

Muscarinic receptors are those that are selectively stimulated by muscarine and blocked by atropine. They are mainly of three subtypes: M1 (increasing intestinal secretions), M2 (mediates vagal bradycardia), and M3 (constriction of visceral and bronchial smooth muscles, vasodilatation in vascular endothelium causing penile erection).

Option B: Ganglionic stimulants can be divided into selective nicotinic agonists (nicotine and varenicline) and nonselective/ muscarinic agonists (acetylcholine and pilocarpine).

Option C: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as physostigmine, neostigmine, and galantamine inhibit cholinesterase enzyme (protects acetylcholine) and produce cholinergic symptoms.

Related Pearl: Ipratropium vs Tiotropium

 

Ipratropium

Tiotropium

Duration of action

Short

Long

Frequency of administration

3-4 times/day

Once daily

Antimuscarinic action

Non-selective

Relatively selective for M1 and M3 receptors

Paradoxical broncho

constriction

Present *

Absent

*Attributed to the nebulizer solution and other additives added. Blockade of prejunctional M2 receptors that normally inhibit acetylcholine release also can contribute.

Related Pearl: Acetyl Choline Receptors

Type

Location

Nicotinic (ionotropic) receptors

NM

Neuromuscular junction

NN

Autonomic ganglia

Muscarinic (metabotropic) receptors

M1, M4, M5

CNS

questions.text: A middle-aged woman develops hoarseness following a total thyroidectomy. On laryngoscopic examination, the left vocal cord is found to be in the cadaveric position. What is the best management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of unilateral complete vocal cord paralysis. The treatment of choice in this condition is speech therapy, if no improvement then medialization of the vocal cord is done.

Unilateral vocal cord paralysis is commonly seen following thyroid surgery (both recurrent and external laryngeal nerves of one side are affected). It results due to paralysis of all the muscles of the larynx on one side, except the inter arytenoid, which receives innervation from the opposite side.

The vocal cord will assume the cadaveric position, i.e., 3.5 mm from the midline. The healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord, thus causing glottic incompetence, resulting in hoarseness of voice and aspiration of liquids through the glottis.

Treatment includes speech therapy and medialization of vocal cords by injection of Teflon paste lateral to the paralyzed cord (type I thyroplasty).

Thyroplasty is a surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki's classification of thyroplasty includes:

  • Type I: It is the medialization of the vocal cord. This is done in unilateral vocal cord palsy. (option B)
  • Type II: It is lateralization of the vocal cord and is used to improve the airway. This is done in bilateral abductor palsy. (option A)
  • Type III: It is used to shorten or relax the vocal cord. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from female to male.
  • Type IV: It is used to lengthen or tighten the vocal cord and elevate the pitch. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from male to female.

Other options:

Options A and C: Tracheostomy and lateralization of the vocal cord (type 2 thyroplasty) are done in case of bilateral abductor paralysis. Patients usually present with dyspnea and stridor. Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position compromising the airway.

Option D: Epiglottopexy is the procedure done for bilateral vocal cord paralysis. Patients present with cough and choking fits due to inhalation of food and pharyngeal secretions.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the hospital with the following complaints as shown in the image below. She noticed that these nail changes started appearing 2 months ago. There is no significant occupation history. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of nail psoriasis.

Nail dystrophy may be associated with all types of psoriasis. They may occasionally be seen as an isolated feature. Nail pitting is the most frequent sign. Nail pitting is formed due to the involvement of the nail matrix.

The subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. It is a highly specific sign seen in psoriasis and involves the nail bed.

Other options:

Option A: Onychomycosis or Tinea unguium is defined as the infection of the nail plate by dermatophytes. A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail may get separated from its bed. It is shown below.

Option B: Mee’s lines are seen in nails in arsenic poisoning. Mees lines (transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands on the nail. They reflect systemic disorders like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. 

Option D: Lichen planus is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes, following a chronic course with relapses and periods of remission. Nail involvement is in the form of an exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

 Associated systemic condition

Clubbing
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Koilonychia

Iron-deficiency anemia, hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s disease

Onycholysis

Psoriasis, onychomycosis, hyperthyroidism, sarcoidosis, trauma, amyloidosis

Pitting

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

Beau’s lines

Any severe systemic illness that disrupts nail growth, Raynaud’s disease, pemphigus, trauma

Yellow nail

Lymphedema, pleural effusion, immunodeficiency, bronchiectasis, sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, nephrotic syndrome, thyroiditis, tuberculosis, Raynaud’s disease

Nail Pterygium

Dorsal: Lichen Planus

Ventral: trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus

 

Nail finding

Associated systemic condition

Terry’s (white) nails

Hepatic failure, cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, CHF, hyperthyroidism, malnutrition

Azure lunula

Hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson’s disease), silver poisoning, quinacrine therapy

Half-and-half nails

Specific for renal failure

Muehrcke’s lines

Specific for hypoalbuminemia

Mees’ lines

Arsenic poisoning, Hodgkin’s disease, CHF, leprosy, malaria, chemotherapy, carbon monoxide poisoning, other systemic insults

Dark longitudinal streaks

Melanoma, benign nevus, chemical staining, normal variant in darkly pigmented people

Splinter hemorrhage

Subacute bacterial endocarditis, SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, antiphospholipid syndrome, peptic ulcer disease, malignancies, oral contraceptive use, pregnancy, psoriasis, trauma

Telangiectasia

Rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, dermatomyositis, scleroderma

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain radiating to the back. Investigations revealed elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. An abdominal X-ray showed the colon-cut off sign.  Which of the following criteria uses CT to stage the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the abdominal radiograph showing the colon cut-off sign are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar Scoring is used for staging the severity of acute pancreatitis based on CT findings.

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks), and Cullen’s sign (bluish discoloration around the umbilicus) can be present.

The Grey Turner sign is shown below:

Cullen's sign is shown below:

The below abdominal x-ray shows an abrupt transition from distended to collapsed colon just beyond the splenic flexure. This is known as a colon cut-off sign.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Other options-

Option A: Modified Glasgow score uses 8 laboratory findings to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis (within 48 hours of treatment onset). It is not a CT-based scoring system.

Option C: APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation score) is another clinical tool that assesses the risk of mortality and predicts prolonged intensive care treatment. It is also not CT-based.

Option D: Ranson's criteria uses 11 clinical and laboratory findings at admission and after 48 hours to assess clinical severity. It does not include CT scan findings.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

Balthazar Score
Balthazar Grade Appearance on CT CT Grade Points
Grade A Normal CT 0 Points
Grade B Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 1 Point
Grade C Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation  2 Points
Grade D  Fluid collection in a single location 3 Points
Grade E Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas 4 Points

 

Necrosis Score  
Necrosis Percentage CT grade points
No necrosis 0 points
0 to 30% necrosis 2 points
30 to 50% necrosis 4 points
Over 50% necrosis 6 points

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

 

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

 

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A middle-aged man was rushed to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. There was a severe injury in his left lower limb which got stuck between the vehicle and the road. The patient was treated conservatively but later developed oliguria, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is not used in the management of his present condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of a lower limb stuck in between the vehicle and the road with the patient developing oliguria, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia is suggestive of crush syndrome. The alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate is done to prevent the precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites are released resulting in reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escape into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. It is usually associated with compartment syndrome.

Management of crush syndrome involves aggressive volume loading of patients, management of the open wound, and excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis. Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules. Renal hemofiltration is recommended if there is oliguria or renal failure. If compartment syndrome is confirmed (by measuring intra-compartmental pressure), then fasciotomy is performed. Fasciotomy should be avoided if entrapment is >12 hours as it can cause a massive release of myoglobin and spread the infection to dead tissues.

The image below shows compartment syndrome in the right upper limb managed by fasciotomy. 

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following retractors is best suited for retracting the skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision?
questions.solution:
A double hook retractor (Image 3)  is best suited for retracting the skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision.

Uses of a double hook retractor (shown below):

  • To retract skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision. 
  • Skin retraction during venesection. 
  • Skin and thyroid isthmus retraction during tracheostomy.


Image 1: Travers retractor (shown below) is a self-retaining retractor. It is used to retract the skin and subcutaneous tissues during intermediate-type operations, such as 

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy

Incorrect usage can traumatize the skin - the retractor has to be repositioned as the incision is deepened.


Image 2: Czerny's retractor (shown below) is a double-ended retractor with two prongs on one end and a blade with a lip on the other. It is used during laparotomy for superficial skin retraction.


Image 4: Mollison’s mastoid retractor (shown below) is self-retaining and hemostatic. It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:
