questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with a port-wine nevus on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. On radiological examination, the given appearance of the skull is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image of the skull showing tram track sign (gyriform calcification in a curvilinear pattern), along with the history of port-wine nevus and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas point to a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome is characterized by a port-wine nevus (along the course of the trigeminal nerve) on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. It is a congenital syndrome.

There is an increased risk of seizures and intracranial calcifications in the child before 2 years of age. There may be associated hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay. The ocular findings commonly associated are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, visual field defects, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Images show port-wine stain associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.


Features of MRI brain include

  • Pial angioma is seen as a diffuse pial enhancement of variable thickness.
  • Enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilatation of transparenchymal veins that communicate between the superficial and deep cerebral venous systems 

MRI and CT show intracranial calcification respectively. The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cerebral cortex.


Other options:

Option A: Moya-moya disease is characterized by dilatation of collateral vessels resulting from stenosis of the internal carotid artery appearing as puff of smoke pattern on angiography.

Option C: Von Hippel Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant multiorgan disorder characterized by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas with an increased risk of developing renal cell carcinomas.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis is a multi-system neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomyolipomas, cysts in kidneys, multiple hamartomas, giant cell astrocytomas, and cortical tubers.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: You are assessing the drinking water quality in your locality. According to WHO, the safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is:
questions.solution:
The safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is alpha activity 0.5 Bq/L and beta activity 1Bq/L.

Radioactivity is the number of nuclear disintegration per unit of time. Its unit of measurement is the becquerel (Bq). 1 Bq = 1 disintegration per second.

These guideline values include both naturally occurring and man-made radioactivity. When it is below the guideline values, the drinking water is considered safe and it does not need any radiological examination.

The variables that are assessed in the drinking water are physical parameters, chemical parameters, biological parameters and radiological parameters. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken for a pond in a village. Which of the following synthetic insecticides are not recommended for such measures?
questions.solution:
DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is not recommended for anti-larval measures. It is mainly used as a residual spray for the control of adult mosquitoes.

Compounds such as DDT and HCH (lindane) are organochlorine compounds. These are not recommended for larvicidal operations for the following reasons: 

  • Long residual effect 
  • Risk of water contamination
  • Risk of developing resistance in the vector mosquitoes

The most effective larvicides are malathion, fenthion, chlorpyrifos, and abate which can quickly hydrolyze in water. Malathion can be used as a low-volume spray to prevent mosquito-borne epidemics, vector-borne diseases during floods and dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A middle-aged, previously normotensive, male patient is brought with sudden onset blurring of vision. On examination, BP is 220/110 mmHg and fundoscopy shows papilledema. He was administered an intravenous anti-hypertensive. The analog of which of the following drugs would have been given in the intravenous form?
questions.solution:
Papilledema and an abrupt increase in BP of a previously normotensive patient are suggestive of malignant hypertension and the analogue of enalapril would have been given in the I/V form for treatment.

Enalapril is an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor). It is a prodrug that gets hydrolyzed in the liver to form the active agent, enalaprilat.

Enalaprilat is more potent than enalapril, however, it is not absorbed in its oral form. So when oral therapy is not appropriate, such as in the case of a hypertensive emergency, enalaprilat, which is available as a parenteral preparation, is used. The dosage is 0.625–1.25 mg given intravenously over 5 min which may be repeated every 6- 8 hours (maximum 5 mg/dose). 

Hypertensive emergency is characterised by progressive retinopathy, worsening renal function with proteinuria, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and encephalopathy. Other parenteral drugs used to treat hypertensive emergencies include:

  • Labetalol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Nicardipine
  • Nitroprusside
  • Loop diuretics (Furosemide)
  • Hydralazine

Other options:

Unlike enalapril, all the other ACE inhibitors such as captopril, benazepril, and lisinopril do not have parenteral preparations. 

Option B: Captopril is itself potent and is taken orally.

Option C: Benazepril is a prodrug that is cleaved by hepatic enzymes into benazeprilat that is orally absorbed.

Option D: Lisinopril is itself active and is an analogue of enalaprilat taken orally. 

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Contraindications

Beta-blockers

 Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis 

D1 receptor agonist

Caution in glaucoma

Vasodilators

 

 

Nitroglycerin

Nitroprusside

 Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure 

Hydralazine

ACE inhibitors

Enalaprilat

 History of angioedema

Alpha-blocker

Phentolamine, Urapidil

Centrally acting sympatholytics

questions.text: A 23-year-old G2P1 with a previous history of Cesarean section for breech presentation presents to your clinic. Which of these factors would favor her having a successful vaginal delivery in this pregnancy?

choices.text: Low vertical incision in previous Cesarean
Induction of labor in present pregnancy

questions.solution:
Spontaneous onset of labor favors a successful vaginal birth after C-section (VBAC) among the given options in a 23-year-old G2P1 with a previous history of C-section for breech presentation.

Favorable factors for VBAC:

  • Spontaneous labor
  • Prior fetal malpresentation
  • Transverse incisions
  • Non-recurrent indication (breech,fetal distress)
  • Current preterm pregnancy
  • Teaching hospital
  • White race

Increased failure rates:

  • Single mother
  • Increased maternal age
  • Macrosomic fetus
  • Obesity
  • Breech
  • Multifetal pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • Gestational age> 40 weeks
  • Low-vertical incision
  • Labour induction
  • Multiple prior cesarean deliveries
  • Short inter-delivery interval 

Risk factors for VBAC:

Low risk  High risk
  • Transverse incision
  • Prior vaginal delivery
  • Sufficient personnel and equipment
  • Classical or T incision in prior cesarean
  • Prior Rupture
  • Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa
  • Inadequate facilities

questions.text: The given injury would have most likely occurred due to:
questions.solution:
The image above shows Lichtenberg figures. This type of injury would have most likely occurred due to a lightning strike.

Lichtenberg's figures also called arborescent or filigree burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings over the skin that resemble the branches of a tree. They usually appear within minutes to an hour of a lightning injury and are observed as having a fern-like pattern of erythema over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks. 

They occur due to staining of the tissues by hemoglobin released by lysed red blood cells along the path of the lightning strike. They can also appear due to the rupture of smaller blood vessels in several places giving rise to ecchymoses.

Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

questions.text: A pediatrician referred a newborn with the given deformity to the orthopedics department. Which of the following is the true order of correction according to Ponseti's method?
questions.solution:
The given image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) or clubfoot. The order of correction according to Ponseti's method is cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE).

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are:

  • Cavus - this deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint
  • Adduction - this deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint
  • Inversion - occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus - this deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints

Ponseti's method is a successful method of manipulation in CTEV. It should begin as early as the first 2 weeks after birth. Weekly manipulation of the foot is done with help of plaster casts. 

To begin with, the first metatarsal is elevated to correct the cavus. This creates a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot. Then, the forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals. This everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination. Finally, the equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. In most cases, a percutaneous Achilles' tenotomy is required later for complete correction of the equinus deformity.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Reversible and Irreversible Inhibitors

Reversible Inhibitors

Irreversible Inhibitors

Binds via non-covalent interaction

Binds via covalent interactions

No chemical change

Inhibitor binds to the substrate & prevent catalytic activity of enzymes

Can be reversed, as there is no bonding between the inhibitor & substrate

Irreversibility due to strong covalent bonding

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: In which of the following types of mechanical ventilation, fresh air is blown into the room by centrifugal fans to create a positive pressure?
questions.solution:
The type of mechanical ventilation in which the fresh air is blown into the room by centrifugal fans to create a positive pressure is plenum ventilation.  

Plenum also known as the propulsion system is used to provide air to the air conditioning buildings and factories. The air is supplied through ducts at desirable points. 

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical.

  • Natural ventilation includes wind, diffusion and inequality of temperature
  • Mechanical ventilation includes exhaust ventilation, plenum ventilation, balanced ventilation and air conditioning. 

Related Pearl: Types of Ventilation

Types of Ventilation

  • Natural ventilation:
    • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
    • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action
    • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings
    • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, like opposite to each other.
    • The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.
  • Mechanical Ventilation
    • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans which run on electricity and are placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
    • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
    • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
    • Air conditioning is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odors and toxic gases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatic heart disease is in her first trimester. She has complaints of chest pain and syncope. Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur in which of the following time period?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur during the immediate postpartum period.

Cardiac failure during pregnancy can occur mostly following delivery. It can also occur during labor and at around 30 weeks.

Advancing age, cardiac arrhythmias, history of previous heart failure, and other pregnancy risk factors such as anemia, infection, hypertension, and multiple pregnancies can cause cardiac failure. 

Features include breathlessness, syncope, chest pain, and nocturnal cough. Chest murmurs, cardiac enlargement, and arrhythmia may be present. Chest radiography reveals an enlarged heart, increased pulmonary markings, and enlargement of pulmonary veins.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors are [Mnemonic: NOPE]

N-NYHA class >2

O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 OR Aortic valve area <1.5 cm2,   peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg.

P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

E-Ejection fraction <40%

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is resuscitated and stabilized. Which of the following is the preferred option to prevent rebleeding?

TIPSS- Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment option to prevent rebleeding is endoscopic band ligation.

In this method, a rubber band that can constrict is placed at the base of the varix. This immediately occludes the vessel and stops the bleeding. Rebleeding occurs very rarely with this method. 

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Other options

Option B - Endoscopic sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosant around the bleeding vessel. It is also effective in treating esophageal varices. However, the incidence of rebleeding is higher with this treatment.

Option C - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary, stabilizing measure.  It tamponades the bleeding varices. It is not a definitive treatment for variceal bleeding but is very effective to stop the bleed and stabilize the patient.

Option D - TIPSS or transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

Related Pearl: Common sites of porto-systemic anastomosis in portal hypertension

  • Left gastric vein [portal] to Distal oesophageal [systemic] veins: Presents with oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding
  • Tributaries of left branch of portal vein in ligamentum teres to Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins: Forms caput medusae
  • Tributaries of right branch of portal vein overlying ‘bare area’ of liver to Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: An elderly patient with type II diabetes presents with altered sensorium. He has not been eating or drinking well for the past few weeks. There are no complaints of nausea or abdominal pain. His blood sugar level is 800 mg/dL. All of the following are true regarding this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). In this condition, the anion gap is normal or slightly elevated, hence, option c- high anion gap is seen is a false statement.

HHS arises due to a relative reduction in circulating insulin and decreased fluid intake. Low level of insulin leads to a hyperglycemic state by two main mechanisms- increased glucose production by the liver and decreased glucose uptake by the skeletal muscles. This hyperglycemia results in osmotic diuresis, leading to volume depletion which is further exacerbated due to inadequate fluid intake by the patient. Eventually, kidney function is affected, reducing the glucose excretion through urine. All these factors result in a hyperosmolar state. 

Commonly seen in the elderly, HHS is usually precipitated by stressful events such as myocardial infarction, stroke, recent surgery, or infection. Certain drugs like steroids, diuretics, and phenytoin have also been implicated.

Symptoms of HHS include weakness, polyuria, and decreased oral intake. Symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis like nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are not usually seen. Hyperosmolarity can ultimately lead to altered sensorium, seizures, and coma. 

Laboratory investigations will show:

  • Blood sugar value >600 mg/dL
  • Sodium >135 meq/L
  • Moderately elevated creatinine due to prerenal azotemia
  • Osmolality between 330-380 mOsm/mL
  • pH >7.3
  • Normal to slightly elevated anion gap

A small anion gap metabolic acidosis may be seen, due to elevated lactic acid levels. Contrary to diabetic ketoacidosis, ketosis is usually not seen. 

Management includes treating the precipitating factor, fluid replacement, potassium supplementation based on serum potassium levels, and intravenous insulin. Once the patient can tolerate oral feeds, he can be started on subcutaneous insulin.

Related Pearl: Comparative Features of Diabetic Ketoacidosis and Hyperglycemic Hyperosmolar State

HHS

Type 2 DM

Kussmaul respiration

Fruity odour of breath

Coma

Sodium

300–320

330–380

< 15 meq/ L

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with difficulty hearing and tinnitus. Pure tone audiometry shows the rollover phenomenon and an MRI reveals a picture as seen in the image below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the MRI image showing an ice-cream cone appearance is suggestive of acoustic neuroma. The treatment of choice is the surgical removal of the tumor.

Acoustic neuroma is also called vestibular schwannoma or neurilemmoma, or the eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2.

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Involvement of other cranial nerves results in the following symptoms:

  • Trigeminal nerve: reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of the face.
  • Facial nerve: hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall called Hitzelberger’s sign.
  • Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve: Dysphagia and hoarseness.

Diagnosis of acoustic neuroma involves the following workups:

  • Pure tone audiometry shows a high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Speech audiometry shows poor speech discrimination and roll-over phenomenon- reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit.
  • MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for diagnosis. It shows an ice cream cone appearance.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA): a delay of >0.2 ms in wave V between two ears is seen.

The treatment of choice is the surgical removal of the tumor. Stereotactic radiosurgery like X-knife or gamma knife surgery is used for people who refuse/ cannot tolerate surgery.

Other options:

Option B: Stereotactic radiosurgery is an alternative treatment for acoustic neuroma. It is used for people who refuse/ cannot tolerate surgery or in those with residual tumors. 

Option C: Intratympanic gentamicin is a form of chemical labyrinthectomy. It is used in the treatment of Meniere's disease.

Option D: Conservative management does not help to manage an acoustic neuroma.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing an abdominal incision uses the surgical blade that is shown in the figure. What is the size of this surgical blade?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is 22. It is often used for abdominal incisions.

The number 10 is used for skin incisions.

The number 11 is often used for drain insertion and arteriotomy. These blades have a sharp tip. 

The number 15 is often used for minor surgical procedures.

questions.text: A hypertensive male patient presents to you with complaints of tingling sensations over his legs. Investigations revealed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody screening, and fibrinoid necrosis on skin tissue biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is polyarteritis nodosa. 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries, especially renal and visceral arteries. Affected individuals usually present with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and weight loss. Other symptoms include arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, abdominal pain, and rashes. Involvement of the renal arteries can manifest as renal failure or hypertension. 

In chronic cases, a biopsy of affected sites such as skin lesions shows fibrinoid necrosis of the vessels under microscopy as shown below. Aneurysmal dilatations up to 1 centimeter of the involved arteries is characteristic.

 

Investigations will show raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and leukocytosis. Patients are generally managed with a combination of prednisone and cyclophosphamide. The prognosis in untreated cases is poor.

Other options:

Option B: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the respiratory tract along with glomerulonephritis. Symptoms include bloody nasal discharge, hemoptysis, cough, and hematuria. In advanced cases, renal failure can occur. Airway biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with necrosis. Laboratory findings include positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), raised ESR, and leukocytosis. 

The image below shows a lung biopsy observed under the microscope:

 

Option C: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), is marked by eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis. It is an ANCA-positive small vessel vasculitis and presents with asthmatic attacks, fever, and weight loss. ESR and CRP are usually elevated. Biopsy shows granulomas with eosinophilic infiltration of tissues as shown below:

 

Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (IgA vasculitis), is a type of small vessel vasculitis commonly seen in children. It is usually preceded by streptococcal pharyngitis. They present with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and hematuria. Mild leukocytosis and raised IgA levels might be seen. A skin biopsy will show immunoglobulin A (IgA) deposition under direct immunofluorescence as shown below:

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

(Large vessel vasculitis)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with episodes of intermittent right upper abdominal pain for the past few months. She underwent cholecystectomy a year back. Investigations showed elevated AST and ALT levels and imaging revealed a dilated common bile duct with prolonged biliary drainage time. What is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?

AST - Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT - Alanine aminotransferase
HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters is the gold standard for its diagnosis.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is characterized by abdominal pain, biliary or pancreatic duct dilatation due to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.

Clinical types include biliary and pancreatic SOD.

Biliary type presents with biliary pain, raised liver enzymes, and/or dilation of the bile duct and/or evidence of delayed emptying on biliary imaging. It should be excluded in patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome. Pancreatic SOD presents as recurrent episodes of unexplained acute pancreatitis.

CT and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can demonstrate dilatation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. MRCP with intravenous secretin injection demonstrates dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to increased sphincter pressures. Endoscopic ultrasound can also be used. HIDA scan will show delayed biliary transit.

The gold standard investigation is ERCP with manometry and is indicated in disabling pain, when noninvasive investigations fail to demonstrate structural abnormalities and when conservative therapy fails. Basal sphincter pressure higher than 40 mm Hg is suggestive of SOD.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. It involves the use of a side-viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It can be a therapeutic and diagnostic modality specifically for viewing the distal biliary tree. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.  

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a radical neck dissection for carcinoma of the buccal mucosa. During the procedure, he inadvertently injured the middle trunk of the brachial plexus. Which of the following nerve functions can be impaired?
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve function can be impaired due to an injury to the middle trunk of the brachial plexus.

The middle trunk is the continuation of the C7 root. Among the given nerves, the thoracodorsal nerve has the root values of C6, C7, and C8. 

The thoracodorsal nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension and medial rotation of the humerus.

Option A: Medial pectoral nerve is a branch of the medial cord. It has the root values of C8 and T1.

Options B and C: Nerve to subclavius and suprascapular nerve are branches from the upper trunk. They both have the root values of C5 and C6.

  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: Which of the following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The Darrow Yannet diagram shown in image 4 depicts adrenal insufficiency. In adrenal insufficiency, there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction.

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Adrenal insufficiency is characterized by aldosterone deficiency which leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid). This results in:

  • The osmolarity of extra-cellular fluid (ECF) decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into the intracellular fluid (ICF). As a result, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction.

The image given below shows Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions:

Diagram 1 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 2 - The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

Diagram 3 - SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of anti-diuretic hormone) is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Diagram 4 - Adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and hematemesis. He has been taking antacids for heartburn for the last three years. He was stabilized. Endoscopy revealed a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum near the pylorus. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be the source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding probably due to peptic ulcer disease. The vessel most likely to be the source of bleeding is the gastroduodenal artery.

Peptic ulcers include duodenal and gastric ulcers of which duodenal ulcers are more common. 

The common sites are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach especially incisura angularis respectively.

Risk factors include H.pylori infection, NSAID intake, and cigarette smoking.

Features of a duodenal ulcer include bleeding and perforation. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena. Perforation is common with anterior duodenal ulcers.

Gastric ulcer also tends to bleed and perforate. They are much larger than duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A child presents with symptoms of fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis following his return from a summer camp. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with pharyngoconjunctival fever. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness with fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery. It is usually caused by serotypes 3, 7 and 14. It occurs usually, as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:

Syndrome Principle serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
ARD in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Tissue culture, serodiagnosis, and polymerase chain reaction for detection of viral DNA may be used.

questions.text: A lady presents difficulty in swallowing food, progressive hoarseness of voice, and loss of taste sensation. On examination, there is a loss of taste sensation on the posterior part of her tongue, absent gag reflex, and difficulty in shrugging her shoulders. Her MRI scan reveals a dural meningioma at an opening located in the base of the skull. The opening most likely to be involved is:
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the MRI brain showing dural meningioma at the opening in the base of the skull suggests the opening most likely to be involved is 1 i.e. the jugular foramen. 

The jugular foramen is an opening situated between the temporal and the occipital bone. It is present just above and lateral to the foramen magnum. Structures passing through the jugular foramen are:

  • Inferior petrosal sinus passes in the anterior part of the foramen
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) cranial nerves pass through the middle of the foramen
  • Internal jugular vein passes through the posterior part of the foramen.

Other options: 

Option A: 3 - Foramen rotundum - The structure passing through this foramen is the maxillary division of cranial nerve V (V2). 

Option B: 2 - Foramen ovale - The structures passing through this foramen are: Mandibular division of CN V (V3), accessory meningeal artery, lesser petrosal nerve, and emissary veins. 

Option C: 4 - Foramen spinosum - The structures passing through this foramen are: Middle meningeal artery, nervus spinosus, and middle meningeal vein.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following findings are not consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding with low serum protein and albumin is suggestive of kwashiorkor, where simian facies is not seen. Simian facies is consistent with marasmus.

Kwashiorkor is a clinical syndrome seen in severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is associated with pitting edema and apathy and affects children aged 1-4 years.

Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly with fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The image given below shows flaky paint dermatosis seen in kwashiorkor.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

The management of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) is outlined in the image below.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 60-year-old grand multipara, you notice the entire uterus lying outside the introitus. What degree of uterine descent will you assign to the clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The entire uterus is lying outside the introitus in fourth-degree uterine prolapse or procidentia.

Prolapse is a condition commonly seen in elderly menopausal women. It occurs due to the atonicity of the pelvic floor muscles and the ligaments that support the female genital tract. 

The degrees of prolapse are as follows:

  • The descent of the cervix into the vagina is first-degree prolapse.
  • When the cervix descends to the level of the vulva, it is second-degree prolapse. 
  • In third-degree prolapse, there is a protrusion of the cervix outside the vaginal orifice. 
  • Procidentia or fourth-degree prolapse is one in which the whole of the uterus protrudes outside the vulva. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina.

questions.text: A 25-year-old badminton player presents with complaints of pain in the right arm for a few weeks. On physical examination, the right arm is pale and cool to the touch. A radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray showing elongation of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra are suggestive of a cervical rib. The symptoms of pain and pallor of the arm are due to neural and vascular compression respectively.

The cervical rib is the extension of the anterior part of the transverse process of the C7 vertebrae which narrows the scalene triangle leading to compression of the subclavian artery, C8 and T1 nerve roots. 


Clinical features:

Most of the cases are asymptomatic. Vascular manifestations include upper limb claudication especially after usage, vasomotor changes (cyanosis, cold fingers and excessive sweating), Raynaud's phenomenon, wasting of the thenar, hypothenar, and forearm muscles, and ischemic ulcers or gangrene of digits. 

Neurological features include pain and weakness in the medial aspect of the arm, forearm, and hand. There may be a hard, fixed bony mass in the supraclavicular region. A palpable thrill and a bruit may be present in the subclavian artery. Positive Roos and elevated arm stress test are characteristic of thoracic outlet syndrome.

A radiograph of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib. However, the absence of a rib on the x-ray does not rule out the possibility of a cervical rib. CT and MRI are more sensitive.

Other options: 

Option A: Herniation of the cervical disc occurs due to degenerative changes with advancing age. MRI may show the protrusion of the disc and associated compression of the nearby nerves. An X-ray may be usually normal.

Option B: Spondylolisthesis refers to the forward translation of one segment of the spine upon the other most commonly occurring between L4 and L5, or between L5 and the sacrum. Oblique view X-rays may show the characteristic ‘Scotty dog neck’ appearance suggestive of a pars fracture with a broken neck or collar. Lateral views show the forward shift of the part of the spinal column above over the stable vertebra below. 

Option D: Cervical spondylosis refers to the degenerative changes in the adjacent vertebra and the intervening intervertebral disc more commonly affecting the C5 and C6 vertebra. X-ray shows a narrow intervertebral space with osteophyte formation.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: After the successful delivery of a baby, a grade 3b perineal tear is noticed. Which are the structures injured in this case?

choices.text: Perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, and <50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, external and internal anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, anal sphincter complex and anorectal mucosa

questions.solution:
The perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of the external anal sphincter are injured in Grade 3b perineal tears.

The lacerations of the perineum have been divided into four degrees:

  • First-degree: Injury to the skin of the perineum and/ or the vaginal mucosa.
  • Second-degree: Injury to the perineum and perineal muscles without the involvement of the anal sphincter.
  • Third-degree: Injury to the perineum and the anal sphincter complex. It is further classified as:
    • Grade 3a: Less than 50% of external anal sphincter (EAS) thickness torn.
    • Grade 3b: More than 50% of EAS thickness torn.
    • Grade 3c: Both EAS and internal anal sphincter (IAS) are torn.
  • Fourth-degree: Injury to the perineum, the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS), and the anorectal mucosa.

Obstetric anal sphincter injuries (OASIS) refer to both third- and fourth-degree perineal tears.

A central tear of the perineum - When the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text:
A homeless man is caught peeping into the women's public restroom and attaining sexual gratification. This act is punishable under which section of the BNS?

BNS - Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita

IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of voyeurism and is punishable under BNS Section 77 (IPC 354-C).

Voyeurism refers to an individual having an intense desire to observe unsuspecting people undress or naked, take a bath, see genitalia, or watch intercourse to attain sexual excitement or gratification. The individual is called a voyeur or a peeping tom.

The punishment for this offence is imprisonment for not less than 1 year which may extend to 3 years and a fine. If the voyeur repeats the offense, they can be punished with imprisonment of 3-7 years.

BNS Section 74 (IPC 354) deals with assault or use of force on a woman to insult her modesty. Such acts are punishable with imprisonment of 1-5 years and a fine.

The other related offenses are given below:

BNS Section IPC Section Offense 
75 354-A Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment. This involves physical contact, advances, demanding sexual favors, making sexual remarks, and showing the victim pornography
76 354-B Assaulting or forcing a woman to disrobe 
77 354-C Voyeurism
78 354-D Stalking or following a woman to force interaction or monitoring using the internet, email, or any electronic communication.

 

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: You are a junior researcher studying about the properties of apoproteins.  Which of the following is the basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48?
questions.solution:
The basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48 is RNA editing.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing. The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100. In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 48kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

DNA rearrangement, transposition and alternate splicing, do alter gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

B-100, E

questions.text: A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. On examination, an irregularly shaped ulcer with a whitish feathery appearance, and satellite lesions were seen in his right eye. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a fungal ulcer and the most appropriate treatment is amphotericin B drops.

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is commonly caused by Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks.

Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer. The clinical signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes
  • Dry slough with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium.
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as oral ketoconazole or voriconazole are considered if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or in suspected endophthalmitis
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

The image below shows a fungal corneal ulcer with a hypopyon.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake.

NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value multiplied by 100.

1 gram of protein is equivalent to 6.25 g of nitrogen. The NPU value of a dietary protein and the protein requirement of the individual are inversely related to each other. The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Other options:

Option A: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the ratio of milligrams of digestible dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the dietary protein to the milligrams of the same dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the reference protein. 

Option C: The biological value is calculated as the amount of nitrogen used for tissue formation divided by the nitrogen absorbed from food expressed in percentage. It is a reflection of essential amino acid supplied and a measure of protein quality. 

Option D: The amino acid score refers to the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein. It is calculated as the percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in both upper limbs. An MRI is done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing a hyperintense area in the spinal cord is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' as it affects the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity, weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Spinal epidural abscess presents with fever, pain, and progressive weakness. The pain may be radicular. There would be elevated white cell count and inflammatory markers. The image below shows a spinal epidural abscess compressing the spinal cord. 

 

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Patients present with paresthesias in the hands and feet and progressive ataxic weakness. They would be areflexic due to peripheral neuropathy. The image below shows a hyperintensity in the posterior part of the spinal cord due to the involvement of the posterior columns. 

 

Option D: Spinal cord infarction occurs due to infarction of one of the three arteries (anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries.) Infarction of the anterior spinal artery leads to quadriplegia or paraplegia, loss of pain and temperature, and sparing of vibration and position sense. Posterior spinal artery involvement leads to a loss of posterior column functions. 

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

Structure / Space  Terminal extent 
Spinal cord at birth  L3 upper border 
Spinal cord at 2 years  L1 lower border 
Adult Spinal cord  L1 lower border  
Filum terminale  1st coccygeal segment 
Filum terminale internum , Dural sac S2 lower border 
Filum terminale externum  1st coccygeal segment 
Piamater  1st coccygeal segment 
Subarachnoid sheath and space, Subdural space  S2 lower border 
Cervical enlargement  C3-T2 spinal segments 
Lumbar enlargement  L1-S3 spinal segments

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. Fundus examination revealed the findings as shown in the image below. The abdominal examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a fundus image showing a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease. 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides. GM2 ganglioside accumulates more commonly in neurons of the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina.

Tay-Sachs disease is common among people from the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Affected infants usually present with loss of motor skills, exaggerated startle response to noise (hyperacusis), seizures, and macrocephaly without hydrocephalus.

On examination of the fundus, a cherry-red spot appears in the macula in almost all patients. This is produced by the accentuation of the red color of the macular choroid, against the background of the rest of the retina appearing pale due to ganglion cells being swollen with GM2 ganglioside.

Histopathological examination reveals ballooned-out neuronal tissue with vacuoles representing lysosomes filled with gangliosides.

Note that cherry red spots are associated with multiple conditions, as discussed in the pearl below and should always be interpreted in the context of the clinical history. 

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP. Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Doxazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Alfuzosin - Specifically created for BHP, not used as an antihypertensive

Other uses of α1 receptor antagonists include the management of hypertension and short-term management of congestive heart failure.

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tumor suppressor gene?
questions.solution:
WT-1, RB, and P53 are all examples of tumor suppressor genes. RAS is a protein involved in signal transduction.

Tumor suppressor gene products inhibit cell proliferation. Abnormalities in these genes cause a failure to inhibit uncontrolled growth which leads to carcinogenesis. Some tumor suppressor genes and associated malignancies:

APC Inhibitor of WNT signaling Familial colonic polyps and carcinomas
NF1 Inhibitor of RAS/MAPK signaling Neurofibromatosis type 1
NF2 Cytoskeletal stability, Hippo pathway signaling Neurofibromatosis type 2 
PTEN Inhibitor of PI3K/AKT signaling Cowden syndrome
RB Inhibitor of G1/S transition during cell cycle progression Retinoblastoma
VHL Inhibitor of hypoxia-induced transcription factors Von Hippel Lindau syndrome
STK11 Suppression of cell growth when cell nutrient and energy levels are low Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
CDH1 Cell adhesion, inhibition of cell motility Gastric carcinoma
TP53 Cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage Li Fraumeni syndrome
BRCA1, BRCA2 Repair of double-stranded breaks in DNA Familial breast and ovarian carcinomas, carcinoma of male breast
MSH2, MLH1, MSH6 DNA mismatch repair Hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma
WT1 Transcription factor Wilm's tumor
MEN1 Transcription factor Multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 ( MEN1- pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic endocrine tumors)
