questions.text: Identify the structure based on the histological features of the specimen obtained after radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
questions.solution:
The given structure can be identified as a fallopian tube based on the histological features. 

The fallopian tube contains the following structures from the inside out: 

  • Mucous membrane consisting of: 
    • Numerous branching folds mostly fill the entire lumen of the tube. They lie on the basement membrane
    • Peg cells- contain secretory granules
    • Intercalary cells
  • Muscle coat- has two layers of smooth muscles. An inner circular and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle
  • Serosa- contains mesothelium that is supported by the connective tissue

Other options: 

Option A: The ovary consists of the following parts: 

  • Germinal epithelium- it covers the surface of the ovary and is lined by a single layer of cubical cells
  • Tunica albuginea- it is a connective tissue layer on which the germinal layer rests
  • Cortex- it contains a stroma made of reticular fibres and mesenchymal cells. Ovarian follicles at various stages of development are scattered in the stroma
  • Medulla- it contains connective tissue with blood vessels, elastic fibres, and smooth muscle. 

Option B: The cervix is a narrow tube-like structure extending between the uterine cavity and the vagina. Its mucosa consists of numerous obliquely placed palmate folds, glands, and cysts called ovula Nabothi. The mucous membrane of the upper 2/3rd of the canal is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium, over the lower 1/3rd it is lined by non-ciliated columnar epithelium and near the external os, it is lined by stratified squamous epithelium. 

Option D: The vagina consists of the following parts: 

  • Inner mucosa- is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium. The mucosa is rich in glycogen, and thus, the cells are palely stained.
  • Muscle coat- it is made of outer longitudinal and inner circular fibres
  • Adventitia- it is made of fibrous tissue with many elastic fibres.

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A female patient on medication for recurrent muscle pain presents with hematuria and flank pain. Investigations revealed a shrunken kidney with papillary necrosis and calcification. Which of the following drugs was she most likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the findings of papillary calcifications and necrosis is suggestive of analgesic nephropathy. The patient was most likely on phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine.

Analgesic nephropathy is a renal disease characterized by tubulointerstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. It occurs due to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics, especially phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine. Paracetamol is another drug that is implicated. It is more common in women and a history of chronic headaches, arthralgias, and abdominal pain which necessitated the chronic use is usually present. 

Flank pain with or without hematuria might indicate a ureteral obstruction due to the sloughed papilla secondary to necrosis. It increases the risk for urinary tract malignancies. 

NSAIDs are a group of drugs with analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties. The effects are exerted by blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins. The COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes are inhibited. These enzymes are the first steps in the production of prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins.

Other side effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) include agranulocytosis, cystitis, hematuria, thrombosis, and dyspepsia.  

Other options:

Options A and C: Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors (CNI), used as immunosuppressants that can cause CNI nephrotoxicity. Acute kidney injury can be due to thrombotic microangiopathy or toxic tubulopathy. Chronic CNI nephrotoxicity is seen commonly in transplant patients. It presents with a decline in glomerular filtration rate, hypertension, and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Lithium, commonly used in manic-depressive disorders can lead to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Rarely, it can cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.

questions.text: A young woman developed sudden onset congestive heart failure. Her condition rapidly deteriorated and she died after a few days. Autopsy of the heart showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes, some of which surrounded individual myocytes. What is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the autopsy showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes is suggestive of viral myocarditis.

Viral myocarditis is the most common cause of inflammation of the myocardium. The most common viral causes are coxsackieviruses A and B, echovirus, and influenza virus. Most patients recover from acute myocarditis, but a few may die from congestive heart failure or arrhythmias.

On gross examination, the heart appears normal or dilated. Sections of the heart show interstitial inflammatory infiltrate with focal myocyte necrosis. There is a predominant lymphocytic infiltration. 

Other options:

Option A-  Giant cell myocarditis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells (fused macrophages) interspersed with lymphocytes, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages.

Option B- Protozoal myocarditis occurs in Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), toxoplasmosis, etc. Histopathology will show the presence of parasites in the myofibers along with infiltrates of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages. 

Option C- Hypersensitivity myocarditis is caused due to hypersensitivity reactions to several drugs. The inflammatory infiltrate includes many eosinophils, and the infiltrate is principally perivascular.

questions.text: The gross appearance of a liver pictured while conducting an autopsy of a chronic alcoholic is as shown below. This finding is a result of the activation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Stellate cells :

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cell. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin. But in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with lesions over his elbow as shown in the given image. Similar lesions are noted over the dorsum of the penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an aggregate of pinhead-sized papules over the elbow of a child, which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

Lichen nitidus is a rare variant of lichen planus, where both are histologically similar in early lesions. It is mostly seen in children and young adults. Lesions of lichen nitidus are typically described as a minute pinpoint to pinhead-size, flat or dome-shaped papules with a shiny surface. They are most commonly found over the forearm, dorsum of the penis, abdomen, chest, and buttocks. They are usually asymptomatic, but can also present with severe pruritus. Koebner phenomenon, if present, is a hallmark of the disease. Nail pitting or rough nails with increased linear striations and longitudinal ridges may be present.

 

Lichen nitidus is found to be associated with Crohn's disease, Down's syndrome, congenital megacolon, and Niemann-Pick disease.

There are several histological characteristics of lichen nitidus. The distinguishing feature of lichen nitidus is a well-circumscribed granulomatous infiltration in the papillary dermis that is surrounded by extensions of epidermal ridges and composed of lymphocytes, macrophages, Langerhans giant cells, and multinucleated epithelioid histiocytes. Usually spanning 4 to 5 dermal papillae in the dermis, this clearly defined inflammatory infiltration has a "ball-in-clutch" appearance.

Other options:

Option A: Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by Sarcoptes scabiei. It presents as vesicles, burrows, and nodules in locations such as interdigital spaces, forearms, breasts, and genitalia.

Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a condition that typically affects children and adolescents who have a great immune sensitivity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is believed to be the outcome of the immune system's reaction to the hemorrhagic dissemination of a tuberculous focus that underlies it. The lesions often consist of small, asymptomatic follicular papules that range in color from skin tone to erythema. are typically over the abdomen, chest, back, or proximal limbs.

Option D: Miliaria rubra is caused due to eccrine sweat gland obstruction which results in leakage of sweat into the epidermis. Common lesions form on the body where the skin rubs against clothing and in the flexures. The lesions are essentially little erythematous papules. Lesions commonly develop on the obstructed skin of the neck, groins, and axillae in infants, though they can also occur elsewhere.

questions.text: A male patient came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft is suggestive of white piedra and the causative agent is Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types: white piedra and black piedra. 

White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii. It is characterized by the presence of soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is seen in the culture as nodules in the form of a sheath extending around the hair shaft. Arthroconidia and blastoconidia are seen.

Black piedra is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. It is caused by Piedraia hortae (option C). On microscopy, they appear as brown, thick-walled with septate hyphae and chlamydoconidia.

Shaving or cutting off the affected hair is useful in managing both black and white piedra. In black piedra, topical benzoic acid and terbinafine is helpful while topical antifungals, azoles, and allylamines can be useful in white piedra.

Other superficial mycoses and infectious organisms are Hortaea (Exophiala) werneckii (option B) causing tinea nigra. They cause lesions in the palm which appear dark brown to black in color. On Sabouraud agar, they appear as grey or black colonies. Skin scrapings reveal brownish branched septate hyphae and budding cells.

Tinea versicolor (Option D) or Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species like Malassezia globosa, Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic lesions are macules that are hypo or hyperpigmented on the chest, upper back, arms, or abdomen. Skin scrapings show yeast-like cells and short branching filaments.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in the latent phase of labor for 8 hours. The latent phase would be said to be prolonged in her if it lasts for more than ______.
questions.solution:
The latent phase is said to be prolonged in nulliparous women if it lasts for more than 20 hours.

Friedman defined the prolonged latent phase by:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase 

The first stage of labor consists of two phases :

1) Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).

2) Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of gonorrhea now presents with hesitancy, straining, and a poor stream of urine. Which of the following structures is most commonly affected in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-inflammatory urethral stricture. The structure marked 3 in the image is the bulbar urethra which is most commonly affected.

The infection in the periurethral glands persists after inadequately treated gonorrhea. The infection spreads to cause periurethritis, which heals by fibrosis. They are more common within 1 year of infection.

Causes of urethral stricture include:

  • Trauma (most common)                                    
    • Bulbar urethral injury
    • Pelvic fracture 
  • Infection
    • Secondary to urethritis
    • Secondary to balanitis
  • Iatrogenic
    • Secondary to urethral catheterization

Clinical features include hesitancy, poor stream, and straining. Other complaints like postmicturition dribbling, incomplete bladder emptying, and retention can also occur. 

Uroflowmetry, urethroscopy, urethrography, and ultrasound can be done.

Urinary tract infection is the most common complication of urethral stricture.

Management options include:

  • Urethral dilatation in elderly men with short strictures
  • Urethroplasty in case of trauma
  • Urethrotomy

The below image shows the parts of the urethra.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with painless swelling as shown below. On examination, the swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. Which of the following is false regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The swelling arises from remnants of 2nd branchial cleft
The cystic swelling is lined by squamous epithelium
FNAC from the swelling may show cholesterol crystals

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the branchial cyst. It lies superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric.

The branchial cyst arises from the remnants of the 2nd branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescents and early 3rd decade.

Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue. It may get infected to form an abscess.

FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent. It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD  with abrupt onset of fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood counts showed a decrease in platelets and RBCs. Bone marrow and peripheral blood smear showed cells as given below. Immunophenotyping revealed the presence of  CD79a+, CD19+, and CD20+. The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphoblasts are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are precursor B lymphoblasts.

ALL is more common in childhood with a peak incidence around 3-5 years of age. The child had symptoms related to bone marrow suppression including anemia, and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration. Hepatosplenomegaly points towards extra-medullary hematopoiesis.

Microscopy reveals lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scanty agranular cytoplasm along with B cell markers like CD79a, CD19, and CD20.

Other options:

Option B: Precursor erythroblasts are cells of myeloid lineage that will have myeloid markers like CD 33, and CD34. Though ALL and AML both have an abrupt onset of presentation and may be difficult to distinguish morphologically. Immunophenotype features will distinguish them. 

Option C: Germinal center B cells will give rise to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL(Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma), or Burkitt lymphoma with characteristic appearances. Moreover, these will have positive CD10 as a marker of the germinal center.

Option D: Thymic origin T-cells will show the presence of T-cell markers.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the given fracture.

choices.text: Non-union is the most common complication
Undisplaced fractures are managed with a sling

questions.solution:
The given image shows a clavicular fracture of the middle third of the clavicle. Non-union is a relatively rare complication in clavicle shaft fracture. 

One of the most frequently fractured bones in the body is the clavicle. Mostly it occurs due to a direct blow or a fall on an outstretched arm. The midshaft of the clavicle is most commonly fractured. The lateral fragment is pulled down by the weight of the arm and the medial half is pulled up by the sternomastoid muscle. 

The patient will be presented with the flexed elbow as the arm will be held to the chest to prevent movement. It is divided into three based on the location of the fractures:

  1. Group I – middle-third fractures
  2. Group II – lateral-third fractures
  3. Group III – medial-third fractures.

Treatment of clavicle fractures:

  • Undisplaced fractures are treated with a sling or figure of eight bandages for 2-3 weeks. This is followed by mobilization of the limb as the pain subsides.
  • Displaced fractures are treated with internal fixation either by contoured locking plates or intramedullary nails (shown below).

Malunion is the most common complication in clavicle fractures. Fractures occur mostly in the middle one-third of the clavicle shaft. 

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women >40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass (free from adnexa) and myometrial cysts on MRI, point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) reveals a salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Other options:

Option A: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the endometrial lining (uterus). They usually present as dysmenorrhea and lower dull abdominal pain. Vaginal examination reveals a tender fixed retroverted uterus. They can be managed medically (oral contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors, etc)  and surgically (if failed medical management). Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is performed in advanced cases.

Option C: Leiomyoma (fibroid) is the commonest benign tumor arising from the uterus. They present as abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, and abdominal pain. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged and the mass moves with the cervix. It can be managed medically (mifepristone or newer progesterone) and surgically. A myomectomy is performed for large fibroids with significant symptoms.

Option D: Endometrial hyperplasia can be simple, glandular, or atypical. They are seen in women with estrogen excess states like obesity, PCOD, or on tamoxifen therapy. They usually present as abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).

questions.text: A dead body was found in an abandoned state in a forest. The postmortem changes in the body are shown in the image below. These changes are indicative of:
questions.solution:
The image above shows marbling which is an external sign of putrefaction.

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. This chiefly occurs due to an increase in hydrogen ion concentration and a decrease in oxygen concentration in the tissues. A contributing factor would be the absence of the body's defensive mechanisms. 

The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase.

The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

The superficial veins of roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, and shoulders are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red, in a linear branching pattern. This is called marbling and is usually prominent 36-48 hours after death occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin formation subsequent to hemolysis of red blood cells.

Other options:

Option B: Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin. 

Option C: Filigree Burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

Option D: Postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ Suggilation refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of the room spinning when his head is in one particular position. His diagnosis was confirmed by performing the Hallpike maneuver. The physician performs another maneuver to relieve the patient's symptoms. Arrange the following in the proper sequence of the therapeutic maneuver.
  1. Affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
  2. Head turned 45° to the affected side and head in hanging position
  3. Head turned forward and chin brought down to 20°
  4. Whole body and head rotated to a lateral recumbent position
  5. Sitting position with head turned to unaffected side by 45°
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Epley's maneuver is performed, which follows the sequence b, a, d, e, c.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1 min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.

The findings seen in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver are due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle.

Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the posterior semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure, and there is a high rate of recurrence.

Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

 Step Maneuver
Position 1 Head turned 45°

Patient is to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2

The head is turned so that the affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
Position 3 Whole-body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a 90° rotation face-down position
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45°

Patient is brought to the sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20°

The illustration given below shows the different positions used in Epley's maneuver:

questions.text: A patient died due to encephalitis. A postmortem biopsy of the brain tissue is shown below. This finding is characteristic of infection caused by:
questions.solution:
The finding in the image shows Negri bodies, which is characteristic of the infection caused by the rabies virus.

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies virus infection. These are spherical-shaped cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. They contain eosinophilic matrix, basophilic granules, and viral antigens. 

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis can be done on a postmortem or antemortem basis. Postmortem diagnosis is done by the demonstration of Negri bodies. These bodies are common in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Antemortem diagnosis is done from corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Demonstration of the virus is done using direct immunofluorescence. 

Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of hearing loss. After examining the child, you order a test that reads low-intensity sounds produced by the cochlea using a sensitive microphone placed near the ear canal. This test will not help diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The test report given in the above clinical scenario is otoacoustic emissions (OAEs). This test cannot help differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.

OAEs are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It is an objective test of hearing. OAEs are of two types, spontaneous and evoked:

  • Spontaneous OAEs are present in healthy individuals where hearing loss does not exceed 30 dB.
  • Evoked OAEs are further divided into two types:
    • Transient evoked OAEs are evoked by clicks.
    • Distortion product OAEs are produced by two tones that are simultaneously presented to the cochlea to produce distortion products.

Uses of OAEs:

  • They can be used as screening tests for hearing in neonates.
  • To distinguish cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss (option B).
  • To diagnose retrocochlear pathology like auditory neuropathy and ototoxic sensorineural hearing loss (option C).
  • Meniere's disease can elicit a unique OAE presentation. OAEs are expected to be absent in patients of Meniere's disease having hearing loss thresholds exceeding 30 dB (option D).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with severe intellectual disability underwent a genetic analysis. He was found to have trinucleotide expansion mutations in the FMR-1 gene. Which of the following is not a morphological feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 16-year-old boy with severe intellectual disability and trinucleotide expansion mutations on the FMR-1 gene is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. Patients with Fragile X syndrome have macro-orchidism, not micro-orchidism. 

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked disorder and the second most common cause of intellectual disability in males after Down syndrome. It is caused by the inactivation of FMR-1 gene due to CGG base repeats on the long arm of the X chromosome.

The characteristic phenotypic features of Fragile X syndrome include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Large testicles (macro-orchidism) - observed in at least 90% of affected post-pubertal males.

In some cases, hyperextensible joints, a high-arched palate, and mitral valve prolapse may also be noted. Neuropsychiatric features include intellectual disability, aggressive behaviour, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

Note: Anticipation is the phenomenon seen in Fragile X syndrome where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family.

Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions:

  • GAA- Friedreich ataxia
  • CAG- Huntington's disease
  • CTG- Myotonic dystrophy

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a recent history of diarrhea. He has associated tenderness over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the management of the CT finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, a recent history of diarrhea, and an abdominal CT showing a moderate-sized abscess in the right liver lobe is suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. It is an extra-intestinal infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating this condition. 

Amebic liver abscess follows intestinal amebiasis. However, a history of diarrhea may not always be present as most patients remain asymptomatic carriers. In patients presenting with the above symptoms, stool examination, serological tests, and radiological imaging help to confirm the diagnosis. 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating invasive amebiasis like an amebic liver abscess. It is a nitroimidazole compound and is a highly active tissue amebicide. Tinidazole, which is another longer-acting imidazole, is also highly effective for the management of this condition. Other tissue amebicides include secnidazole, satranidazole and ornidazole.

Metronidazole is also effective against other anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It is used in the management of giardiasis, trichomoniasis, anaerobic bacterial infections (e.g., pelvic or abdominal abscesses following surgery), pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal manifestations like anorexia, nausea, and a metallic taste. It is known for its ability to produce a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol. Metronidazole can decrease the renal elimination of lithium and potentiate its toxicity. It may also cause significant bleeding in patients on warfarin therapy.

Other options:

Iodoquinol (Option B), paromomycin (Option C), and diloxanide furoate (Option D) are luminal amebicides. They are poorly absorbed and thus reach high concentrations in the bowel and are used in the management of intestinal amebiasis. They are also indicated for invasive amebiasis. However, their role is to eradicate cysts and prevent further transmission. They would not have any direct effect on the extraintestinal liver abscess as seen in this case.

Related Pearl: Difference between pyogenic and amebic liver abscess

Clinical features

Pyogenic abscess

Amebic abscess

>50 years

20–40 years

Male:Female ratio

1.5:1

10:1

Solitary 80%

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with seizures. MRI of the brain revealed cortical tubers. The image below depicts a type of skin lesion seen in this condition. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the image shows confetti skin lesions seen in this condition.

Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is a neurocutaneous syndrome with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. It is due to a mutation in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene, which encodes proteins hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

It presents during childhood with intellectual disability, skin lesions, and seizures. Infants can present with infantile spasms.

Various skin lesions seen in tuberous sclerosis include:

Confetti skin lesions - hypomelanotic macules that are 1-3 mm in diameter that usually appears symmetrically over the distal extremities. 

Facial angiofibromas - reddish nodules seen on the nose and cheeks. Eventually, they join together to form a fleshy growth. It is usually seen between the ages of four to six. It is shown in the image given below:

 

Periungual fibromas - They are small fibromas or skin nodules seen around finger or toenails in a few patients. The image below shows these lesions:

 

Shagreen patch - a rough, raised lesion with the consistency of an orange peel. It is usually seen in the lumbosacral region.  

 

Ash leaf macules - hypomelanotic macules that are ≥5 mm, seen on the trunk and extremities as shown in the image below:

 

There can be involvement of other organ systems as seen by cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis. Involvement of the central nervous system is a hallmark of tuberous sclerosis. These include cortical tuber, retinal lesions, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA).

Surgical resection of SEGA is done in patients with symptoms. Routine antiepileptic therapy can be implemented for seizures. Vigabatrin is used to manage infantile spasms.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes with complaints of pain in his great toe. The pain is recurrent, usually starts at night, and is triggered by alcohol consumption. On examination, the toe is warm, tender, and swollen. Which of the following drugs would not be beneficial for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gout flares and benzhexol, a central anticholinergic, would not be beneficial in this condition.  

Gout is a hyperuricemic condition that occurs among the middle-aged and elderly. It manifests as acute recurrent gout flares that often involve the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe (podagra). The pain begins at night and continues to early morning. Triggering factors include alcohol, diuretic use, trauma, purine-rich food, etc.   

Uricosuric drugs help in augmenting the excretion of uric acid. The various drugs used are: 

  • Probenecid inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by the enzyme URAT-1. This effect is decreased if it is coadministered with salicylates such as aspirin. 
  • Benzbromarone: It is a reversible inhibitor of the urate-anion exchanger in the proximal tubule.
  • Lesinurad: It inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting URAT-1 and OAT-4.
  • Sulfinpyrazone: It inhibits the organic anion transporter that is involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules.
  • Losartan is an angiotensin receptor antagonist that also has mild uricosuric action.

Other treatment goals include:

  • Symptomatic relief of an acute attack (glucocorticoids, NSAID)
  • Prevention of inflammatory responses to crystals (colchicine)
  • Inhibition of urate formation via xanthine oxidase inhibitors (allopurinol and febuxostat)
  • Uricase drugs that oxidize uric acid to more soluble allantoin (pegloticase and rasburicase)

Pegloticase is used in chronic gout or if it is refractory to other drugs.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: An older patient with bilateral hearing loss and occasional vertigo is being investigated. Biopsy from the region is given below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The given histology image shows dense pink Antoni A areas predominantly (bottom left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (top right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels seen in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 (Neurofibromatosis 2) gene on chromosome 22.

They appear as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading. They cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures.

Their cell of origin is the Schwann cell, thus they show immunoreactivity for the S-100 marker.

Treatment is done using surgical removal.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors, that often arise in the uterus and are the most common neoplasm in women. Histologically, they are composed of fascicles of densely eosinophilic spindle cells that tend to intersect each other at right angles. 

Option B: Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent primary tumors of the heart in children. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. But due to routine histological processing, the glycogen content is reduced and looks like thin strands that stretch from the nuclei to the surface membrane, which appears like ‘spider cells’.

Option D: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors and the histological picture shows the presence of bland Schwann cells admixed with stromal cells such as mast cells, perineural cells, and fibroblasts. The stroma of the tumors contains loose collagen arranged in wavy bundles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with an ultrasound report suggesting a fetus in breech position with hyperextended neck. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fetus with a hyperextended neck indicates that the fetus is in a stargazing position at term. The next best step in the management is to terminate by Cesarean section.

This hyperextension makes vaginal delivery and ECV dangerous as they can result in fetal cervical spine injury. And thus, the stargazing position is an indication for a Cesarean section.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

Note: Flying fetus is a term used when the fetus is in a transverse lie with a hyperextended neck.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: Pelvic examination of a patient with post-menopausal bleeding shows a growth in the vagina. A biopsy reveals that the growth is endometrial adenocarcinoma. Surgery is performed. Distant metastases are absent. What is the stage of her cancer?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina with absent distant metastasis is likely to be in Stage 3B.

Surgical staging of Ca endometrium with total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingoophorectomy+lymphadenectomy is the cornerstone of treatment. Thus, further management is mainly postoperative.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair of muscle locations with their action on the mandible.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as "1" in the above image is the lateral pterygoid muscle and its function is the depression of the mandible (opening of the mouth).

Marking  Muscle Action

  • Depression of the mandible (opening of the jaw)
  • Jaw protrusion
  • Side-to-side grinding movement
 2 Medial pterygoid
  • Elevation of mandible
  • Jaw protrusion
  • Side-to-side grinding movement

Among the four mastication muscles (temporalis, masseter, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid), the lateral pterygoid is the only muscle that helps in depression/ opening of the jaw. 

The main jaw opener muscles are digastric and geniohyoid.

The image below shows the muscles of mastication.

questions.text: Which of the following fluids have high potassium and low sodium content?
questions.solution:
Endolymph is akin to intracellular fluid and hence high in potassium.

Perilymph and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are both extracellular fluids (ECF) that are high in sodium.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text:
The laboratory results of a patient with congestive cardiac failure are given below. He does not have any preexisting renal condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine sodium  18 mEq/L
Urine osmolality 800 mOsm/L of water
Fractional excretion of Na <1%
Urine/plasma creatinine >40
questions.solution:
Based on the history of congestive cardiac failure and given laboratory values, the most likely diagnosis is prerenal acute kidney injury. 

Prerenal acute kidney injury occurs due to reduced renal plasma flow and intraglomerular hydrostatic pressure. Common causes are hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The kidney has autoregulatory mechanisms to compensate for the decreased blood flow resulting in the retention of sodium and water to preserve blood volume. The urinary sodium and fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) will be also very low. The ratio of urine creatine/plasma creatinine is usually greater than 40:1. The urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) can be prerenal, intrinsic, or postrenal:

  Pre-renal AKI Renal AKI
(acute tubular necrosis)		 Post-renal AKI
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <250-300 mOsm/kg <400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 mEq/L >20mEq/L Variable
FeNa ≤1% 1-3% Variable
Urine creatinine/
plasma creatinine		 >40:1 <40:1  
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 <20:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline
casts		 Muddy brown cast

Normal.
RBCs, WBCs, or crystals may be seen


Various causes of acute kidney injury are given below:


Other options: 

Option A: Intrinsic acute kidney injury arises due to injury to the tubules, interstitium, blood vessels, or glomeruli. These include but are not limited to acute glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, sepsis, infections, and malignancies. 

Option C: Nephrotoxic acute kidney injury is a type of intrinsic kidney injury due to direct damage to the tubular cells of the kidney. They can be endogenous toxins such as myoglobin, hemoglobin, and uric acid. Contrast agents, aminoglycosides, and amphotericin B are also implicated.

Option D: Glomerulonephritis can cause intrinsic kidney failure by compromising the filtration barrier and the blood flow within the renal circulation. The FeNA is <1% and urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

questions.text: Increased baroreceptor discharge leads to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Increased baroreceptor discharge leads to the production of vasodilation, venodilation, bradycardia, and hypotension not hypertension.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels. They are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the blood vessels when there is an increased volume or blood pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. They are of two types - carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) and cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions). 

An increase in blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). This in turn inhibits the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) considered the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart.

Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic center. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node. 

These neural changes produce vasodilation, venodilation, hypotension, bradycardia, and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: While examining a 2-year-old child with peripheral edema, you notice alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal-pigmented areas on the hair strands. Which condition is this clinical finding typically associated with?
questions.solution:
Peripheral edema and alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand, i.e. the flag sign are typically associated with kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by pitting peripheral edema and apathy. It usually affects infants and children, most often around the age of weaning till the age of 4. Children are miserable, often refuse to eat with marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

Children with kwashiorkor have moon-shaped faces. Peripheral edema and abdominal distension due to hepatomegaly are consistent features. Skin changes of increased pigmentation in some sites along with desquamation results in 'flaky paint' or 'crazy pavement' dermatoses.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish. Alternating bands of hypopigmented and pigmented hair may be seen, known as the flag sign due to growth spurts. These growth spurts are not seen in a child with Marasmus. 


Other options:

Option A: Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition that occurs usually in children < 1 year due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears very thin, having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. Due to its aged and wrinkled appearance, the loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face'. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

The hair and nails often grow slowly and show brittleness. The hair is easily pluckable and areas of alopecia may be seen but not flag sign as there is no growth spurts in a child with marasmus. Lanugo hair may be observed on the face and neck. 


Option B: Pellagra is caused to niacin deficiency and presents as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis of pellagra is an intermittent, painful, or pruritic erythema and edema in sun-exposed areas. It gradually becomes a sharply marginated, hyperpigmented keratotic plaque. It commonly affects the dorsum of the hands. It can be associated with protein-energy malnutrition but not associated with any hair changes.


Option C: Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. It presents after weaning with diarrhea, alopecia, and a cutaneous eruption in the periorificial and acral areas. Children often have symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusted edges. It is associated with nutritional alopecia like marasmus and kwashiorkor but flag sign is not seen.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and enlarged lymph nodes. The microscopy of the patient's lymph node exudate shows the following appearance. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a man presenting with painful lesions in the nose and oral mucosa and microscopy of the lymph node aspirate showing pilot wheel appearance is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis which is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioidomycosis, also known as South Americal blastomycosis, is a chronic granulomatous infection typically involving the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs.

The disease initially affects the lungs upon inhalation of the fungal spores and subsequently spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics where it can cause ulcers and granulomas. These are characteristic clinical findings.

The causative agent is a thermally dimorphic fungus. In infected tissues, it is seen in yeast form with large oval cells surrounded by multiple buds encircling the mother cell. This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance. The other form which exists is mycelium.

Microscopic examination of the sputum or other material from the lesions with potassium hydroxide (KOH) or calcofluor white stain helps demonstrate the presence of the fungus. Cultures on Sabouraud’s or yeast extract agar and serological examination are also helpful in the diagnosis.

Itraconazole is very effective against paracoccidioidomycosis, but ketoconazole and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can also be given. Severe disease is treated with amphotericin B.

The given image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis:

The given image shows swollen lymph nodes in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

The given image shows a CT scan of a patient with lung involvement in paracoccidioidomycosis. Note bilateral small nodules, ground-glass changes, and a cavitary lesion:

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following technique is used to sequence proteins without prior purification?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to sequence proteins without prior purification.

Tandem mass spectrometry involves two mass spectrometers linked in series. Individual peptides are separated by the first spectrometer based on the differences in mass of each peptide.

A single peptide is directed to the second mass spectrometer by adjusting the field strength of the first magnet. Here, it gets fragmented and the mass is determined.

It is used to screen the blood samples of newborns for genetic disorders such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutamic acidemia.

Other options:

Ion exchange chromatography, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, and isoelectric focusing are the methods of purifying/separating proteins.

Related Pearl: Some Important Methods Used to Study Glycoproteins

Method Use
Periodic acid-Schiff stain Detects glycoprotein as pink bands
Mass spectrometry Molecular mass, composition, sequence, and sometimes branching of a glycan chain. can be used for site-specific glycosylation profiling.
NMR spectroscopy To identify specific sugars, their sequence, linkages, and the anomeric nature of glycosidic chain.
Amino acid or cDNA sequencing Determination of amino acid sequence.

questions.text: In the given breathing pattern, what are the points with the highest PCO2 in pulmonary blood and the highest PCO2 of the neurons in the respiratory center respectively?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Cheyne-Stokes respiration. The highest PCO2 of pulmonary blood and the neurons in the respiratory center are denoted by points 1 and 2 respectively.
 
Cheyne-Stokes respiration is a pattern of periodic breathing. It is characterized by periods of hyperventilation with gradual waxing and waning of the tidal volume separated by equal periods of apnea. It occurs during sleep and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.
In the Cheyne-Stokes pattern, the depth of respiration corresponds to the PCO2 in the respiratory center. The maximum depth of respiration occurs when the PCO2 in the respiratory center is maximum. (Point 2)
 
The CO2 of the pulmonary blood takes several seconds before it is transported to the brain. Therefore, when there is excessive ventilation, the CO2 washes away, and PCO2 is decreased in the blood. After a delay, the PCO2 in the respiratory center is decreased and ventilation is inhibited. 
 
During the phase of apnea, the PCO2 of the pulmonary blood starts rising, however, the ventilation does not begin immediately. After some delay, at the time when the PCO2 in the pulmonary blood reaches the maximum, the PCO2 in the respiratory center starts rising, and at this point (Point 1) the ventilation begins.
 
The image given below shows different types of breathing patterns.

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

CP - middle cerebellar peduncle

DRG - Dorsal group of respiratory neurons

IC - inferior colliculus

NPBL - nucleus parabrachialis (pneumotaxic center)

VRG - ventral group of respiratory neurons
