questions.text: A concerned pregnant woman underwent karyotyping which was highly suggestive of a particular syndrome. The image of her results is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is associated with patients with the given karyotype?
questions.solution:
The above karyotype - 47, XXY, is suggestive of Klinefelter’s syndrome, in which gynecomastia and long thin limbs are seen.

Klinefelter’s syndrome:

  • Most common sex aneuploidy in males
  • Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY
  • Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division)

Clinical features:

  • Disproportionately long arms and legs
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Gynecomastia
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma
  • Testicular dysgenesis
  • Infertility/ azoospermia

Note:

A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature.

questions.text: A mother is advised that the baby should be allowed to empty one breast completely before switching over to the other for optimum growth. All the following are reasons for this, except ____.

choices.text: Foremilk is rich in  sugar and vitamins

questions.solution:
While breastfeeding, the mother should allow complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both fore-milk and hind-milk for optimum growth. Hind milk is rich in fats that provide more energy.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right hand. Her daily routine involves taking care of her 2 kids. Of late, she feels excruciating pain in certain movements of her hand. On examination, the Finkelstein test is positive. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved in this condition?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive Finkelstein's test is suggestive of De Quervain's disease. The structures likely to be involved in this condition are extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test- the examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons. 

The image below shows Finkelstein's test. 


Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you prefer not to use a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) for securing the airway?

choices.text: Providing CPR to a patient who had a road traffic accident
A 45-year-old male patient with suspected lung carcinoma, planned for bronchoscopy
A 50-year-old man planned for laparoscopic appendicectomy, having Mallampati class III airway
A term G2P1L1 previously diagnosed with preeclampsia planned for elective LSCS

questions.solution:
From the above-given options, laryngeal mask airway (LMA) cannot be used in a term woman previously diagnosed with preeclampsia planned for elective LSCS. This is because pregnancy is a state which is more prone to aspiration and hence LMA is contraindicated.

A laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic device that consists of a wide bore tube. It has a proximal end connected to a breathing circuit while a distal end is connected to an elliptical cuff which can be inflated through a pilot tube. 

It is inserted in a deflated manner following lubrication blindly into the hypopharynx. After inflation, it forms a low-pressure seal around the laryngeal entry. Ideally positioned cuff will have the base of the tongue superiorly and the upper esophageal sphincter inferiorly. Pyriform sinuses should be present laterally.

It is indicated in cases with difficult airways where endotracheal intubation is not possible or not available. It can be used as an alternative to an endotracheal tube for ventilating and oxygenating the patient.  

Indications are acute trauma, difficult intubation, and laparoscopic surgeries, to facilitate fibreoptic intubation.

LMA is relatively contraindicated in

  • Conditions that are associated with an increased risk of aspiration such as hiatus hernia, and pregnancy. 
  • The presence of a pharyngeal pathology such as an abscess or tumor, or a pharyngeal obstruction.
  • Low pulmonary compliance.

Advantages of LMA are hands-free operation, better seal, and easy-to-maintain airway. It protects against secretions when compared to face masks. When compared with tracheal intubation, it is less invasive, useful in difficult intubations, causes less damage to the tooth and larynx, and does not require muscle relaxant and mobilization of the neck.

The disadvantages associated with the use of LMA in comparison with tracheal intubation are increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration, less safe in prone or jack-knife positions, less secure airway, and greater risk of a gas leak and pollution.

The below image shows the normal positioning of LMA.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O. 


 

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

Mask size Patient Size  Weight (kg) Cuff Volume (mL)
1 Infant <5 2-4
1.5 Infant 5-10 upto 7
2 Child 10-20 upto 10
2.5 Child 20-30 upto 14
3 Small Adult 30-50 upto 20
4 Normal adult(women) 50-70 upto 30 
5 Normal adult >70 30-40
6 Adults >100 50

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with complaints of paroxysmal sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching in the nose. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of his condition?

choices.text: Intranasal cromolyn sodium is recommended for mild disease
Intranasal steroids is recommended for moderate disease
Oral steroids is recommended for severe persistent disease
Immunotherapy is recommended for severe persistent disease for at least a period of 1 month

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic rhinitis. In allergic rhinitis, immunotherapy is recommended for severe persistent disease for a period of at least 1 year along with a short course of oral steroids.

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunological response of the nasal mucosa to allergens in the environment.

Patients typically present with recurrent bouts of sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching and clinical signs include allergic shiners (dark circles around the eyes) and allergic salute (black transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose due to repeated upward rubbing).

Allergic rhinitis can be classified into intermittent and persistent, based on the duration of the disease:

  • Intermittent- Symptoms are present for less than 4 days a week, or less than 4 weeks
  • Persistent- Symptoms are present for more than 4 days a week, or more than 4 weeks

It can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe based on the severity of the disease:

  • Mild- None of the following symptoms are present- sleep impairment, impairment of daily activities, school, or work, troublesome symptoms.
  • Moderate- severe: If at least one of the symptoms mentioned above are present.

Treatment options include:

  • Avoidance of the allergen
  • Treatment with drugs like oral antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, intranasal cromolyn sodium
  • Immunotherapy is through the delivery of allergen in gradual increasing doses till the maintenance dose is reached. It suppresses the development of IgE. It has to be given for a year to see significant improvement in symptoms.

A step-care approach is recommended for allergic rhinitis and its impact on asthma (ARIA) for the treatment of allergic rhinitis includes the following:

  • Oral antihistamines or intranasal cromolyn sodium are recommended for mild, intermittent disease. (option A).
  • Intranasal corticosteroids are used for moderate disease as monotherapy. (option B).
  • Oral antihistamines and intranasal steroids can be used in combination to treat severe diseases. (option C).
  • A short course of oral corticosteroids and immunotherapy can be used for severe, persistent disease in case the above intervention fails.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab within him after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?

BNSS- Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defences by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata - BNSS Section 337 (CrPC 300) states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: At which stage of a woman's life, is the vaginal pH at its maximum?
questions.solution:
The vaginal pH is maximum at post-menopausal age. The pH is more than 7.

The pH of the vagina is acidic due to the presence of lactic acid. This is mainly due to the Doderlein bacteria or lactobacillus, a large gram-positive rod. It converts the glycogen in the vaginal epithelium to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen.

The pH of the vagina is around 4.5 during the reproductive life. The acidity falls after menopause. The pH of 6-7.5 is strongly suggestive of menopause. 

The pH is also high before puberty. It is about 7.

questions.text: A man with chronic alcoholism presented with orthopnea and pedal edema. On investigation, cardiomegaly is noted. Which vitamin deficiency can lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure (orthopnea and pedal edema) and cardiomegaly in a patient with chronic alcoholism suggest a diagnosis of wet beriberi. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to this condition. 

Chronic alcohol consumption is associated with thiamine deficiency due to inadequate dietary intake, malabsorption of thiamine from the gastrointestinal tract and impaired utilization of thiamine in the cells. This deficiency presents as:

  1. Wet beriberi: The cardiovascular system is affected. Patients present with high output cardiac failure (orthopnea, pedal edema), dyspnea, cardiomegaly, and pulmonary edema.
  2. Dry beriberi: Both the peripheral and central nervous systems are affected. Patients present with symmetric motor and sensory neuropathy (pain, paresthesia, loss of reflexes) especially in lower limbs. In severe cases, muscle atrophy may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Assay and test

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

questions.text: A physician prescribed varenicline to a young smoker who wanted to quit smoking. About which of the following adverse effects should the patient be counseled about?
questions.solution:
Suicidal ideation is an adverse effect of varenicline and the patient should be counseled about it. 

Varenicline is a first-line therapy advocated for smoking cessation. It is a partial agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It helps in the reduction of cigarette craving and maintenance of abstinence. It has also been shown to reduce alcohol consumption. Other side effects of varenicline include taste disturbances, appetite changes, agitation, and mood changes.

The first line pharmacologic interventions recommended for smoking cessation are:

  • Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT)
  • Bupropion
  • Varenicline

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant, which is frequently used as a sustained release formulation to aid in smoking cessation. Side effects include seizures, suicidal ideation, and tremors.

Nicotine replacement therapy helps to reduce the withdrawal symptoms of nicotine without the use of tobacco. Nicotine gum releases nicotine, which is absorbed through the buccal route. Acidic beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice can decrease the absorption of nicotine, hence should be avoided. Patients can use 1-2 gums per hour, and a maximum of 24 gums a day. Other forms available for NRT include nicotine lozenges, patches, nasal spray, and inhalers.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her family history reveals that her mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 50 years, while her 42-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Further investigations ruled out familial adenomatous polyposis and confirmed the diagnosis of familial cancer. Which of the following genes is most likely to be mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome in which the gene MSH2 is likely to be mutated. 

Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and as well as endometrial, ovarian, gastric and small intestine cancers. This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, mainly MLH1 and MSH2.

They occur commonly at a young age and mostly involve the right side. Histology shows:

  • Sessile serrated adenoma
  • Mucinous adenocarcinoma

It can be diagnosed by the Amsterdam II criteria or by genetic testing. 

Note- APC gene mutation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis and sporadic colonic cancer. The mechanism is due to a defect in APC/WNT pathway. 

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman comes to you in her first trimester and asks for your advice regarding immunisation. Which of the following vaccines would you tell is contraindicated for her?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is contraindicated for her as she is pregnant.

Varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is recommended for children aged 12-18 months and those without a history of chickenpox infection in the past. It is administered subcutaneously in one or two-dose schedules. 

It is contraindicated in pregnant, immunocompromised individuals and those who are allergic to neomycin. However, patients with clinically stable HIV on HAART (highly active anti-retroviral therapy) can be considered for vaccination if CD4+ cells >15%. Avoidance of salicylates is recommended 6 weeks after the vaccination to prevent Reye's syndrome. 

Maternal varicella infection may result in fetal loss and birth defects. If maternal varicella infection occurs within 5 days of delivery, the baby should receive VZIG (varicella-zoster immunoglobulin) due to the risk of disseminated infection.

Other options: 

Options A: Hepatitis A vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals in a two-dose schedule given intramuscularly one month apart.

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals. It is given intramuscularly in three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. 

Option C: Tetanus toxoid is routinely administered in pregnant women. The first dose is given at 16-20 weeks while the second dose is at 20-24 weeks ideally maintaining a one-month interval between the two doses.

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of taste sensation on the marked 'A' region of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The area marked as A in the above image is in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. The nerve likely to be affected is the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Nerves mediating the taste sensation in different parts of the tongue: 

  • Chorda tympani branch of facial nerve - anterior 2/3rd of the tongue 
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve -
    • Posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
    • Circumvallate papillae
    • Post-sulcal part of the tongue
    • Palatoglossal arches
    • Oropharynx
  • Internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve - posterior most (vallecullae, epiglottis) tongue.

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the IX cranial nerve. It leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath. Its branches are tympanic, carotid, pharyngeal, muscular, tonsillar, and lingual branches.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibers to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
  • Motor fibers to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibers for the postsulcal part of the tongue

Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. These plexes mainly supply the pharynx. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion. 

Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve examinations include:

  • Observe the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula at rest and with phonation (“aah”).
  • By assessing the strength of the cough.

Infection, malignancy, and postoperative inflammation of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa will cause referred pain in the ear. This is conducted through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal menstrual bleeding and crampy abdominal pain. Bimanual examination reveals an irregularly enlarged uterus.  All of the following are the risk factors for her condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abnormal menstrual bleeding, abdominal pain, and irregularly enlarged uterus are suggestive of a fibroid uterus. Smoking reduces the risk of fibroid uterus.

Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors mainly arising from the myometrium. Grossly, they are round rubbery masses with a whorled pattern.

  • Increased risk is seen in nulliparous women, early menarche, obesity, hyper-estrogenic state (endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma), and African-American women.
  • Decreased risk in multiparous women and smoking.

Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. When symptomatic, patients complain of abnormal menstrual bleeding, abdominal pain, urinary frequency, and incontinence.

Small and asymptomatic uterine fibroids do not require removal or medical treatment. They can be observed every 6 months. Large or symptomatic fibroids need treatment. Treatment may be medical, minimal invasive surgery, and surgery.

Medical treatment includes mifepristone, GnRH analogs, and Mirena IUCD. They cause shrinkage of tumor size. Minimal invasive procedures are uterine artery embolization, MRI-guided laser ablation, and laparoscopic myolysis. Surgical management includes myomectomy and hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies which women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy.

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, levonorgestrel 0.75 mg one tablet can be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and another tablet 12 hours later. 

Note: Under the National Reproductive and Child Health Programme, the Drug Controller of India has only approved levonorgestrel tablets for use as an emergency contraceptive pill.

Other options:

Option A: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analog used in the medical termination of pregnancy.

Option B: High doses of ethinylestradiol can provide emergency contraception when used in combination with levonorgestrel. This is known as the Yuzpe regime.

Option C: Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and prevents/ delays ovulation, and suppresses the endometrium, thereby preventing implantation. Ulipristal 30 mg should be taken within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. It is approved by US-FDA and European medicine agencies but at present, it is not available in India as an emergency contraceptive pill.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging midline neck swelling, along with hoarseness of voice and dyspnea. The histopathological study of the biopsy is given below. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathology slide showing sheets of undifferentiated, anaplastic cells with marked cytologic atypia, are likely suggestive of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare and one of the most aggressive malignancies in humans. It is usually diagnosed in the elderly and there is a female preponderance. The clinical features include rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, hoarseness, cough, and hemoptysis. Patients have distant metastasis at the time of presentation and the most common sites include lungs, bone, and brain.

Management of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (ATC) is as follows:

  • Total thyroidectomy with central node dissection is the recommended surgery.
  • En bloc resection- if an extrathyroidal extension is present.
  • Postoperative external beam irradiation or adjunctive chemotherapy (adriamycin + paclitaxel/cisplatin) is given to prolong survival.

Other options:

Option B: Follicular thyroid carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is characterised by branching papillae, orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and psammoma bodies that are concentric calcified structures within the papillae. They are shown below in the image.

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient who is known to have polycystic ovarian syndrome comes with complaints of excessive facial hair as shown below. Which of the following is an androgen receptor antagonist that can be used in the treatment of this symptom?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing excessive facial hair are suggestive of hirsutism. Among the above options, flutamide can be used to manage hirsutism.

However, the use of flutamide should be made with caution as it can cause hepatotoxicity (not commonly used for cosmetic purposes). 

Flutamide is a non-steroidal androgen receptor antagonist used in the treatment of prostatic cancer and in female hirsutism. Other anti-androgens like bicalutamide, nilutamide, and enzalutamide are mainly used with a GnRH analog (such as leuprolide) in managing metastatic prostate cancer. They cannot be used alone in prostate cancer because they increase LH secretion which further causes an increase in serum testosterone secretion. 

Hirsutism is an increased male pattern of hair growth in women of the reproductive age group. It can occur as a benign condition or can be a part of overt virilization caused by excessive androgen production (due to ovarian/adrenal tumors). Other specific causes include PCOS, Cushing's syndrome, etc. Initial therapy is usually with a combination of oral contraceptive pills and, if patients fail to respond, can be changed to anti-androgens like spironolactone, cyproterone acetate, finasteride, and flutamide. Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that also reduces prostate size.

Other options:

Option A - Nilutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used to treat prostate cancer. It is not used in the management of hyperandrogenic states like hirsutism and acne.

Option C- Dutasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D- Letrozole is a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina which started a week earlier. On examination, the vaginal walls are congested with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Whiff's test is positive and gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. What can be used to treat the condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of vaginal itching, foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and positive Whiff test with clue cells in the gram staining is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. It is treated with metronidazole.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial condition caused by an increase in a number of organisms such as Gardnerella, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus and Mycoplasma hominis.

This is due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora which causes a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. It mainly reduces the pH and has antibacterial action by releasing hydrogen peroxide.

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells has a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Other options:

Option B: Ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of Gonococcal vaginitis.

Option C and D: Azithromycin and Tetracycline are used in the treatment of chlamydia infections.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A child with a history of egg allergy is advised not to take the live attenuated vaccine for influenza by their family doctor as the vaccine was developed by growing the influenza virus in an embryonated egg. Which of the following sites of an embryonated egg is used for the influenza virus vaccine production?
questions.solution:
Allantoic cavity inoculation is used for the growth of the influenza virus for vaccine production.

Embryonated eggs of a duck or a hen are used for the cultivation of several viruses at different sites. These sites are:

  • Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) (option A) inoculation results in the formation of lesions called pocks. These vary in morphology from one virus to another and each virus particle forms one pock under suitable conditions. Pock counting is employed in the assay of variola or vaccinia.
  • The allantoic cavity can be used to inoculate influenza and some paramyxoviruses. 
  • Inoculation of the amniotic sac (option B) is used for the isolation of the influenza virus.
  • The yolk sac (option C) is inoculated for the cultivation of viruses, chlamydiae, and rickettsiae.

For the production of the influenza vaccine, each strain of virus is grown in the allantoic cavity of the embryonated eggs. The allantoic or amniotic fluids may be harvested to prepare a single harvest after incubation.

Other chick embryo vaccines include those for yellow fever (17D strain) and the non-neural rabies vaccine. (Flury strain)

Related Pearl: Cultivation of viruses

Animal inoculation:

  • Suckling mice are used for inoculation of coxsackie and arbovirus

Tissue culture: Cell lines

  • Primary cell lines- Rhesus kidney cell line, Human amniotic cell line, Chick embryo fibroblast
  • Secondary cell lines- Human fibroblast cell line, MRC-5, and WI- 38
  • Continuous cell lines- HeLa cell line, HEp-2, KB, Vero

Embryonated egg inoculation:

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit all of the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a louse. It can transmit all diseases except endemic typhus. The vector for endemic typhus is rat flea. 

The table below shows diseases transmitted by the louse, and the causative agent:

Disease transmitted by louse   Causative agent
Epidemic typhus Rickettssia prowazeki
Relapsing fever Borrelia recurrentis
Trench fever Bartonella quintana
Pediculosis Infestation with the louse

Rickettsial infections are classified based on clinical features and epidemiology as follows:

Group

Zoonotic disease

 Vector
Typhus group  

Epidemic typhus

 Louse

Murine typhus

Flea

Scrub typhus

 Mite
Spotted fever group  

Indian tick typhus

Tick

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 Tick

Rickettsialpox

 Mite
Others 

Q fever 

 -
Trench fever Louse

Rickettsial infections present with fever, malaise, headache, prostration, hepatosplenomegaly and a skin rash. Q fever does not have skin lesions. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for all rickettsial infections. 

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: You are asked to plan a combination therapy for a 60-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is being treated for congestive heart failure. His liver and renal functions are normal and his BMI is within normal limits. Which of the following class of drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones should be avoided in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).

Thiazolidinediones are drugs that act by binding to the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ), thereby reducing insulin resistance. These drugs are associated with an increase in plasma volume, weight gain, and hepatotoxicity. They commonly result in peripheral edema and are contraindicated in patients with CHF and hepatic disease. Metformin (biguanides) is also avoided in unstable CHF. 

Oral glucose-lowering agents include:

  • Biguanides: metformin
  • Insulin secretagogues: glimepiride, repaglinide
  • α-glucosidase inhibitors: acarbose
  • Dipeptidyl peptidase inhibitors: sitagliptin
  • Thiazolidinediones: rosiglitazone, pioglitazone

The management of type 2 diabetes mellitus should be initiated with medical nutrition therapy. According to the American diabetes association, vegetables, fruits, low glycemic index foods, and high fiber content is recommended. 

Other options:

Option B: α-glucosidase inhibitors reduce glucose absorption from the GI tract by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down oligosaccharides. They should be avoided in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The common side effects include diarrhea, flatulence, and abdominal distention. 

Option C: Dipeptidyl peptidase IV inhibitor, increases insulin levels and decreases glucagon levels. This class of drugs generally warrants a reduced dose with renal insufficiency. Serious side effects include allergy and hypersensitivity reactions like anaphylaxis, angioedema, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Option D: Sulfonylureas act by increasing insulin secretion. These are recommended in individuals with recent onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus. These drugs are avoided in patients with hepatic and renal dysfunction. Common side effects include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Other classes of hypoglycemic drugs:

SGLT2 inhibitors: Lead to increased loss of glucose and sodium in the urine. This leads to an increased incidence of urinary and genital mycotic infections and fall in systolic blood pressure.

GLP-1 receptor agonists: They are associated with an increased risk of acute pancreatitis and are avoided in patients with pancreatic disease.

Biguanides: They are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Related Pearl: Treatment Goals for Adults with Diabetes

Index

Goal

HbA1c*

< 7 %

Preprandial capillary plasma glucose

80–130 mg/dL

Peak postprandial capillary plasma glucose

<180 mg/dL

Blood pressure+

< 140/80 mmHg

*Note that most diabetes associations recommend the target HbA1c must be individualized to the patient. A target of <7% is reasonable in most individuals.

+ Blood pressure: Harrison's 20th  edition,(based on ADA) recommends the target blood pressure goal of <140/90 mmHg for adults with diabetes. It further adds that for younger individuals the target blood pressure is <130/80 mmHg. But the "AHA/SPRINT TRIAL recommendations" recommend that the goal of blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus is less than 130/80 mmHg.

Dyslipidemia: Although not a treatment goal, ADA recommends to intensify lifestyle therapy and optimize glycemic control for patients with elevated triglyceride levels (≥150 mg/dL [1.7 mmol/L]) and/or low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dL for men, <50 mg/dL  for women). Treatment with statins would depend on the overall cardiovascular risk (ASCVD) rather than specific LDL/HDL cholesterol level.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Diabetes mellitus

I. Type 1 diabetes: Beta cell destruction, usually leading to absolute insulin deficiency

  • Immune-mediated
  • Idiopathic

II. Type 2 diabetes: Insulin resistance with relative insulin deficiency

III. Other specific types of diabetes

  • Genetic defects of beta cell development or function
    • MODY – Maturity Onset Diabetes of Young
  • Genetic defects in insulin action
    • Type A insulin resistance
    • Leprechaunism
    • Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome Lipodystrophy syndromes
  • Diseases of the exocrine pancreas
    • Pancreatitis
    • Neoplasia
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Hemochromatosis
  • Endocrinopathies
    • Acromegaly
    • Cushing’s syndrome
    • Glucagonoma
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Infections
    • Congenital rubella
    • Cytomegalovirus
    • Coxsackievirus
  • Uncommon forms of immune-mediated diabetes
    • “Stiff-person” syndrome
    • Anti-insulin receptor antibodies
  • Genetic syndromes sometimes associated with diabetes
    • Wolfram’s syndrome
    • Down’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome

IV. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient in her second trimester came with complaints of bleeding. She had a prior Cesarean section. Ultrasound showed a placental abnormality that corresponds to the illustration given below. The following placental abnormality is due to the absence or improper development of ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta percreta. The abnormality is due to the partial or total absence of decidua basalis.

Decidua is the modified endometrium of pregnancy. It is classified into three parts as follows:

  • Decidua basalis is the part deeper into the developing blastocyst.
  • Decidua capsularis: part surrounding enlarging blastocyst and separating the conceptus and the uterine cavity.
  • Decidua parietalis: part lining the rest of the uterine cavity.

The below image shows the parts of the decidua.

The pathology in this condition is that the decidua basalis is absent and the Nitabuch layer is imperfectly developed.

When the villi are attached to the myometrium, it is known as placenta accreta whereas, in placenta increta, the myometrium is invaded by the villi. In placenta percreta, there is the penetration of villi through the serosa and the myometrium.

Risk factors include a co-existing previa and previous history of Cesarean section. Hemorrhage is the most common presentation in the first and second trimesters.

Treatment is a Cesarian section followed by hysterectomy.

The below image shows the placenta accreta, increta and percreta.

questions.text: A deceased male was brought to the morgue for a ​post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes should be examined in this case.

Some amount of material or dye used for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Hence, in cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined.

questions.text: A young patient on awakening after surgery complains of severe pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Which of the following drug is better suited to rescue this patient from pain?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is better suited to rescue this patient from pain. It is the most commonly used drug in rescue analgesia due to its rapid pain control and less incidence of adverse effects.

Rescue Analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize severe post-operative pain. Mild pain can be treated with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl. Fentanyl (20 to 25 μg) is commonly used for this purpose to rapidly achieve analgesia. 

Fentanyl is a potent short-acting opioid analgesic. It is lipophilic in nature.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone in rescue analgesia. It controls the pain more rapidly than morphine (option A) and also reduces the incidence of PONV i.e postoperative nausea and vomiting. While oxycodone (option C) has good analgesic action when given systemically for visceral pain relief, it has an increased incidence of adverse effects when compared to fentanyl. Hence, fentanyl is preferred over morphine and oxycodone for rescue analgesia. 

Other uses are: to manage pain before surgical procedures, supplement in balanced anesthesia, in combination with benzodiazepines in diagnostic, endoscopic, angiographic, and minor procedures, and as an adjuvant in spinal anesthesia.

Hypertonia can often occur following a rapid infusion of fentanyl and hence a muscle relaxant is often supplemented. Respiratory depression is a common side effect. Other side effects include nausea, vomiting, and itching.

Note: Codeine is a less potent opioid agonist. Oral codeine is useful to suppress cough but has mild to moderate analgesic properties. When given intravenously, it can cause profound hypotension, and hence it is not recommended.

questions.text: The USG abdomen of a patient showed the following finding in the gall bladder. All of the following are essential for the formation of this except:
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of a gallstone. The gall bladder stone casts an acoustic shadow. Bile stasis, nucleation, and lithogenic bile are factors associated with gallstone formation. Crystallization is not an essential/precipitating factor for gallstone formation. 

The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder in a patient with cholelithiasis. The gall bladder stone casts an acoustic shadow.

Cholesterol is synthesized in the liver. Its solubility is determined by the relative concentration of cholesterol, bile salts, and phospholipid. Altered levels of cholesterol, phospholipids, and bile salts in bile reduce the micelle concentration in the bile leading to precipitation of insoluble cholesterol, hence, the stone formation (lithogenic bile). 

Factors affecting gallstone formation: 

  • Bile stasis due to impaired gallbladder 
    • Emptying
    • Absorption
    • Excretion
  • Lithogenic bile due to supersaturation
    • Age 
    • Sex
    • Genetics
    • Obesity 
    • Diet
  • Cholesterol nucleating factors
    • Mucus 
    • Glycoprotein
    • Infection
  • Impaired enterohepatic circulation of bile
    • Deoxycholate
    • Cholestyramine
    • Bowel transit time
    • Fecal enteric flora
    • Ileal resection

Related Pearl: Types of Gallstones

questions.text: A young patient was posted for liver transplantation surgery. He was given cisatracurium for neuromuscular blockade. Which of the following is not true regarding the class to which the drug belongs?

choices.text: Their action is potentiated by Mg2+ and antagonized by Ca2+
Characteristic train of 4 and tetanic fade present

questions.solution:
Cistacurium is metabolised by Hoffman's degradation. Mivacurium is metabolised by pseudocholinesterase.

Cisatracurium belongs to the class of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (NDMR). Cisatracurium is preferred in patients undergoing liver transplantation because of its organ-independent elimination and reduced histamine release. It is a competitive inhibitor at acetylcholine receptors.

Neuromuscular blockade can be done by depolarising or non-depolarizing agents.

Feature Depolarising (Non-competitive) block Non-depolarising (Competitive) block
Drugs Succinylcholine (SCh) at a normal dose (2-3mg/kg)
  • All other muscle relaxants
  • SCh at high doses (6mg/kg)or over a long period
Mechanism Non-competitive blockade of Ach receptor Competitive blockade of Ach receptors
Metabolism Pseudo cholinesterase (butyryl cholinesterase) Only mivacurium is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase.
Recovery Rapid Increasingly prolonged

Anticholin

esterase (Anti ChE)

 Potentiates the block Reverses the block

Train of four and tetanic stimulation

No fade

Fade
Train of 4 ratio More than 0.7 Less than 0.4
Antagonized by Acidosis, non-depolarizing muscle relaxants Mild cooling, SCh (not in myasthenics), Ca2+
Potentiated by Isoflurane, respiratory alkalosis, Mg2+, hypothermia Volatile agents, Mg2+, acidosis, hypokalemia, verapamil, further cooling below 33 degrees C.

Other options:

Option D: TOF (train of fade) is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade and is related to the degree of neuromuscular block.

The illustration shown below shows variations of a train of fade patterns by various muscle relaxants.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: An African American man came to the clinic with the lesion shown below. He says it has been there for years and seems to increase in size. It recurred after surgery. What is the underlying abnormality of this patient's lesion?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The underlying abnormality of keloid scars is the excessive accumulation of collagen with hypervascularity.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and certain parts of the body such as the triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip. These are more common in African Americans and tend to be inherited.

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and the keloid scar's excision has a high recurrence rate.

Note: The same pathology is seen in hypertrophic scars but they tend to be within the margins of the wound and rarely grow beyond the margins of the original wound. 

Other options:

Option A: The exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts is seen in desmoid tumors, a low-grade neoplasm occurring due to exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts and other connec­tive tissue elements, following inci­sional scars or traumatic injuries.

Option B: Excessive accumulation of granulation tissue is seen in proud flesh, where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and block re-epithelialization.

Option D: Exaggerated wound contraction occurs in contractures, where excessive contraction leads to deformities of the wound and surrounding tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following WHO strategies to control trachoma is considered as primordial prevention?
questions.solution:
Environmental cleanliness is considered as primordial prevention in the WHO strategies to control trachoma.

WHO programme for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness is SAFE strategy. It includes:

  • Surgery - Tertiary prevention.
  • Antibiotic use - Secondary prevention.
  • Facial hygiene - Primary prevention.
  • Environmental changes - Primordial prevention.

Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness in the world. Features are foreign body sensation, lacrimation, mucoid discharge etc. On examination, conjunctival follicles resembling boiled sago grains are seen. The follicles if present on the bulbar conjunctiva, is pathognomic. Herbert's follicles may be seen at the limbus. The cornea may get infiltrated and vascularized leading to progressive pannus.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: Trachoma Staging

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

questions.text: A patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the formation of Bezold abscess.

Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system.

The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis:

Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid. Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy.

Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are:

  • Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the parapharyngeal space

The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess:

 

Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:

  • Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
  • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
  • Luc abscess (meatal abscess) -  the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and external auditory meatus
  • Citelli’s abscess - the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone

questions.text:
Match the following.
1) Verocay bodies A) Granulosa cell tumor
2) Cowdry type-A bodies B) Asbestosis
3) Call-Exner bodies C) Herpes simplex infection
4) Ferruginous bodies D) Schwannoma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, and 4-B.

  • Verocay bodies - Schwannoma
  • Cowdry type-A bodies - Herpes simplex infection
  • Call-Exner bodies - Granulosa cell tumor
  • Ferruginous bodies - Asbestosis

Verocay bodies: It is seen in microscopic examination of schwannoma.

Schwannoma consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The Antoni A areas contain densely arranged spindle-shaped cells. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain loosely arranged spindle-shaped cells. These cells are separated by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Cowdry type-A bodies

The Cowdry type-A bodies are large eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions seen in Herpes simplex virus infection. They appear as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo.

Call-Exner bodies :

It is occasionally seen in cases of granulosa cell tumors. These are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles.

Ferruginous bodies

They are formed by inorganic particulates like asbestos coated with iron-protein complexes. It is seen in asbestosis.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is bought to your outpatient department with complaints of bleeding gums. Investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. Further workup revealed a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX. What is the underlying pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX are suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is a disorder of platelet adhesion.

Platelet adhesion normally occurs due to interaction between Gp Ib of the platelets and von Willebrand factor (vWF) of the subendothelium of blood vessels. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the defect in Gp Ib/IX results in impaired adhesion of platelets. This causes a defect in the formation of the primary platelet plug, leading to abnormal bleeding tendency.

Other options:

Option A- Disorder of platelet aggregation - Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a disorder of platelet aggregation. It occurs because of the dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb–IIIa, which is responsible for bridge formation between the platelets by binding fibrinogen.

Option C- Disorder of platelet activation - These are characterized by the defective release of certain mediators of platelet activation, such as thromboxanes and granule-bound ADP. These include platelet storage pool disorders and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Option D- Disorder of platelet production - These may include disorders involving ineffective hematopoiesis such as leukemias and bone marrow failure or they may be drug-induced.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild thrombocytopenia  Normal Normal (except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)

(aggregation of platelets)
