questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. Ultrasonographic examination shows overlapping of skull bones and no fetal movements. Which of the following is false about this likely condition?

choices.text: Robert's sign may be seen as early as 12 hours
Spalding's sign may be seen on USG
Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required
Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intrauterine fetal death (absent fetal heart sounds, no fetal movements and Spalding's sign on ultrasound). The false statement is spontaneous expulsion is rare and induction is required.

It is an antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. In most of these cases, spontaneous expulsion occurs within 10-14 days. 

The causes of intrauterine fetal death are given below -

  • Maternal - Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, diabetes in pregnancy, maternal infections, APLA, hyperpyrexia, thrombophilias, abnormal labour, post-term pregnancy, SLE
  • Fetal - Chromosomal abnormalities, structural abnormalities, infections, Rh-incompatibility, non-immune hydrops, growth restriction
  • Placental - Antepartum hemorrhage, cord accident, twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency
  • Iatrogenic - External cephalic version, drugs
  • Idiopathic 

Sonographically, fetal heartbeat and fetal movements are absent. Overlapping of skull bones irregularly on one another known as Spalding's sign can be seen. Also, a gas shadow in the chambers of the fetal heart and great vessels called Robert's sign is seen as early as 12 hours.

Complications like infection following rupture of membranes with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii, and blood coagulation disorders may occur.

Management includes early intervention for psychological issues, signs of uterine infection, prolonged retention beyond two weeks, and falling fibrinogen levels. The first-line choice for induction of labor in such cases is a combination of mifepristone and prostaglandins, although misoprostol and oxytocin infusion can also be utilised effectively.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: Drug 'X', a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist, is prescribed to treat a patient with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Identify the drug 'X'.
questions.solution:
Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS–D.

Options B and C: Tegaserod and lubiprostone are used in the treatment of constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS–C).

Option D: Ondansetron is used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A 70-year-old post-renal transplant patient, who is on cyclosporine, is diagnosed to have enterococcal endocarditis and started on gentamicin and penicillin. Which of the following factors is least likely to cause gentamicin-related renal toxicity in this patient?
questions.solution:
High-dose extended-interval gentamicin administration is least likely to cause gentamicin-related renal toxicity in this patient. 

High-dose, extended-interval dosing schemes are the preferred means for administering aminoglycosides, as it has fewer chances of causing the characteristic ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. This strategy ensures a good therapeutic response and initial bacterial killing. But it should be avoided in patients with decreased creatinine clearance levels.

Renal toxicity is more likely in elderly (>60 years of age) patients and with the concurrent use of nephrotoxic drugs such as cyclosporine. Prolonged therapy and the total amount of drug administered also contribute to its toxicity. Due to its low safety margin, patients on aminoglycosides should undergo therapeutic drug monitoring, especially during extended interval dosing regimens.

Gentamicin is used to treat serious gram-negative bacillary infections. In enterococcal endocarditis, a combination of gentamicin and penicillin is given for 4-6 weeks as the standard therapy. The threshold for toxicity for gentamicin is the plasma concentration of 2 μg/mL, the maximum recommended for prolonged exposure.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following tests would you use to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo in a patient?
questions.solution:
Diascopy is a test that helps to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo.

Nevus anemicus is secondary to a localized area of vasoconstriction, and diascopy of the adjacent skin reveals a color identical to that of the ‘depigmented’ area, since other pigments are unaltered. In vitiligo, the lesion appears paler, since there is a loss of melanin.

Diascopy is a clinical maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. In this procedure, a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic is pressed onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on diascopy, known as ‘apple jelly’ nodules. They are seen in all 3 of sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • Differentiation between nevus anemicus and nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevus: Application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation between erythema (vasodilation) and purpura (extravasated blood): Erythema blanches on compression of vessels, while purpura and petechiae do not blanch on compression.

Wood's lamp examination can also be used to distinguish between vitiligo and nevus anemicus.

In vitiligo, the depigmented areas appear milky white, due to a loss of melanin, while in nevus anemicus, the pallor completely disappears, since it is secondary to localized vasoconstriction.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a primary health center. On 5th May 2023, you took a look at these 4 vaccine vials. Vial 1 had an expiry date of 4th May 2023 and the rest of the vials had an expiry date of 14th October 2023. Which of the following vials could be used?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, only vial 2 can be used.

According to the vaccine vial monitor, vial 1 and vial 2 can be used, but vial 2 is the one that was really fit for use as it had not yet expired as on 5th May 2023. Whereas, vial 1 has crossed the date of expiry.

Vial 3 and vial 4 should be discarded even though the drug has not expired. This is because the color in the inner square has matched the outer circle in vial 3 and is darker than the outer circle in vial 4.

Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are chemical indicator labels which are used to monitor the heat stability of the vaccines and are useful throughout the vaccine supply chain. The VVMs are designed to ensure that heat-damaged vaccines are not given to the patients. They also indicate preferable order of usage of the vials, thereby minimising vaccine wastage. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

Related Pearl: Temperature Sensitivity of Vaccines

Heat sensitivity in order of decreasing sensitivity: 

Group Vaccines
A OPV
B Influenza
C

IPV

Japanese encephalitis(live)

Measles, mumps, rubella
D

Cholera

DTaP

Pentavalent

Rubella

BCG

Tetanus, TD, Td
F

Hepatitis B

Pneumococcal

Vaccine sensitivity to freezing:

Rotavirus(liquid)< T,DT,dT< IPV < Hib(liquid)< HepB < Pentavalent <DTaP

Vaccines not damaged by freezing:

  • Yellow fever
  • BCG
  • Hib
  • Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated)
  • Measles, mumps, rubella

  • Rabies

questions.text: A patient who is posted for renal transplant in 5 hours is started on an interleukin- 2 receptor antagonist to prevent acute transplant rejection. Which of the following drugs would have likely been given?
questions.solution:
Basiliximab is the interleukin-2 receptor antagonist that would have been likely given.

It is otherwise known as the anti-CD25 antibody and is a murine-human chimeric monoclonal antibody that acts by inhibiting T-cell activation and proliferation, but does not induce cell lysis. It is used prophylactically to prevent acute solid-organ rejection. 

Basiliximab is used with a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine and prednisone. It is also effectively used in a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine, Mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Lymphoproliferative disorders and anaphylactic reactions may occur rarely as adverse effects.

Other options:

Option A: Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and arrests the immune response at a later stage than cyclosporine. It can be used alone or in combination with cyclosporine or corticosteroid and mycophenolate mofetil. It is not recommended for a liver transplant. 

Option C: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor and is highly effective in preventing graft rejection reactions. However, it is nephrotoxic.

Option D: Alemtuzumab is a humanized IgG1 that binds to CD52 found on normal and malignant B and T lymphocytes, NK cells, monocytes, macrophages, and a small population of granulocytes. It is used for the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia, relapsing and remitting multiple sclerosis and as an off-label in kidney transplant.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of abdominal pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, the patient had pain on passive extension of the right hip and a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is likely suggestive of a psoas abscess.

Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus due to an infection in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is also called a retroperitoneal abscess. The compartment contains iliacus and iliopsoas muscles. 

Psoas abscess is either primary or secondary. Tuberculosis of the spine leading to Pott's abscess was the leading cause of psoas abscess. But, recently, hematogenous spread of infection from an occult primary site (gastrointestinal or urinary tract) has become common, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. It can also occur due to contiguous extension of infection from neighboring structures.

Clinical features include:

  • Back pain and fever.
  • Soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin (hip).
  • Pain on passive hip extension or active flexion of the psoas. 

CT scan is useful in diagnosis. Percutaneous CT-guided drainage and antibiotic therapy are useful in the treatment of the condition. 

Radiological images showing psoas abscess (mass lateral to the vertebral column).


Option A: Acute pyelonephritis is usually common in females during childhood, puberty, and during pregnancy. It is characterized by fevers, rigors, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness. 

Option C: Appendicitis is common in childhood. It is characterized by periumbilical pain, shifting pain to the right iliac fossa, rebound tenderness, and nausea. Psoas sign is seen in which the patient keeps the hip in a flexed position for pain relief.

Option D: Testicular torsion is seen as a bluish swelling at the superior pole of the testis. It can cause testicular pain and swelling.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD alone, seeking treatment for a minor medical condition. A general physical examination can be performed with just the child’s consent, only if the child is older than ______.
questions.solution:
A general physical examination can be performed, exclusively by the child's consent, if that child is older than 12 years of age.

According to section 89 of the I.P.C, a child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In these cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient even to save the patient's life.

Additionally, a father giving consent for an operative procedure on the child in good faith and for the child's benefit, though the said procedure is risky, cannot be held responsible if the child dies.

questions.text:
The SpO2 values of 5 patients in a COVID-19 ward are given below. Which of the following statement is true?
SpO2 levels 90% 92% 92% 92% 94%
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, mean = median = mode.

The mean is the sum of all the elements divided by the number of elements in the distribution. In this scenario, the mean = (90 + 92 + 92 + 92 + 94) / 5 = 460/ 5= 92%

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. In this scenario, the median = 92% which is the middle value.

The mode is the observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency. In this scenario, the mode = 92%

Hence, the mean = median = mode = 92%

In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same,  mean = median = mode. In a positively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the positive direction, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode. In a negatively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the negative direction, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Other options:

Options B and C: Mean = Mode = Median = 92%. Hence options B and C are incorrect.

Option D: There is only one value that occurs with the greatest frequency. Hence, the frequency distribution is unimodal. If two values occur with the greatest frequency then the frequency distribution is bimodal. If more than two values occur with the greatest frequency then the distribution is multimodal.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A patient with 1.5D myopia undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits:
questions.solution:
In a patient with myopia of 1.5D, the red reflex will exhibit movement against the plane mirror.

When a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter, based upon the movement of the red reflex, the results can be interpreted as:

  • No movement of red reflex: myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with the plane mirror retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, or myopia < 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the plane mirror retinoscope: Myopia >1D
  • Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text: A researcher wanted to study the social background of the disease under his study. He had a set of predetermined questions to interview his study population. What is the type of interview?
questions.solution:
The type of interview, in this case, is a structured interview where a set of predetermined questions are prepared and the reviewer gets the answers to those questions. 

Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. The technique is helpful in understanding the social and psychological factors in the natural history of the disease.

Types of interviews are: 

  • Direct or structured interview - consists of a set of predetermined questions and sequences
  • Non-directive or unstructured interview - doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions
  • Focused interview - is usually used to study the effects of mass communications like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect of the problem and draws responses from people
  • Repetitive interview - is used to find the gradual influence of social or psychological processes along with the maintenance of records

Related Pearl: The Art of Intervieweing

  • Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. A proper interview technique must be employed to achieve the objective.
  • Aims of an interview
    • To secure information usually through face to face association and to understand the individual/group being interviewed.
    • To form a hypothesis.
    • To collect personal data for quantitative purposes.
    • To collect data from secondary sources of information.
  • Types of interviews
    • A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence.
    • A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions.
    • A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communications like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem and draws responses from people.
    • A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.
  • Technique of interviewing
    • Establishing contact
    • Starting an interview
    • Securing rapport
    • Recall
    • Probe questions
    • Encouragement
    • Guiding the interview
    • Recording
    • Closing the interview
    • Report

questions.text: The X-ray image given below shows which type of Salter-Harris fracture?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows a fracture of the medial malleolus, with the fracture line in the epiphysis, below the physis. So it is a type III Salter-Harris fracture.

Salter-Harris classification is used to classify the injuries of the physis based on the radiological appearances. 

In a type III Salter-Harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance. This type of fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A lethargic infant was presented with vomiting and irritability. He was diagnosed with an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a deficiency in enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is likely to have a diagnosis of type 2 hyperammonemia inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate leading to elevated levels of glutamine in the blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

Infants present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea due to high ammonia levels in the plasma. Mothers also have an aversion to protein-rich foods. 

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea namely ammonia, and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  1. Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  2. Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  3. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  4. Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  5. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  6. Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with a large left breast mass with enlarged axillary lymph nodes. She also has a family history of breast cancer. Which is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Trucut /core-needle biopsy is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of breast carcinoma.

A 14 gauge needle is used for core biopsy which helps to analyze the breast architecture. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as compared to excisional breast biopsy.

Other options:

Option A: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not the investigation of choice. The needle used is a 22 gauge needle. It is used in the case of non-palpable lesions.

Option C: Mammography is either used to screen asymptomatic patients or evaluate patients with abnormal findings such as a mass or discharge. Two views - a mediolateral oblique (MOL) and a craniocaudal (CC) view are obtained. The volume of breast tissue and axillary tail of Spence is seen in the MOL view whereas the medial aspect of the breast is seen through the CC view. 

Option D: Excisional biopsy is one in which the breast lesion along with normal breast tissue is removed. It is done when the results of the core biopsy are not consistent with imaging findings and clinical findings.

questions.text: A patient being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following will decrease mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Long-term oxygen therapy will decrease mortality in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). 

Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting O2 saturation of ≤88% or ≤89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day). Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia. 

Patients with dependent edema, P-pulmonale on ECG, or hematocrit value >56% with PaO2 value between 56-59 mm Hg or SaO2 of 89% are also eligible for oxygen therapy.

COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction.  It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Patients present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. Diagnosis is based on pulmonary function tests and the severity is graded according to the global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease (GOLD) criteria. 

Pharmacotherapy of COPD includes:

  • Muscarinic antagonists: ipratropium, tiotropium
  • Beta-agonists: salbutamol, salmeterol
  • Theophylline
  • Inhaled corticosteroids

Acute exacerbations are managed with inhaled beta-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, oxygen, mechanical ventilation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation, and antibiotics.

Smoking cessation and lung volume reduction surgery in some emphysematous patients are the other interventions associated with reduced mortality.

Other options:

Option 2: Long-term oral glucocorticoids are not recommended to treat COPD due to the significant adverse effects such as osteoporosis, weight gain, and cataracts.

Option 3: Inhaled corticosteroids are mainly used to reduce exacerbations. Patients with two or more exacerbations per year or hospitalized patients with one exacerbation can be considered. 

Option 4: Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors (PDE4) inhibitor roflumilast can be used to reduce the frequency of exacerbations in severe COPD and chronic bronchitis.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with the complaint that she needs to check if the front door of her home is locked at least 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She understands that this habit is irrational but she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that her door is unlocked but has not been treated for the condition before.  which of these management options would you suggest for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder which can be managed by behavior therapy.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

Behavior therapy and pharmacotherapy can be used alone or in combination for the management of this condition. Behavior therapy is thought to be longer-lasting than pharmacotherapy. Hence, it is considered the treatment of choice by many clinicians. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or clomipramine are used for medical management.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors are called compulsions, such as counting and checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

It is associated with other mental disorders such as major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. In adults, it is seen with equal prevalence among men and women. The four major symptom patterns include contamination, pathological doubt, intrusive thoughts, and symmetry.

Other options:

Option A: Cingulotomy is carried out in severe and treatment-unresponsive patients.

Option B: Electroconvulsive therapy can be considered in treatment-resistant and chronically debilitating conditions.

Option D: Antipsychotics such as risperidone have been helpful in some cases when added to the treatment.

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: During ward rounds, you come across four patients who have sudden onset chest pain and breathlessness. All of them have a modified Well's score of 4. Assuming they are under the age of 50 with stable vitals, in whom can you rule out pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: A woman with SpO2 96% on room air
A man who had a recent road traffic accident
A man with unilateral lower limb swelling

questions.solution:
You can rule out pulmonary embolism in a woman with SpO2 96% on room air using the pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC).

The PERC, as the name suggests is a tool that includes 8 clinical criteria, which can be used to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients. A modified Well's score of ≤4 is a prerequisite for the application of this criteria. The criteria include:

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 beats per minute
  • SpO2 on room air ≥95%
  • No history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) injury or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No one-sided leg swelling

Patients who meet all the above criteria can be monitored off anticoagulation and needs to be assessed for alternative diagnoses as pulmonary embolism (PE) can be ruled out.

Patients with PE present with unexplained breathlessness, syncope, hypotension, and cyanosis.

Well's criteria is used as follows to assess the likelihood of developing pulmonary embolism.

Criteria along with the score is given below:

  • Signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT): 3
  • Alternative diagnosis is less likely: 3
  • Heart rate > 100/minute: 1.5
  • Surgery in previous 4 weeks, immobilization for more than 3 days: 1.5
  • Previous PE or DVT: 1.5
  • Hemoptysis: 1
  • Cancer: 1

According to modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely if the score is >4
  • PE unlikely if the score is ≤4

According to Well's criteria (Three-tiered clinical probability assessment):

  • High risk >6
  • Moderate risk 2-6
  • Low risk <2

Other options:

All the other patients have features that do not fit into the PERC criteria and hence pulmonary embolism cannot be ruled out.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old tourist presents with complaints of abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. He reports having food that had a disagreeable smell and taste at a local restaurant the previous night. The serotype of E. coli most likely responsible for these symptoms is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a tourist with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is indicative of traveler’s diarrhea. The serotype of E.Coli most likely responsible for these symptoms would be Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC).

Enterotoxigenic E.Coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. It has a heat-labile (LT) and a heat-stable toxin (ST). LT has 2 fragments A1 and A2. A1 activates the adenyl cyclase which forms cAMP. This leads to increased outflow of water and electrolytes in the gut, thus causing watery diarrhea. The heat-stable toxin ST acts by increasing cGMP in the intestine.

Other options:

Option A: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes bloody diarrhea resembling shigellosis. This ability to invade epithelial cells is determined by a plasmid.

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin and Shiga-like toxin. They target the vascular endothelium. EHEC also causes bloody diarrhea and can cause severe cases like hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Option D: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes diarrhea in infants and children in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using EPEC adhesion factor and LEE (chromosomally coded locus of enterocyte effacement). This causes the effacement of microvilli and disruption of the brush border. 

The electron micrographic image below shows EPEC adherent to effaced microvilli of the small bowel:


Note: Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on HEp-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever, muscle pain, and hemoptysis. Serology showed MPO-ANCA positivity. Laboratory parameters such as ESR and CRP were elevated. A diagnosis of microscopic polyangiitis is suspected. Which among the following is not a feature of the above likely condition?

choices.text: Medium and large arteries are spared

questions.solution:
Granuloma is not a feature of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is a vasculitis typically involving capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is more common in males with an age of onset of around 57 years.

Clinically, patients may complain of fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. They mainly present with glomerulonephritis and in a few cases, hemoptysis may be the presenting feature. Mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous vasculitis are the other manifestations. 

They are associated with MPO-ANCA or P-ANCA antibodies. ESR and CRP are elevated. Anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis are also present. 

Morphological features include:

  • Fibrinoid necrosis of the media with absent granulomas.
  • Sparing of the medium and large arteries.
  • Fragmented neutrophils in the postcapillary venules lead to leukocytoclastic vasculitis.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
Vessels affected Small and medium vessel vasculitis Small vessel vasculitis

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

GIT

Skin (cutaneous vasculitis)

Upper respiratory tract

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

Eye

Skin

Upper airway involvement

 Less common

More common

(Sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, septal perforation)
Nodular cavities in the lungs Absent Present
ANCA pANCA (mainly) cANCA(mainly)

Necrosis Present Present

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient presents with increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence which are muscarinic symptoms, likely due to pesticide(organophosphorus compounds) poisoning. 

Organophosphorus compounds are constituents of pesticides. They block the acetylcholinesterase thereby causing persistent parasympathetic muscarinic and nicotinic receptors activation resulting in the symptoms. They can be absorbed through the skin, mucosa, or gastrointestinal tract.

Four clinical syndromes are identified with respect to organophosphate exposure. They include: 

  • Acute poisoning - This results in CNS, muscarinic, nicotinic, and somatic motor manifestations.
  • Intermediate syndrome -  Usually observed 1-5 days after organophosphate exposure. It is characterized by paralysis of neck flexors, muscles innervated by cranial nerves, proximal limb muscles, and respiratory muscles.
  • Chronic toxicity - It is seen primarily in agricultural workers with daily exposure. It manifests as symmetrical sensorimotor axonopathy.
  • Organophosphate-induced delayed neuropathy - Characterized by cognitive dysfunction, extrapyramidal symptoms, and peripheral neuropathy. It can lead to flaccid paralysis and muscle wasting

A diagnosis can be made by measuring the pseudocholinesterase levels in RBC, which if less than 50%, confirms the diagnosis. Treatment involves the administration of atropine.  

Postmortem appearances - Congestion and frothy hemorrhagic exudate is seen in respiratory passages. Stomach contents smell of kerosene.

Other options: 

Option A: Arsenic clinical features can be divided into fulminant type, gastrointestinal type, or narcotic form. The fulminant type is characterized by death due to shock and peripheral vascular failure. The gastrointestinal type is a common form and is similar to food poisoning, akin to cholera. The narcotic form is characterized by giddiness, muscle tenderness, coma, and death.

Option B: Strychnine(spinal poison) consumption is responsible for opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, and pleurosthotonus. These symptoms occur due to convulsions and muscle rigidity caused by action on the spinal reflex centres. Risus sardonicus, where the jaws and facial muscles are contracted and drawn back, may also occur. 

Option D: Aconite(cardiac poison), if swallowed, causes tingling and numbness of the mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Salivation, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea then follow, and subsequently, the patient would develop dry mouth, thirst, and dysphagia. Paresthesia, ataxia, slurred speech, and muscle twitching. Hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia with AV block occur.

Related Pearl: Muscarinic and Nicotinic Signs and symptoms of Organophosphorus Poisoning

questions.text: A young woman was admitted to the psychiatry ward for severe depression with psychotic features, and a complete refusal to eat or drink. During rounds, she was found to be in the position shown in the image below, and resistance was felt in attempting to change her position. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for a patient with severe depression and psychotic features with posturing with waxy flexibility would be electroconvulsive therapy. 

Posturing with waxy flexibility refers to the maintenance of the body position into which they are placed, where any attempt made to change the posture results in resistance felt by the examiner. 

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by three or more behav­ioral abnormalities such as: 

  • Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  • Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  • Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  • Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  • Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  • Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  • Grimacing
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  • Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  • Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.

 The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially, lorazepam, are effective in temporarily improving the symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

Other options:

Option C: Lithium is a mood stabiliser used for the management of mania and bipolar depression. 

Option D: Transcranial magnetic stimulation using magnetic energy stimulates the nerve cells in the brain and is used for the treatment of depression. 

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A patient complained of fever with a mild headache associated with difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever, headache, difficulty in swallowing, and throat examination findings of swollen glands, whitish membrane over tonsils, and gram stain showing a rod-shaped organism arranged in Chinese letter pattern is faucial diphtheria.

The condition is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. It is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

Image below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).  

Other options:

Option A: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium perfringens. It usually occurs when the organism invades the wound infections. Gram staining demonstrates gram-positive bacilli with spores as shown below.

Option B: Vincent's angina is a spirochetal infection and is a differential diagnosis of a membrane in the throat. It is caused by Leptotrichia buccalis (earlier known as Fusobacterium) and is demonstrated on gram stain as gram-negative curved rods with pointed ends. They appear as fusiform and spiral shaped bacilli as shown below.

Option D: Streptococcal pharyngitis usually doesn't cause membrane formation and appear as gram positive cocci in chains as shown in image below.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A surgeon performing a radical neck dissection wants to start at the anterior triangle. Which of the following areas will she not dissect?
questions.solution:
The subclavian triangle is a posterior triangle of the neck.

Anterior triangles in the neck are:

  • Submental triangle
  • Digastric triangle
  • Muscular triangle
  • Carotid triangle

Posterior triangles in the neck are: 

  • Occipital triangle
  • Subclavian triangle 

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text:
An 18-month-old baby was brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing. According to IMNCI, what should be the respiratory rate to diagnose this baby with pneumonia?

IMNCI: Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness
questions.solution:
An 18-month-old baby presenting with fever and fast breathing should have a respiratory rate of >40 to be diagnosed with pneumonia according to IMNCI.

According to the IMNCI, three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with suspected pneumonia:

  • Respiratory rate (RR): distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. Children are classified under pneumonia if:
    • > 60 breaths per minute if age  is < 2 months 
    • > 50/min RR for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40/min RR for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing refers to the indrawing of the lower chest wall with respect to the child's breathing and indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor indicates those with severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 
Danger signs of severe pneumonia are: 
  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of frequent fainting. On detailed history taking it is noted that the girl suddenly falls off while playing, gets up immediately, and resumes her activity. She has normal behavior after such episodes. If there are no other health issues, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given is atonic seizures.

Atonic seizures are identified by a sudden loss of postural control for 1-2 seconds. There can be a brief impairment of consciousness but, there is no post-ictal confusion. Sometimes if the seizure is long-lasting, it will lead to the patient's collapse, which can cause a head injury. Atonic seizures are usually associated with known epilepsy syndromes.

Valproic acid is effective in the treatment of the condition. In refractory cases, hemispherectomy or multilobar resection is done especially when it is part of a mixed-seizure syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Absence seizures are marked by brief lapses of consciousness lasting for a few seconds. Postural control is not lost during the absence seizures. It lasts only for a few seconds and there is no post-ictal confusion. It can be associated with motor signs such as chewing movements or rapid blinking of the eyelids. Due to a lack of characteristic symptoms, it is usually noticed as daydreaming or a decline in scholastic performance.

Option C: Syncope is unlikely with the clinical features as there is no history of fatigue, lightheadedness, or visual disturbances preceding the fainting episodes. It is due to an acute impairment in the cerebral blood flow.

Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents as loss of consciousness associated with diaphoresis, tachycardia, and pallor.

questions.text: A newborn was screened for an inborn error of metabolism. Blood phenylalanine levels were elevated and urine had a mousy odor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a newborn with elevated blood levels of phenylalanine and mousy odor in urine, the most likely diagnosis is phenylketonuria.

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by elevated phenylalanine concentrations which get converted to phenylacetate, phenylpyruvate, and phenylacetate metabolites that give the urine a characteristic musty or mousy odor.

Other features such as microcephaly, developmental delay, seizures, and hypopigmentation can occur.

Newborn screening is used to diagnose the condition. It is done by dried blood spots taken from the heel and assessed using tandem mass spectroscopy (TMS).

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of synthetic amino acids and natural foods like fruits, vegetables, and cereals can be helpful. 

Other options:

Option A: Maple syrup urine disease is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to the deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). Features include feeding problems, vomiting, ketosis, and a maple syrup-like odor in the urine.

Option C: Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and plasma. Features like ectopia lentis, skeletal anomalies, and intellectual disability are seen. 

Option D: Tyrosinemia is a condition due to the deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase and is characterized by a cabbage-like odor in urine.

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

Inborn Error of Metabolism

Urine Odor

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?

choices.text: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
Most common type of anal canal carcinoma

questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cell carcinoma >Melanoma

The median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleeding per rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph node metastasis is to inguinal lymph nodes. 

Risk Factors:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection 
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression
  • Smoking
  • Anal receptive intercourse
  • Sexual promiscuity
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia
  • History of vulvar or cervical cancer

Diagnosis:

  • Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice 
  • MRI- for local staging 
  • CT scan- to evaluate for distant metastasis

Treatment :

  • Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice
  • If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is performed

8th AJCC: TNM Classification of Carcinoma of the Anal Canal and Anal Margin

Primary Tumor:
  • Tis - high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
  • T1 - 2 cm or less
  • T2 - >2 - 5 cm
  • T3 - >5 cm
  • T4 - invades adjacent organ, e.g. vagina, urethra, bladder. (invasion of the rectal wall, perirectal skin, subcutaneous tissue, or sphincter muscle is not included as T4).
Regional Nodes:

Regional lymph nodes include mesorectal, inguinal (superficial, deep), superior rectal (hemorrhoidal), external iliac, and internal iliac (hypogastric) groups.

  • N0 - no regional lymph node metastases
  • N1a - inguinal, mesorectal, or internal iliac lymph nodes
  • N1b - external iliac nodes
  • N1c - external iliac nodes + N1a

Distant Metastases:
  • M0 - no
  • M1 - yes

Stage grouping:
  • 0 - Tis
  • I - T1 N0
  • IIA - T2 N0
  • IIB - T3 N0
  • IIIA - T1-2 N1
  • IIIB - T4 N0
  • IIIC - T3-4 N1
  • IV - M1

questions.text: According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with which of the following pelvis?
questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.

The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet's shape as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

The image and features of the different types of the female pelvis are given below:

Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (more than 90°) 
Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipitoanterior or posterior  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse or oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse or oblique  Transverse

questions.text: A man is under suspicion of smuggling cocaine in his body at the local airport. He is asymptomatic and an X-ray of the abdomen was done and is shown below. The next best step in the management of this case would be:
questions.solution:
The given scenario with an X-ray showing multiple cylindrical capsules (marked as *) in the stomach and intestine is consistent with body packing. The next best step in the management of this case would be to initiate whole-bowel irrigation.

 

The X-ray reveals that the packs are largely intact and unruptured. Since he is asymptomatic, the next step in management would be to give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to hasten packet elimination gently.

Body packing involves swallowing packets of illegal drugs like heroin, cannabis, morphine, and cocaine to smuggle the same. Usually, the drugs are packed by first carefully wrapping them in latex or plastic. These are swallowed and later excreted with the help of laxatives.

Similarly, a person who smuggles these drugs by consuming or stuffing drugs in the rectum or the vagina is referred to as a body stuffer. This generally occurs due to the non-availability of time. Radiography is not as helpful in these cases. Drug toxicity may be seen in body stuffers due to systemic absorption of the drug.

Other options:

Option A: Sometimes, drugs like heroin or cocaine that have the same radiodensity as feces, may be difficult to detect on X-rays. A CT scan helps to identify the same in this scenario.

Option B: Endoscopy or colonoscopy to remove the drugs is not done because any manipulation can rupture the packets, leading to their toxicity. 

Option D: Surgery is indicated in those patients who exhibit the symptoms of toxicity due to the rupture of packets.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient in her 16th week of gestation came for prenatal karyotyping since her first child is suffering from Down's syndrome. Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: Limb reduction defect is a known complication

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is amniocentesis. Limb reduction defect is not a known complication of amniocentesis, it is a complication of chorionic villous sampling. 

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications

Congenital infections

Fetal genetic disorders

Alloimmunization

Assessment of lung maturity
Complications

Fetal loss

Amniotic fluid leakage

Transvaginal spotting

 

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A veterinarian presents with symptoms of myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever for the past 10 days. On examination, he had non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Sabin-Feldman dye test was positive. Identify the parasite responsible for these findings in the patient.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a veterinarian presenting with myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a positive Sabin Feldman dye test is indicative of toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular coccidian parasite and is the causative agent of toxoplasmosis. Its definitive hosts are cats and other felines while humans are intermediate hosts.

The life cycle of toxoplasma gondii is shown below.

Humans acquire the infection upon consumption of meat containing tissue cysts, food or water containing mature oocysts, or fingers contaminated by cat feces.

Infection can also be transmitted from the mother to the fetus or from an infected donor to the recipient subsequent to a blood transfusion or organ transplantation.

Manifestations are mostly asymptomatic and if symptomatic can be congenital or acquired. Features such as fever, headache, myalgia, splenomegaly, and lymphade­nopathy commonly affect the cervical lymph nodes.

Central nervous system involvement is observed in toxoplasma infection affecting immunocompromised individuals. Toxoplasma infection in pregnancy can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis that most frequently presents with chorioretinitis. Chorioretinitis can also present in ocular toxoplasmosis.

Trophozoites and tissue cysts can be detected in tissue and body fluids. The tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. 

The Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of IgG antibodies against toxoplasma. It is based on the presence of antibodies that lyse the parasite membrane and hence prevent methylene blue dye from staining the cytoplasm of trophozoites (tachyzoites). If there are no antibodies, trophozoites with an intact membrane are stained and appear blue under the microscope, indicative of a negative result.

A false-positive test is seen in infection with Sarcocystis, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Trypanosoma Lewisi. Other tests done include indirect fluorescent antibody test, latex agglutination test, and ELISA, the latter of which can measure circulating IgG antibodies to Toxoplasma.

MRI and CT are used to diagnose toxoplasmosis with CNS involvement.

Other options:

Option A: In Leishmania infection, Montenegro test/Leishmanin test is positive. It is a skin test based on delayed hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from cultured Leishmania. Features include high-grade fever, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.

Option B: In Echinococcus infection, Casoni’s test is done. It is a skin test based on immediate hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from hydatid fluid. It is positive in hydatid disease. The typical features are hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice. If lungs are involved, cough and hemoptysis can be present.

Option C: Is Schistosoma infection, Fairley's test is done. It is a skin test that is group-specific to all schistosomiasis. Manifestations include skin rash, anaphylaxis in acute stages. It can be associated with bladder carcinoma and infections in chronic stages.
