questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female patient presents with severe abdominal pain. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present over the right hypochondrium and epigastrium. Her erect X-ray of the abdomen is given below. What would be the histopathological section of the affected organ show?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image of the porcelain gall bladder are suggestive of chronic cholecystitis. The histopathology of the affected organ would be showing dystrophic calcifications of the gall bladder.

The porcelain gall bladder is a morphological feature seen in chronic cholecystitis and is characterized by dystrophic calcification. It is a pathologic calcification in which calcium gets deposited at the sites of cell injury and necrosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are the outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall seen in chronic cholecystitis. They can rupture and develop into xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis.

Option B: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is characterized by xanthoma cells. These are macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids. In this condition, the gallbladder is shrunken, nodular, and has thickened walls. 

Option D: Hydrops of the gallbladder is characterized by clear secretions within an atrophic, obstructed, and dilated gall bladder.

The below image shows Rokitansky–Aschoff's sinus.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a daily fever for the last 2 months. She has not been playful during the daytime but appears to get better in the evening. The girl also complains of wrist and knee pain for the last two months which worsens with movements. There is a faint salmon-pink rash on the trunk. Below is the lab report. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

TLC - 15,000 cells/cu.mm 

ESR - 40 mm/hr
questions.solution:
A young child with pain in the joints, daily fever spike that reduces spontaneously, salmon-pink rash on the trunks, and elevated ESR and WBC count is likely suggestive of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Systemic JIA - Arthritis in ≥1 joint + fever of at least 2 weeks in duration that is documented to be daily (quotidian fever) for at least 3 days and accompanied by ≥1 of the following:

  • Evanescent (nonfixed) maculopapular truncal rash
  • Generalized lymph node enlargement
  • Hepatomegaly or splenomegaly or both
  • Serositis

JIA is defined as arthritis in ≥1 joint with onset <16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks. It can be classified as systemic, oligoarthritis, polyarthritis with rheumatoid factor (RF) positive or negative, psoriatic arthritis, and enthesitis-related arthritis.

  • Chronic arthritis ≥6 weeks and age of onset ≤16 years is essential for the diagnosis of JIA
  • Oligoarthritis JIA - ≤4 joints involved
  • Polyarthritis JIA -  ≥5 joints involved
    • RF positive - Symmetric involvement is seen in >8 years of age 
    • RF negative - Asymmetric involvement is seen in <8 years of age
  • Psoriatic JIA - Features of psoriasis and any 2 of the following
    • Dactylitis
    • Pitting of nails
    • 1st degree relative with psoriasis
  • Enthesitis-related JIA - Arthritis + Enthesitis
    • HLA-B27 positive

Treatment options include NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) for symptomatic management and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as methotrexate. DMARDs should be started in all children with polyarthritis. Systemic glucocorticoids are usually reserved for children with severe unremitting arthritis, systemic manifestations (serositis, vasculitis), and rapidly progressive disease.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis undergoes a CT abdomen and pelvis as shown below. All the following are true about his likely condition except.

choices.text: They are associated with multiple cysts
They are prone to reflux and obstruction
They are associated with Turner's syndrome

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the CT image are suggestive of a horseshoe kidney. It is not associated with multiple cysts. 

Multiple cysts are seen in polycystic kidney disease, a genetic condition that can be autosomal dominant or recessive. 

Horseshoe kidneys are a type of renal fusion anomaly. They are formed when the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse during organogenesis to form an isthmus. They are typically low lying as the inferior mesenteric artery interferes with its ascent due to its size and presence of an isthmus. 

It has a 2:1 male preponderance. Horseshoe kidneys are present in 30% of individuals with Turner's syndrome.

Individuals with horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

The CT image below depicts the fused poles in the horseshoe kidney.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A patient developed generalized pruritis and swelling of the face, lips, and tongue after having dinner at a new restaurant. He also complained of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.solution:
This is an example of an IgE-mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. It is also known as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. IgE immunoglobulin is the only heat-labile antibody.

The primary mediators of type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

IgE:

  • Half-life: 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat-labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.
  • It does not pass the placental barrier or fix complement.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presented with a diminution of vision and was diagnosed to have a moderate visual impairment. According to NPCBVI, this condition is defined as:

NPCBVI: National program for control of blindness and visual impairment

choices.text: Visual acuity < 6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity < 3/60 in the better eye with available correction

questions.solution:
As per the NPCBVI guidelines, moderate visual impairment is defined as the visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with correction. 

Refractive error is the main cause of visual impairment in ages 0-49 years followed by cataracts, amblyopia and corneal opacity. However, in the age group >50 years, cataract is the major cause followed by refractive errors and surgical complications of cataract. 

Definitions of blindness and visual impairment as per NPCBVI: 

Blindness Presenting visual acuity < 3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Early visual impairment (EVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with available correction
Moderate visual impairment (MVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with available correction
Moderate severe visual impairment (MSVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/18-3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Severe visual impairment (SVI) Presenting visual acuity < 6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Functional low vision

The visual functioning is impaired even after standard refractive correction.

Visual acuity <6/18 to light perception or

a visual field of fewer than 10 degrees from the point of fixation in people able to use the vision for planning and execution of tasks.
Blindness(BCVA/Pinhole <3/60)  Best-corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye

Cataract was the principal cause of blindness, severe visual impairment, and moderate visual impairment followed by corneal opacity, cataract surgical complications, posterior segment disorders and glaucoma.

For early visual impairment, the most important cause is a refractive error. Principal causes of severe visual impairment other than cataracts were cataract surgical complications and other posterior segment diseases.

questions.text: You are a psychiatry junior resident who is called to the medicine ward to assess a 68-year-old woman for suspected signs of delirium. You proceed to evaluate for delirium using the confusion assessment method. The presence of which of the following is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected of delirium, the confusion assessment method (CAM) diagnostic algorithm can be used as a screening tool. The presence of signs of psychomotor activity is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is used as a screening tool and the diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of:

  • Acute onset and fluctuating course (Options A & D), 
  • Inattention (Option C), and
  • either disorganized thinking or an altered level of consciousness

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Delirium, a life-threatening but reversible CNS disorder, is characterized by an acute decline in the level of consciousness and global impairment of cognitive functions. It has an acute onset (hours to days) and prodromal symptoms like restlessness and fearfulness can be seen. with a fluctuating course. The episodes are usually brief lasting from days to weeks and follow a fluctuating course.

The hallmark feature is a decline in the level of consciousness, particularly altered attention. It is accompanied by impairment in cognitive function manifesting as disorientation and decreased memory. Abnormalities of mood, perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations, and behavioral abnormalities are common psychiatric manifestations. 

Abnormal psychomotor activity is also seen, although it is not used during assessment via the Confusion Assessment Method (CAM). Other clinical features include sleep cycle impairment, worsening of symptoms at night (sundowning), and neurological manifestations like autonomic instability.

The major neuroanatomical area and the major neurotransmitter hypothesized are the reticular formation and acetylcholine, respectively. The precipitating factors include drugs like sedatives-hypnotics and narcotics, neurological diseases like meningitis and stroke, intercurrent illnesses like infections and hypoxia, environmental stressors, and major surgeries.

Delirium is a clinical diagnosis and screening tools like CAM are used for it. The primary goal of treatment is to identify the underlying cause and rapid improvement can be seen once it is eliminated. Management requires prompt supportive care. Antipsychotics like haloperidol, for managing psychotic symptoms, and short-acting benzodiazepines like lorazepam, for managing insomnia, may be required. Delirium is associated with high morbidity, and thus, the predisposing and precipitating factors should be identified to prevent an episode of delirium.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their causative agents:

   I. Pinta

  A. Treponema pertenue

   II. Lymphogranuloma venereum   

   B. Klebsiella granulomatis

   III. Yaws

   C. Chlamydia trachomatis

   IV. Granuloma inguinale

   D. Treponema carateum
questions.solution:
The causative organisms of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Organism
Pinta Treponema carateum
Lymphogranuloma venereum Chlamydia trachomatis
Yaws Treponema pertenue
Granuloma inguinale Klebsiella granulomatis 

India is the first country in the world to be officially acknowledged as being yaws-free. The WHO declared India free of yaws on 5th May 2016.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with palpitations and a heart rate of 150/minute. An ECG is done which is shown below. If the blood pressure is normal, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
The ECG showing sawtooth flutter waves along with the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of atrial flutter. The next best step is to administer an intravenous (IV) beta-blocker for rate control as the patient is hemodynamically stable.

The initial management of atrial flutter targets rate control through IV atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking agents. These include beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCB) such as verapamil and diltiazem. Intravenous ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic agent can be used for rhythm control.

If the patient presents with severe symptoms or is hemodynamically unstable, electrical cardioversion is the first step. If the episode duration is > 48 hours, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHAD2DS2 -VASc scoring system, anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion. The drugs which can be used are direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) such as apixaban, edoxaban, and rivaroxaban. Dabigatran, an antithrombin inhibitor, and warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist can also be used. 

The first episode does not warrant the continuation of antiarrhythmic drugs after conversion to sinus rhythm. In recurrent episodes, sotalol or amiodarone may be used.

At least 4 weeks of anticoagulation therapy is carried out after electrical or chemical cardioversion, as done in atrial fibrillation. Patients with risk factors for thromboembolism should continue it for longer. The definitive treatment is catheter ablation for recurrent cases.

The ECG shows characteristic sawtooth flutter waves due to the atrial activity in the inferior leads ( leads II, III, and aVF). Positive P waves are seen in lead V1. Conduction of more than 230 impulses/ minute through the AV node is not possible in adults. Hence a 2:1 or greater AV block is almost always associated. So patients present with tachycardia of 130-150 beats/minute. Typically, the atrial rate is around 240-300/minute.

Atrial flutter is more commonly seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or structural heart disease. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Congenital zikavirus infection causes microcephaly, not macrocephaly. 

Zikavirus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, sexual and blood-borne transmission is also observed. Humans are the only reservoir. Vertical transmission from an infected mother can occur throughout gestation and commonly results in fetal death. Other complications include neural tube defects, sensorineural deafness, microcephaly, and ocular abnormalities.

Affected adults present with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, and rash, similar to dengue fever. Non-purulent conjunctivitis and palatal petechiae may also be seen. Complications though rare include Guillain-Barre syndrome, leukopenia, encephalitis, and thrombocytopenic purpura. It can persist in the testes for up to 160 days, making sexual transmission possible during this period.

It is diagnosed by RT-PCR which detects viral RNA. There are no curative or preventive antivirals or licensed vaccines available as of yet.

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic man presents with complaints of pain and swelling over his left middle finger, which appears as below. The digital pressure test is positive. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a positive digital pressure test and the image showing erythema and swelling around the nail folds is suggestive of acute paronychia with abscess. Abscess in paronychia requires immediate incision and drainage.

Paronychia refers to an infection of the proximal, lateral nail folds. It results from the disruption of the protective barrier between the nail and the nail fold, introducing pathogens and predisposing the area to infection. Paronychia is more common in women than in men. It can be acute if it lasts less than six weeks or chronic if it lasts for more than six weeks.

In addition to infectious causes, papulosquamous disorders like psoriasis and pemphigus also can cause paronychia.

Certain factors that predispose to paronychia include

  • Certain occupations like dishwasher, bartender, housekeeper
  • Certain medications like retinoids, protease inhibitors
  • Immunosuppressive states like diabetes, HIV, malignancy

Paronychia is diagnosed based on clinical presentation. Clinical features vary with respect to the presentation.

Acute paronychia:

  • Erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold
  • Area of fluctuance if an abscess is present - positive digital pressure test

A digital pressure test is used to assess if an abscess is present or not. Pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the involved digit. A larger than expected area of blanching will be visible at the paronychia if an abscess is present and drainage will be needed.

The image below shows acute paronychia of a fingernail.

Chronic paronychia:

  • Nail fold may be red, swollen or boggy
  • Nail plate may be thickened and discolored
  • Retraction of the proximal nail fold
  • Nail dystrophy
  • Loss of the cuticle
  • Fluctuance is rare on digital pressure test

Management involves:

  • Non-pharmacological measures like:
    • Patients should keep their hands dry and warm
    • Wear gloves for any recurrent contact with water, chemicals, and irritants
    • Avoid trauma to the hands as much as possible
    • Avoid nail-biting or manicuring nail folds until complete recovery
    • Warm soaks using antiseptics or antibiotic solutions for 10 to 15 minutes, multiple times a day.
  • Antibiotic coverage depends on the type of paronychia.
    • Acute paronychia: Since acute paronychias are mostly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, adequate coverage is required in the form of:
      • Topical antibiotics: Triple antibiotic ointment, bacitracin, or mupirocin
      • Oral antibiotics:
        • Dicloxacillin 250 mg four times a day
        • Cephalexin 500 mg three to four times a day
      • If suspecting MRSA:
        • Clindamycin 300 to 450 mg four times a day
        • Doxycycline 100 mg twice a day
    • Anaerobic coverage requires the addition of clindamycin or amoxicillin-clavulanate, in cases of suspected oral inoculation.
    • Chronic paronychia: Topical and systemic antifungal agents such as itraconazole and terbinafine are used to cover Candida species.
    • Topical tacrolimus ointment is effective in case of allergic and atopic contact dermatitis causing chronic paronychia
  • Presence of abscess warrants immediate incision and drainage under local/digital block. Partial or complete nail plate removal may be needed.
  • Surgical management of chronic paronychia involves procedures like:
    • Eponychial marsupialization: A crescent-shaped incision parallel to the distal edge of eponychium, exteriorizes the infected and obstructed nail matrix and allows its drainage.
    • En-bloc excision of the proximal nail fold
    • Swiss roll technique: Nail fold is elevated proximally over a non-adherent dressing, rolled up, and secured with the application of sutures and dressing. After 48 hours, if the wound is clean, the sutures are removed and the nail fold is brought to the original position by secondary intention. This exposure of the nail bed allows the drainage of any residual infection.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was administered thiopental for induction before a surgical procedure. Induction is faster with thiopental in all of the following, except _______.
questions.solution:
Induction is faster with thiopental in all of the options, except alkalosis.

The rapidity of induction of thiopental is based on how fast it gets redistributed. This depends on the lipid solubility and a higher nonionized fraction of the barbiturates in the blood.

Increased non-ionized fraction as in case of acidosis, contracted central compartment as seen in hypovolemic shock (option D), and low serum albumin as in severe malnutrition or liver disease (option B and C) thus favors rapid induction. 

Thiopental is a barbiturate used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset of action within 15-30 seconds and smooth induction. It is also used to maintain general anesthesia. The dosage is 3-4 mg/kg.

questions.text: A runway model was presented with anemia, swollen parotid glands, and low BMI. Her husband says that she does not eat well and is always worried about gaining weight. Which of the following is the most common psychiatric comorbidity that you would expect to find in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common psychiatric comorbidity to expect in this patient with anorexia nervosa is depression. 

Anorexia nervosa is a disease characterized by self-induced starvation, fear of gaining weight, and uncontrolled wish to become thin. It is divided into:

  • Restrictive: Losing weight by reducing the food intake.
  • Binge/purge: Losing weight by purging after binge eating along with diet. 

It is commonly seen associated with depression, social phobia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and mania. Depression is the most common psychiatric comorbidity in these patients. Other features seen are swollen parotid glands, anemia, dehydration, etc.

Patients with a weight 20% less than expected weight for height should be considered for hospitalization. Psychotherapy consists of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy. Pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment but cypro­heptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorproma­zine show some improvement in these patients.

Other options:

Option B: Social phobia is the fear of being embarrassed or humiliated in front of others. Anxiety disorders, mood disorders, substance-related disorders, and bulimia nervosa are the other comorbidities seen. 

Option C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) includes intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and compulsions which cause distress to the patient. Depression is the most common comorbidity seen. The frequency of presenting patterns of OCD is an obsession with contamination > pathological doubt > aggressive or sexual act >need for symmetry. Management includes CBT and SSRIs. 

Option D: Panic disorder is a feeling of sudden intense fear when there is nothing to fear. Social phobia, generalized anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, OCD etc are the other comorbidities seen.

questions.text:
A woman presents to you with a feeling of heaviness of her head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. On investigating further, her serum ALP levels are raised and the following radiographic changes are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?

ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, dull headache throughout the day, raised serum ALP levels, and the radiograph showing Tam o' Shanter sign are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Paget's bone disease (PBD) is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. It is usually asymptomatic but can present with a dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. Serum ALP levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4-5 mg.

Radiographic features: 

  • The early phase features the osteolytic (lucent) region which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement.
  • Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. 
  • Osteoporosis circumscripta is seen as a large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance  is seen as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion of the skull
  • Tam o'Shanter sign is frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones.
  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 

The image below shows the cotton-wool appearance of the skull seen in Paget's disease:

The image below shows Tam O Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph:

The arrow mark in the image given below depicts the 'blade of grass'/Flame shaped lesion.

The image given below depicts a picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.

The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is characterised by increased circulating parathyroid hormone levels. There is osteoclastic hyperactivity resulting in hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis and chondrocalcinosis. Typical features in radiology include subperiosteal cortical resorption and osteoporosis. 

Option C: Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy occurring in the bone and is characterised by the presence of punched-out osteolytic lesions resulting in a pepper pot appearance of the axial skeleton.

Option D: Osteomyelitis refers to the infection of the bone more commonly starting in the trabeculae. Radiographic features include periosteal new bone formation around the second week of infection which later progresses to periosteal thickening.

questions.text: A child was in the postoperative ward following a tonsillectomy. Pain needs to be assessed and the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) for rating postoperative pain was used. It includes all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) includes all the options, except oxygen saturation.

CHEOPS is a behavioral scale used to measure postoperative pain in young children. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of interventions to reduce pain and discomfort.

It measures crying, facial expression, body position (torso), verbal expression, touch position, and leg position.

Other pain assessment scales in children include:

  • Oucher face scale
  • Visual analog scale (VAS)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent blood in the urine and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. CT shows a renal tumor. A radical nephrectomy was performed and the histology of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and histology specimen showing round or polygonal tumor cells with clear cytoplasm is suggestive of clear cell carcinoma. 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma. The growth pattern of clear cell carcinomas varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular. Cells are round or polygonal in shape. The cytoplasm is clear or granular and it contains glycogen and lipid.

Clear cell carcinoma mostly arises from the proximal tubular epithelium. It is associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3. The VHL gene (tumor suppressor gene) is located on chromosome 3p.

Clear cell carcinomas are usually single and unilateral. They are spherical masses that vary in size. Composed of yellow-colored tissue that distorts the renal outline. The yellow color is due to the accumulation of lipids in tumor cells.

The most common risk factors of renal cell carcinoma are tobacco usage, obesity, hypertension, and unopposed estrogen therapy. 

Other options:

Option A- Chromophobe carcinoma arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Tumor cells have pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with a halo around the nucleus and prominent cell membranes as shown below.

Option B- Papillary carcinoma arises from distal convoluted tubules. They can be multifocal and bilateral. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities associated are trisomies 7, 17 and loss of Y. Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option D- Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla. They show irregular channels lined by atypical epithelium with a hobnail pattern as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man sustained a traumatic head injury. The following image was taken after he was asked to look straight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is right 6th nerve palsy as the image shows esotropia and a limitation of abduction of the right eye. 

The 6th cranial nerve or abducens nerve supplies the lateral rectus muscle which is an abductor of the eye. Its lesion cause esotropia due to the unopposed action of the medial rectus.  The 3rd cranial nerve or oculomotor nerve supplies the medial rectus which is an adductor of the eye.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is asked to look left, the lesion would be in the left eye. The left lateral rectus would be affected due to a left abducens nerve palsy.

Other options: 

Option A: 3rd or oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris, abduction and depression in the primary position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique). Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to medial rectus, superior rectus and inferior oblique weakness. Pupil will be dilated pupil with defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Option B: 4th or trochlear nerve supplies the superior oblique muscle and its palsy causes hypertropia, limited depression and extorsion of the affected eye. 

Option D: Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion in the parapontine reticular formation. This leads to ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus weakness. It is characterized by the inability to look in the direction of the lesion.

questions.text: An IV urogram of a child who presented with recurrent urinary tract infection is shown below. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: The upper pole ureter inserts superolaterally in the bladder
The lower pole ureter may lead to vesicoureteral reflux
The upper pole ureter is usually obstructed
The lower pole ureter inserts into the bladder through a shorter submucosal tunnel

questions.solution:
The given scenario with the image of the intravenous urogram showing the "drooping lily" sign is suggestive of a completely duplicated collecting system. According to Weigert Meyer's rule of complete duplication of the ureter, the ureter draining from the upper pole of the kidney enters the bladder medial and inferior to the ureter draining from the lower pole.

This is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract which occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

There are 2 types of duplication:

  1. Incomplete- Y ureter arises when the ureteric bud bifurcates after its initial development from the mesonephric duct
  2. Complete- 2 separate ureteric buds. One is at normal while the second one is at a lower position. The lower pole ureter is associated with vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) due to its insertion into the bladder through a short submucosal tunnel. The upper pole ureter commonly gets in obstructed resulting in scarring.

Often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. If the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and it looks like a drooping lily. 

The condition is asymptomatic in adults while children have VUR. Females are more commonly affected. Voiding is normal but prolonged dribbling of urine is seen.

According to Weigart Meyer's rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter:

  • The ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney (Weigert–Meyer rule). The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 
  • In case of an incomplete duplication, there is only one ureteric orifice on that side of the bladder.

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty. Other options include a partial or complete nephrectomy.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 45-year-old overweight man who is being treated for hypertension presents to you with complaints of snoring and episodic gasping during sleep. He also gives a history of fatigue, morning headaches, and daytime somnolence. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Overnight polysomnography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome which is described here.

Obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome is a debilitating condition seen commonly among males of older age, with a sedentary lifestyle. Other risk factors include obesity, family history, mandibular deformities, and hypothyroidism. It is also associated with hypertension and diabetes. Usually, there is a decline in neuromuscular output to pharyngeal dilator muscles during sleep. In predisposed individuals, this results in complete (apnea) or partial (hypopnea) pharyngeal collapse.

They present with symptoms such as snoring, gasping, and snorting during sleep. Other features include daytime sleepiness, morning headaches, and fatigue. Five or more episodes of apnea/ hypopnea per hour of sleep determined by a sleep study such as an overnight polysomnogram is a requirement for diagnosis. Such sleep studies, usually measure breathing, oxygenation, the position of the body, and cardiac rhythm. 

A polysomnogram helps to quantify sleep latency, sleep efficiency, and the time spent in each sleep stage. A negative test rules out obstructive sleep apnea. Management includes lifestyle modifications, treatment of exacerbating comorbidities, and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

Syndrome Z is used to describe the interaction between obstructive sleep apnea and the components of metabolic syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Electroencephalography is a study used to assess the electrical activity of the brain. It is used in the diagnosis and management of seizure disorders. It is also a component of sleep studies. 

Option B: Chin electromyography can be used to assess sleep cycle and continuity. 

Option D: Actigraphy used a device known as an actigraph worn on the wrist as a rough measure of the sleep-wake cycle. It can be used to assess insomnia, movement disorders, and circadian rhythm disorders. 

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Causes of Secondary Hypertension

Renal parenchymal

Glomerulonephritis, renal cysts, renal tumors

Renovascular

Renal artery stenosis, arteriosclerotic, fibromuscular dysplasia

Adrenal

Primary aldosteronism, Cushing’s syndrome, pheochromocytoma

Aortic coarctation

 

Obstructive sleep apnea

  

Pre-eclampsia/ eclampsia

 

Neurogenic

Psychogenic, polyneuritis (acute porphyria, lead poisoning), acute increased ICP, acute spinal cord section

Endocrine

Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, hypercalcemia, acromegaly

Medications

High-dose estrogens, adrenal steroids, appetite suppressants, cyclosporine, tricyclic antidepressants, MAO inhibitors, NSAIDS

Mendelian forms

Liddle’s syndrome, Gordon’s syndrome, MEN 2A & 2B

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of new-onset left-sided chest pain. He had a recent history of a viral infection. ECG showed diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and echocardiography detected a pericardial effusion. What is the finding that can be seen on the chest radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pericardial effusion as a result of acute pericarditis. The chest radiograph may show a water-bottle configuration due to enlargement of the cardiac silhouette because of the pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible.

Echocardiography is a widely used imaging technique that allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid.

The chest X-ray shows an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette- water-bottle configuration. It may be normal in small effusions. The lateral radiograph may show the oreo cookie sign. It is a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line (paracardial fat) directly behind the sternum anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. 

CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or if there is pericardial thickening.

A water bottle configuration on a chest X-ray is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: A boot-shaped heart is seen in patients with Tetrology of Fallot. It refers to the appearance of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy. 

Option C: Batwing appearance is seen in pulmonary edema. It refers to the appearance of perihilar consolidation.

Option D: The figure 3 sign is seen in the aortic coarctation. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and indentation of the left subclavian artery at the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text: A young man experiences a sudden onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain. Which of the following physiological factors has no role in this condition?

choices.text: Altered permeability of blood brain barrier
Release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum
Increase in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of sudden onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain suggests high-altitude cerebral edema. Calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum has no role in high-altitude cerebral edema.

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and fluid through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

  • Mechanical factors- loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).
  • Increased chemical mediators of permeability- vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), nitric oxide, and cytokines (options A and C).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with headache, and papilledema leading to a blurring of vision, breathlessness (due to hypoxia), nausea, and vomiting

Treatment involves the administration of oxygen and descent to a lower altitude. Nifedipine can be given as adjunct therapy.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A 9-year-old child was evaluated for night blindness.  Ophthalmoscopy showed atrophic changes in the choroid, retina, and pigment epithelium. Urine and plasma ornithine levels were elevated. Defective catabolism of which of the following amino acids led to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of essential/ gyrate atrophy of the choroid. This is due to the defective catabolism of arginine.

Catabolism of arginine involves the conversion of arginine to ornithine, followed by the transamination of ornithine to glutamate-γ-semialdehyde by ornithine δ-aminotransferase. Mutations in ornithine δ-aminotransferase cause elevated plasma and urinary ornithine levels which leads to gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina.

It usually manifests in early adulthood. The patient may present with night blindness and progressive visual field constriction. 

Treatment involves restricting dietary arginine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a histone deacetylase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of cutaneous T - cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Vorinostat is a histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of cutaneous T - cell lymphoma. 

It is indicated for use in patients with cutaneous T - cell lymphoma who have progressive, persistent, or recurrent disease on or following two systemic therapies.

HDAC are enzymes that catalyze deacetylation reactions of acetylated lysine amino acids in histones leading to the transcriptional activation of cellular genes.  

Overexpression of HDAC can be found in some cancers. Thus HDAC inhibitors can cause differentiation with the emergence of a more normal cellular phenotype or cause cell cycle arrest with an expression of endogenous regulators of cell cycle progression. Romidepsin is also an HDAC  inhibitor that can be used to treat cutaneous or peripheral T - cell lymphoma. 

Other options:

Option A: Panobinostat is an HDAC inhibitor that is indicated for the treatment of patients with multiple myeloma who have received at least 2 prior regimens, including bortezomib and an immunomodulatory agent.

Option B: Alemtuzumab is a CD52-directed cytolytic monoclonal antibody indicated for the treatment of patients with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis and for treating B-cell CLL.

Option C: Denileukin difitox is a CD25-directed cytotoxin indicated for the treatment of patients with persistent or recurrent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma whose malignant cells express the CD25 component of the IL-2 receptor. It is a fusion protein of diphtheria toxin which inhibits protein synthesis. It is commercially unavailable at present.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with palpitations.  ECG shows a short PR interval and slurred QRS complexes as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome based on the clinical features and ECG showing the characteristic delta-wave. 

Short PR intervals and wide QRS complexes with delta waves (slurred and slow initial upstroke) are diagnostic ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

 

In this syndrome, there is an abnormal conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles called the bundle of Kent. Compared to the atrioventricular (AV) node, electrical conduction is faster through the accessory pathway. This setup facilitates the circus movement of electrical impulses. 

 

Treatment for WPW includes:

  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs from classes Ia (procainamide)and class III (ibutilide).
  • Electrical cardioversion if the patient is hemodynamically unstable
  • Radiofrequency ablation of the aberrant pathway (definitive treatment)

Other options:

Option A: AV nodal re-entry tachycardia (AVNRT) is due to a reentrant mechanism through multiple pathways connecting the atrium and AV node. The P wave is usually not seen, but sometimes appears as a pseudo-r' in lead V1 (black arrow) and pseudo-S waves in leads II, III, and aVF (blue arrows). Narrow QRS complexes (green arrows) are seen. It is the most common paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia for which vagal maneuvers such as the Valsalva maneuver and carotid sinus massage can be tried.

 

Option B: Junctional tachycardia, commonly seen in children with congenital heart diseases. It arises due to automaticity in the AV node. ECG shows narrow QRS complexes. 

Option D: In atrial flutter, sawtooth flutter waves are seen in leads II, III, and aVF with an atrial rate of 240-300 beats per minute. The condition is often associated with a 2:1 AV block and narrow QRS complexes.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 3-year-old child develops these lesions over his face. How would you describe these lesions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows skin lesions characteristically appearing as shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a pox virus. The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen. It refers to dermatosis resulting from the spread of an infective agent. 

On microscopic examination, cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and molluscum bodies are seen. They are large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum. It is seen below.

 

Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid or curettage, and expression.

Related Pearl: Shapes of skin lesions

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: A man comes to the emergency with a 0.5 cm deep clean lacerated wound on his forearm.  The suture technique shown below was used to close the wound. What should be the ideal distance between 2 consecutive sutures in this method?
questions.solution:
The above image shows simple interrupted sutures. While using this method, if 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the bite distance on each side of the incision must be 'x', while the distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. Therefore, the distance between two consecutive sutures in this patient would be 2 * depth of the wound = 2 * 0.5 cm = 1 cm.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should enter and exit at right angles. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid enlargement of the needle holes.

The image below shows the interrupted suturing technique.

Other commonly used suturing techniques include:

Mattress sutures - can either be vertical or horizontal. The initial suture is inserted as in an interrupted suture. The needle can then be moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound once again.

The image below shows horizontal and vertical mattress sutures.

Continuous sutures - the first suture is inserted similar to an interrupted suture. The rest of the sutures are made in a continuous manner till the other end of the wound. 

The continuous suturing technique is shown below.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who was in preterm labor was infused with an oxytocin receptor antagonist. Which of the following drugs was she likely administered?
questions.solution:
The oxytocin receptor antagonist that would have likely been administered to her is the tocolytic atosiban.

Tocolytics are drugs that suppress uterine contractions of preterm labor. Atosiban acts as an oxytocin receptor antagonist and inhibits preterm labor at 24-33 weeks of gestation.

Tocolytics can be effective only if administered before cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm and the lower uterine segment is taken up minimally. Other tocolytics that are used to delay premature labor:

  • Beta-2 agonists - ritodrine, terbutaline, isoxsuprine
  • Calcium channel blockers - nifedipine
  • Magnesium sulfate - It is a tocolytic as well as a first-line drug that is used in pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. 
  • Indomethacin

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of self-biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: A patient with a pituitary tumor has increased levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). This leads to the excess synthesis of thyroid hormones. Which of the following proteins is upregulated by the TSH to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells?
questions.solution:
The TSH upregulates the Na-I symporter (sodium-iodide symporter) to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells.

Na-I symporter (NIS) is the protein on the basolateral membrane of thyrocytes facing the capillaries. It mediates the entry of iodide into thyrocytes through secondary active transport. It transports two ions of sodium and one ion of iodine in the same direction (symporter) utilizing energy from the Na, K ATPase pump. TSH controls both the expression and retention of NIS in the basolateral membrane.

It is responsible for the uptake of iodide in the thyroid, salivary, mammary, gastric, and intestinal glands. It is regulated transcriptionally by the action of TSH.

The absence of NIS is implicated in causing congenital hypothyroidism. NIS is also upregulated in some thyroid cancers like papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This is used in the targeted treatment of thyroid cancers using therapeutic doses of radioiodine, which will be accumulated into cancer cells because of NIS.

Iodide exit from thyrocytes into colloid occurs on the apical surface and is mediated via Cl-I exchanger. It is also known as pendrin. A defect in this protein is associated with Pendred syndrome (thyroid dysfunction and deafness).

The image given below shows the steps involved in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with complaints of fatigue and diarrhea. Physical examination shows pallor and peripheral neuropathy. Laboratory findings reveal increased levels of methylmalonic acid and homocysteine. A peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented granulocytes. Which of the following is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Antibodies to intrinsic factor are not specific

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pernicious anemia. Antibodies to intrinsic factors are specific in this condition. 

Pernicious anemia is a type of vitamin B12 deficiency anemia that occurs mainly due to impaired absorption of vitamin B12.  

It is mainly seen in older age at around 60 years and has an association with autoimmune conditions such as autoimmune thyroiditis and autoimmune adrenalitis. 

The main clinical features in more severe cases are those of anemia. Anorexia is usually marked, and there may be weight loss and diarrhea due to malabsorption. Glossitis, angular cheilosis, jaundice (unconjugated), and reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation may also occur. The neurological presentation includes paraparesis, sensory ataxia, and paraesthesia in the lower limbs. 

Diagnosis is based on the following:

  • moderate to severe anemia
  • leukopenia with hypersegmented granulocytes
  • low serum vitamin B12
  • increased levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid

The stomach shows chronic gastritis that is diffuse. The most characteristic feature is atrophy of the fundic glands, which affects the parietal cells and chief cells. Mucus-secreting goblet cells that resemble those lining the large intestine replace the glandular epithelium of the stomach. This is known as intestinalization. There is an increased risk of gastric carcinoma.

Serum antibodies to intrinsic factors are particular for pernicious anemia. Neurological features can be reversed by oral or parenteral vitamin B12 administration. The risk of gastric carcinoma cannot be reversed with vitamin B12 administration.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. The fundoscopic examination picture shows a Hollenhorst plaque as in the image given below.  What is the composition of this plaque?
questions.solution:
A Hollenhorst plaque is composed of cholesterol. The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with the presence of a Hollenhorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Retinal artery occlusion can occur due to emboli from the carotids, atherosclerosis-related thrombosis, retinal arteritis, raised intraocular pressure, etc. Emboli are the most common cause. They may be:

  • Cholestrol emboli or Hollenhorst plaque- at retinal vessel bifurcation, from carotid artery atheromas
  • Calcium emboli from cardiac valves
  • Platelet fibrin emboli from carotid atheromas

Patients present with sudden painless loss of vision and may have a past history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax). On examination, visual acuity is diminished, and the pupillary reflex is lost. On funduscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Narrowed retinal arteries and veins
  • Milky white appearance of the retina due to edema
  • Cherry red spot at the center of the macula
  • Cattle trucking or segmentation of blood column in the retinal veins

CRAO is treated with immediate lowering of intraocular pressure, intermittent ocular massage, iv mannitol, and iv acetazolamide. Vasodilators like nitroglycerine and oral isosorbide dinitrate are helpful. Steroids for arteritis, fibrinolytic therapy, and laser photodiruption of the embolus may be done.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

questions.text: A man presents with tingling of lips and mouth, abdominal discomfort, nausea, and flushing. He gives a history of eating a mackerel fish about an hour back and that it had an unusually metallic taste. He responds well to treatment with intravenous antihistamines. Which of the following is not a causative organism for this form of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is not a causative agent of this type of poisoning. The given clinical vignette of a man presenting with the above symptoms after eating improperly stored mackerel or scombroid fish, with symptoms subsiding on treatment with intravenous antihistamines is indicative of histamine or scombroid fish poisoning.

It is caused due to consumption of fish (mackerel, tuna, etc) that is not preserved or refrigerated adequately. This results in the formation of histamine, histamine phosphate, and histamine hydrochloride by the following bacteria Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Proteus species. The affected fish may have a normal look and flavor, or it can have a strong metallic and peppery taste.

Symptoms usually develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. In mild cases, patients exhibit symptoms like tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. In severe cases, there is flushing of the face, neck, and upper trunk with pruritis. If the patient is not treated promptly, complications like bronchospasm, diarrhea, hypotension, and cardiogenic shock may occur.

Treatment is directed at reversing the effect of histamine with systemic antihistamines.

Staphylococcal food poisoning manifests as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea about 2-6 hours after consuming food that is contaminated by a preformed staphylococcal enterotoxin. Common sources of food are poultry, potato, egg salad, mayonnaise, or cream pastries. The condition is self-limited.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains of amenorrhea and hot flushes for 3 months following pelvic radiotherapy. She had regular menses before the procedure. A urine pregnancy test was negative. Investigations revealed normal prolactin and TSH. FSH was elevated on two occasions. Which of the following findings are consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of secondary amenorrhea with signs of estrogen deficiency (hot flushes) along with elevated FSH in a woman <40 years is suggestive of premature ovarian failure (POF). Among the given options, low estradiol is consistent with this diagnosis.

Premature ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (range of 30 to 40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. Other findings consistent with POF are:

  • Low estradiol.
  • Elevated FSH/LH ratio 

Normal TSH and normal prolactin rules out other causes of secondary amenorrhea such as thyroid dysfunction and prolactinoma respectively. A urine pregnancy test must also be done on a woman of childbearing age with amenorrhea.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy.
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or
    • Offer donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B - FSH/LH ratio is elevated in POF.

Option C - Anti-Mullerian hormone levels are decreased in POF.

Option D - DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is elevated when an adrenal tumor is a cause of secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A snake catcher presents with headache, vomiting, difficulty in opening his mouth, and body ache. He is profusely sweating and there is generalized stiffness and tenderness of muscles. An image of the collected urine specimen is shown below. A bite from which of the following snakes is likely to be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dark brown or tea-colored urine are suggestive of a bite by a sea krait.

The sea krait belongs to the subfamily Hydrophidae, which also includes other sea snakes. The snake's venom is myotoxic.

Some common symptoms include headache, thirst, sweating, and vomiting. Generalized muscle ache, stiffness, and tenderness occur subsequently. Trismus is an early symptom and is followed by generalized flaccid paralysis similar to elapid neurotoxicity.

Myoglobin released from damaged skeletal muscles causes renal failure and myoglobinuria occurs after a bite, which manifests as the patient passing dark urine that is brown, red, or tea-colored. Potassium released from damaged muscles causes hyperkalemia which can cause cardiac failure.

Other options :

Option A: Bites of Elapidae like Cobras, Common Kraits, Mambas, and Coral Snakes, generally result in neurotoxic effects in the patient. The early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, and ‘gooseflesh’. Paralysis first presents with ptosis followed by external ophthalmoplegia. Later paralysis of other muscles continues with respiratory paralysis as the end result.

Options C and D: Bites by Viperidae like Saw scaled viper, Russell viper, or Pit Viper usually produce more severe local effects. There may be persistent bleeding from the wound site, venipuncture, or injection sites. Spontaneous systemic hemorrhage, gingival bleeding, epistaxis, hematemesis, hemoptysis, subconjunctival, retroperitoneal, and intracranial hemorrhages can occur.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae
