questions.text: An infant was brought to the hospital with complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. What is the lesion likely to be?
questions.solution:
The given lesion in the abdomen is likely to be strawberry naevus.

Strawberry naevus or capillary hemangiomata is the commonest birthmark seen predominantly in the head and neck. They appear by birth but resolve by 7 years. Girls are affected more commonly than boys.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over the eyelid).

Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

Other options:

Option A: Salmon patches are small, ill-defined, pink-colored macules commonly seen over the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia and disappear within 1 year. It is also a common vascular birthmark.

Option B: Port wine stains are less common capillary vascular malformations which appear at birth. They are seen as flat, smooth, purple areas mostly on the head and neck.

Option D: Pyogenic granuloma is an acquired vascular malformation. They have a tendency to bleed after trivial trauma and the lesions are raised, pedunculated, and nodular with superficial ulcers.

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried female patient presents with an abdominal mass, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, and fever. On palpation of the abdomen, it has a doughy feel. What could be the most likely causative agent in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of genital tuberculosis and the most likely causative agent, in this case, is Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis occurs secondary to primary foci. It initially affects the fallopian tubes bilaterally following which it spreads to other genital organs. The presenting features include a mass abdomen and associated menstrual irregularities. On palpation, the abdomen has a doughy feeling. Other features include dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and pelvic inflammatory disease (fever, nausea and vomiting, menstrual irregularities, vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, etc)

Hysterosalpingography reveals features suggestive of genital tuberculosis such as

  • Lead pipe appearance of the tubes
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx

The pelvic inflammatory mass in an unmarried woman is mostly tubercular in origin. A pelvic inflammatory disease that doesn't respond to treatment and recurs is likely to be due to tuberculosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, and Mycoplasma hominis are sexually transmitted and can cause pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain.  A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the given statements regarding the patient's likely condition is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is more obtuse (>100)
This condition is also called as Wilkie’s syndrome

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta is more acute (<20 degrees).

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

The given image shows compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the casualty with complaints of severe suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. On examination, there was gross distension of the lower abdomen. A CT was done as shown. All of the following can cause this condition except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario with a CT showing a grossly distended urinary bladder is suggestive of acute urinary obstruction. Cholinergics do not cause urinary obstruction. Anticholinergics and opiates cause urinary retention. 

Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Its clinical features include:

  • Inability to pass urine
  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • A distended, palpable, and tender bladder (shown below)

Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually in BPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they are flexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, can be used to overcome the urethral obstruction.

If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. 

If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators. In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in the distal urethra than the proximal urethra.

Significant hematuria can result in the formation of blood clots, which can further block the urethra and cause retention.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient was found to have multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. He is started on the intensive phase of treatment according to standard RNTCP guidelines. A week after treatment, he develops features of frank psychosis. Which of the following drugs is likely to have caused this?

RNTCP - Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme
questions.solution:
Cycloserine is likely to have caused features of frank psychosis.

It is an oral second-line antitubercular drug that inhibits M. tuberculosis and, according to RNTCP guidelines, is given during the intensive phase of treating multi-drug resistant TB.

This drug has the nickname, pych-serine, due to its strong association with neuropsychiatric adverse effects. Symptoms range from headache and somnolence to severe psychosis, seizures, and suicidal ideas. Therefore, it is contraindicated in epilepsy and given with caution in patients with depression. Pyridoxine 100 mg/day should be given to reduce neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Other options: 

Options A and C: Amikacin (aminoglycoside) and capreomycin (cyclic peptide analogue) are injectables that are also used as second-line antitubercular drugs. They cause ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. 

Option D: Rifampicin is a first-line anti-TB drug that is used to treat drug-sensitive TB. Other first-line drugs include isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of pressure epiphysis?
questions.solution:
Head of the femur is an example of a pressure epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis is articular in nature and takes part in the transmission of weight. Examples are head of the femur, the lower end of radius, etc.

Other options

Options A and D: Tubercles of humerus and trochanters of femur are examples of traction epiphysis.

Option C: Coracoid process of scapula is an example of the atavistic epiphysis.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery is taken inside the OT. You observe the following capnograph as the anesthetist starts the procedure. When is this pattern observed?
questions.solution:
The pattern is observed when the anesthetist commences the tracheal intubation of the patient. Tracheal intubation resembles a normal capnogram during controlled mechanical ventilation. 

A capnograph is a simple device that records and shows the concentration of carbon dioxide as a function of time. It describes both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. Phase 0 refers to the inspiratory segment while there are usually three phases during expiration. They are:

  • Phase I is the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration. It correlates to the expired dead space gas from the central conducting airways or from any equipment distal to the site of sampling. In this phase, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide is zero and thus there is no detectable CO2.
  • Phase II is characterized by a sharp rise in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2). This is due to the exchange of gases between the conducting airway and alveoli. 
  • Phase III has a plateau component (no rise in PCO2) which depicts the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the alveoli. It is flat throughout expiration in a homogeneously ventilated lung. 

 The below image shows normal capnography.

Other options:

Option A: In esophageal intubation, the capnograph remains flat or shows small abnormal waveforms which get diminished in height in the following 2 or 3 cycles till they are lost. It can be seen when the endotracheal tube is incorrectly placed. It is shown below.

 

Option B: In rebreathing, the fraction of inspired CO2 is above zero while the shape of the capnograph is preserved with one exception. EtCO2 rises as a consequence. 

Option D: Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by hypoventilation. In this, there is a rise in ETCO2 while the shape is otherwise preserved.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A soldier infested with body louse comes with a 2-month history of recurrent fever with chills, headaches, and shin pain lasting for five days. The physician suspects it to be trench fever.  Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Also known as five day fever
Causative organism is associated with culture negative endocarditis

questions.solution:
Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana. It is an exclusively human disease and there is no known animal reservoir.

Trench fever is also known as a five-day fever. It occurred among the soldiers fighting in the trenches during World War. It is caused by Bartonella quintana and the vector is body louse.

Clinical features include sudden onset fever lasting for 5 days. It is associated with chills, headaches, malaise, shin pain, and restlessness.

Bartonella quintana is now frequently seen as the cause of culture-negative endocarditis in homeless individuals.

Bartonella henselae is another important organism in this genus. Cat is the animal reservoir for Bartonella henselae. It causes cat scratch disease, bacillary angiomatosis, and bacillary peliosis. In cat scratch disease, patients present with fever and lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. A biopsy of the affected lymph node will show the presence of rounded or stellate granuloma. Organisms can be seen with Warthin-Starry staining.

Bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis are mainly seen in HIV-infected or immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is evaluated for familial dyslipidemia. His lab reports were consistent with type IV hypertriglyceridemia. The overproduced lipoprotein in this condition has all of the following apolipoproteins except?
questions.solution:
VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein) is the overproduced lipoprotein in type IV hypertriglyceridemia. VLDL has Apo E, Apo C-II, and Apo B-100 but not Apo A-I. Apo A-I is present in HDL and chylomicrons.

In type IV hypertriglyceridemia, there is overproduction of VLDL and cholesterol. However, LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and HDL (high-density lipoprotein) levels are usually subnormal. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, obesity, hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hyperuricemia. The lipid profile shows increased total cholesterol, increased triglycerides, and VLDL. 

Apolipoproteins are the protein component of lipoprotein and it has the following functions

  • Apo E - mediates remnant uptake (except LDL)
  • Apo A-I - activates LCAT (lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase). It is specific for HDL and is anti-atherogenic
  • Apo C-II - lipoprotein lipase cofactor
  • Apo B-100 - binds to LDL receptor
  • Apo B-48 - mediates chylomicron secretion
